HD What Do The Concepts Of ‘Social Licence’ And ‘Public Confidence’ Mean For Energy Projects And Their Regulators In Canada?
WC 1051 words
PD 26 October 2016
SN The Daily Oil Bulletin
SC DOILB
LA English
CY (c)2016 copyright Junewarren-Nickle’s Energy Group. All rights reserved

LP 

By Jennifer Winter

How did energy projects in Canada become so controversial? Public protests over pipelines and hydraulic fracturing have become common-place, and the National Energy Board has had record numbers of intervenors in pipeline hearings.

TD 

One might be tempted to lay the blame at Stephen Harper for calling pipelines “no-brainers” and giving the impression that pipelines such as Northern Gateway would be approved no matter what. But the controversy and debate around energy projects spans much more than pipelines. One only has to look at the discussion of hydraulic fracturing in Eastern and Atlantic Canada to realize that fossil fuel development is not generally accepted. Opposition are not limited to fossil fuels; renewables such as wind are equally contentious, with protests in Ontario and Quebec. And let’s not forget the controversy over the Site C hydro dam in B.C. — protest groups have given an ultimatum that the government must choose between LNG exports and Site C.

Politicians of all stripes across the country have latched onto the idea of “social licence” — an amorphous concept that suggests energy projects need not only regulatory approval but also approval from society. Rachel Notley used the idea of social licence to link getting pipelines built with Alberta’s Climate Leadership Plan. In Nova Scotia, the government named having a social licence in place as one of the conditions for lifting the moratorium on hydraulic fracturing. Justin Trudeau stated it was necessary for Energy East to proceed. Tom Mulcair claimed pipeline projects “will not obtain the social licence they require without having a rigorous review process in place to ensure environmental sustainability, community partnership and long-term prosperity of our economic development.”

This issue has become such a prominent part of the discussion around energy projects that Trudeau has initiated a review of federal energy and environmental regulation, citing the need to restore trust and confidence in both. As well, the Energy and Mines Ministers’ Conference — the annual gathering of federal, provincial and territorial ministers responsible for energy and mining portfolios — convened a working group on public confidence in advance of their August 2016 meeting in Winnipeg. There is even a report with different case studies on “building public confidence” in mining and energy projects, which aims to describe the role of government in public confidence.

What do the concepts of “social licence” and “public confidence” mean for energy projects and their regulators in Canada? This is the question I explore with my co-authors — an interdisciplinary collaboration of academics from across Canada — in a white paper published by the University of Calgary’s School of Public Policy in May 2016. We explore the origins of the term “social licence” and related concepts, and offer three perspectives on the state of energy regulation in Canada — broken, not broken, and can be improved. These led to eight recommendations for improving energy policy and regulation in Canada. Here, I focus on three of the recommendations that, in my opinion, are the most helpful for improving energy policy and regulation in Canada.

As part of white paper, we provide a comprehensive literature review of the origins of “social licence”: the idea has its roots in the mining sector and corporate environmental performance more broadly. The concept of social acceptance, on the other hand, originated in the development of renewable energy technologies. Both terms have a common element: the idea of legitimacy, that the actions of an entity are viewed as appropriate or desirable, and have support from stakeholders, the general public, opinion leaders and government officials.

Comparing these concepts to the current debate about energy use and energy sources in Canada, we argue that the idea of social licence is no longer a useful concept, having broadened in scope so much that its meaning has become “unclear, amorphous and confusing.” Moreover, we recommend that whenever regulators, policy-makers or politicians use terms such as “social licence,” “acceptance,” “support” or “public confidence” they do so carefully, with a clear explanation of their interpretation of the term.

Relatedly, we discuss the extent to which the public can and should be involved in energy discussions and regulatory hearings. We note that regulators are often placed in a difficult position of determining who can have standing in the hearing of an energy project, given the regulator’s mandate and the scope of the project. Developing clear standards for identifying hearing participants that are consistent across jurisdictions will help build legitimacy in regulatory processes. The Canadian Energy Strategy is a natural place to implement this policy change.

A key issue in the legitimacy of regulatory processes, and in the current energy debate in Canada, is the scope of regulatory hearings. For practical and statutory reasons, the scope of topics for determining whether a project is in the public interest is limited; this creates frustration for Canadians with concerns outside of a regulator’s or hearing’s mandate. This is a clear policy gap, as there is limited scope for Canadians to engage with policy-makers beyond regulatory hearings. We recommend energy regulators should report recurring concerns beyond their mandate to policy-makers, as this information can and should be used to help Canadians speak back to policy-makers.

At the end of the day, Canadians appear to be caught up in a “great energy debate” — about where our energy comes from, how we use it, and what the future of energy use will be in Canada. It behooves our provincial and federal governments to adjust energy policy and regulation to ensure there is an outcome, rather than endless debate. While the Trudeau government’s modernization plan for the NEB is a start, it should not be considered a silver bullet, as our current debate is much deeper and more complex than the regulation of interprovincial pipelines. The white paper provides recommendations for improving trust in and legitimacy of energy regulation in Canada, which is something all levels of government should strive for.

Jennifer Winter is Scientific Director of Energy and Environmental Policy at the School of Public Policy, and an Assistant Professor of Economics, University of Calgary. Opinions expressed here do not necessarily reflect the opinions of my co-authors.


IN 
ifrack : Fracking | i1 : Energy | i13 : Crude Oil/Natural Gas Upstream Operations | ibasicm : Basic Materials/Resources | iextra : Natural Gas/Oil Extraction | imet : Mining/Quarrying

NS 
ccat : Corporate/Industrial News | c13 : Regulation/Government Policy | ncat : Content Types | nfact : Factiva Filters | nfcpin : C&E Industry News Filter

RE 
cana : Canada | namz : North America

PUB 
Junewarren-Nickle’s Energy Group

AN 
Document DOILB00020161026ecaq00004


SE SNL Extra
HD Energy experts to gas industry: Help, don't obstruct, work on climate issues
BY Sean Sullivan
WC 685 words
PD 6 October 2016
SN SNL Daily Gas Report
SC DGR
VOL Issue: 92617
LA English
CY Copyright 2016. SNL Financial LC

LP 

Natural gas has potential to carry much of the world's energy load for the next three decades if the industry confronts and resolves concerns about climate change, energy experts said at a recent gas industry conference.

Representatives from the energy industry and environmental advocacy groups at Energy Dialogues LLC's North American Gas Forum agreed that promise and challenges fill the future of natural gas, which is in great supply in the U.S. and in great demand in countries looking to back up renewable energy sources or reduce the use of coal in pursuit of economic and environmental benefits.

TD 

"There is a huge opportunity for natural gas … if natural gas is viewed correctly as a clean energy source," Richard Newell, president of Resources for the Future, said in an Oct. 4 panel.

"All the boxes are checked," Newell said. Conventional air pollution from gas combustion is already low, he said. Gas is a great substitute for coal, especially if the methane emissions are controlled, he said. Gas can be coupled with carbon capture and carbon storage, as shown by pilot projects in Texas.

"If that carbon is sequestered in the ground, natural gas can be a zero-emitter," according to Newell, a former administrator of the U.S. Energy Information Administration. "I really believe that."

Shale gas added about 20 Bcf/d of incremental production to the U.S. total over the last four years, primarily from the Marcellus formation, Berkeley Research Group Director Tom Choi observed the day before. Yet most Americans either do not know or do not care about the country's energy successes, he said.

All this gas can work well with renewables, said Ben Ratner, director of corporate partnerships for the Environmental Defense Fund. His group is trying to make sure market processes and FERC rules work to provide a "package solution."

Ratner urged the industry and its trade associations to rethink their approaches. Groups that represent the long-term interests of gas companies should "take a modernized, forward-leaning, collaborative approach that includes accelerating the sharing of best practices, catalyzing technology development and innovation on these legitimate risks and challenges, and coming to the table — or at least not interfering with some of their more forward-thinking operators — to develop the public policies of the future that not only the planet needs, but are so critical to establish trust [with the public]," he said.

Some major industry players support the idea of collaboration. Michael Crothers, president of Shell Canada Ltd. and vice president of North American unconventionals business at Royal Dutch Shell plc's Shell Upstream Americas, encouraged other members of the industry to build relationships and respond to public concerns and feedback.

"The world needs all the energy it can get, from all different forms, and gas is going to be a key part of that," Crothers told the forum's largely industry-based crowd. "The way to enable that to happen is to continue to build trust. Get out there. Build relationships. Put more emphasis within your organizations on social acceptance."

"Secondly, build your credibility by aligning with environmental groups, with academics and with government to actually create the momentum and make it easy for politicians to agree and move us forward as a society," he said.

"And third, keep thinking global," he said, "because gas has a huge role to play in managing global greenhouse gases, not just in continental North America."

Shell and other oil and gas companies have worked with Environmental Defense Fund and other environmental groups. Shell supports the "Rational Middle Energy Series," a group of short films that cover energy and environmental issues by Director and Producer Gregory Kallenberg, who moderated the forum panel.

Sarah Sandberg, COO at the Colorado Oil and Gas Association, summed it up for the industry executives. "You're at the table or you're on the menu," she said. "Choose to be part of the solution. It's tough work, but it's our responsibility to do it."


IN 
i13 : Crude Oil/Natural Gas Upstream Operations | i16101 : Electric Power Generation | i8395205 : Public Relations | i1 : Energy | i16 : Electricity/Gas Utilities | i83952 : Market Research/Public Relations | iadv : Advertising/Marketing/Public Relations | ibcs : Business/Consumer Services | ieutil : Electric Utilities | iutil : Utilities

NS 
gclimt : Climate Change | gcat : Political/General News | genv : Environmental News | gglobe : Global/World Issues

RE

Document DGR0000020161007eca60000a


HD Top 4 Drivers Impacting the Legal Marijuana Market Until 2020, Reports Technavio
WC 1035 words
PD 29 September 2016
ET 11:03
SN Business Wire
SC BWR
LA English
CY (c) 2016 Business Wire. All Rights Reserved.

LP 

LONDON--(BUSINESS WIRE)--September 29, 2016--

Technavio analysts forecast the global legal marijuana market to grow at an astounding CAGR of more than 37% during the forecast period, according to their latest report.

TD 

The research study covers the present scenario and growth prospects of the global legal marijuana market for 2016-2020. To calculate the market size, the report considers the revenue generated from legal sales of marijuana. It also presents the vendor landscape of the top six vendors in the market along with listing down the other prominent vendors in the market.

Marijuana, one of the premium variants of cannabis, is used for recreational (psychoactive drugs) and medicinal purposes. Usage of marijuana for recreational purpose is expected to increase significantly over the forecast period, which in turn, can lead to increase in the global demand for marijuana. Vendors are introducing different products like marijuana-based tablets and topical applications to propel the sale of marijuana. In 2015, the market generated the major part of its revenue from the sales of marijuana through retail and convenience stores. Medicinal marijuana refers to the use of cannabis and cannabinoids for treating chronic pain and spasms in patients. The adoption of cannabis for diverse medical purposes have rapidly grown during the period 2013-2015. The legal medicinal marijuana market accounted for 75.26% of total marijuana market in 2015.

Request a sample report: http://www.technavio.com/request-a-sample?report=53196[http://www.technavio.com/request-a-sample?report=53196]

Technavio's sample reports are free of charge and contain multiple sections of the report including the market size and forecast, drivers, challenges, trends, and more.

Technavio media and entertainment analysts highlight the following four factors that are contributing to the growth of the global legal marijuana market: 

   -- Technological advances in multiple domains of market 
 
   -- Premium pricing due to high energy consumption in marijuana production 
 
   -- Rising social acceptance of marijuana and growing business opportunities 
 
   -- Increasing business sophistication

Technological advances in multiple domains of market

Ujjwal Doshi, a lead media and entertainment services analyst at Technavio, says, "Technological advances in all these operations coupled with the millennial generation's preference for marijuana for recreational purposes is expected to have a huge impact on the market's growth. With the increasing legalization of marijuana during the forecast period, it is important for vendors to engage with their customers, increase the production capacity and to comply with the legality of marijuana use in various countries."

Premium pricing due to high energy consumption in marijuana production

The production of marijuana in in-house conditions is an extremely energy intensive process. In 2015, the electricity consumption accounted for 0.85% of the electricity output in countries where marijuana is legal. Electricity is mainly used to maintain optimal growing conditions for the plants like the generation of intense heat through indoor cultivation lights and operation of ventilation, cooling, and humidity management systems.

The prohibition and strict penalties imposed on the cultivation of marijuana have also considerably increased the selling price, which allows the vendors to recoup their costs on energy investments and maintain high-profit margins. Vendors are not very motivated to increase the energy efficiency of their operations because customers are willing to pay any premium amount to get the product.

Rising social acceptance of marijuana and growing business opportunities

The growth of the marijuana market has significantly increased the revenue for dispensary owners as well as cultivators and governments. In addition, the growing popularity of marijuana for recreational purpose is increasing the market competition and business opportunity for several vendors. Ancillary businesses such as cannabis oil market, hookah parlors, bubblers, volcano vaporizers and percolated bongs, THC-infused ice cream, and brownies are also profiting from the growing legal marijuana market.

Increasing business sophistication

"With more vendors entering the market, marijuana market is growing out of the emerging-business phase. The increased competition is expected to squeeze the profit margins which will result in the mid-stage companies refining their strategies," adds Ujjwal.

The global marijuana industry is expected to grow rapidly during the forecast period with the focus shifting from developing operational standards of manufacturing marijuana to enhancing strategic priorities, including marketing and target areas. The importance of business intelligence is growing in all industries, including marijuana market. It will play a significant role in the marijuana market's growth as data-driven decision gain prominence. Decisions regarding retail location, pricing decisions, and product mixes will not be more empirical and not driven by instinct and anecdote.

Top vendors: 

   -- American Cannabis 
 
   -- Canopy 
 
   -- Greengro 
 
   -- mCig 
 
   -- Medical Marijuana 
 
   -- Mentor Capital 
 
   -- Terra Tech 
 
   -- United Cannabis

Browse Related Reports: 

   -- Cannabis Market in the US 2015-2019 
 
   -- Epilepsy Market in the US 2015-2019 
 
   -- Multiple Sclerosis Market in the US 2015-2019

Do you need a report on a market in a specific geographical cluster or country but can't find what you're looking for? Don't worry, Technavio also takes client requests. Please contact enquiry@technavio.com with your requirements and our analysts will be happy to create a customized report just for you.

About Technavio

Technavio is a leading global technology research and advisory company. The company develops over 2000 pieces of research every year, covering more than 500 technologies across 80 countries. Technavio has about 300 analysts globally who specialize in customized consulting and business research assignments across the latest leading edge technologies.

Technavio analysts employ primary as well as secondary research techniques to ascertain the size and vendor landscape in a range of markets. Analysts obtain information using a combination of bottom-up and top-down approaches, besides using in-house market modeling tools and proprietary databases. They corroborate this data with the data obtained from various market participants and stakeholders across the value chain, including vendors, service providers, distributors, re-sellers, and end-users.

If you are interested in more information, please contact our media team at media@technavio.com.

View source version on businesswire.com: http://www.businesswire.com/news/home/20160929005613/en/[http://www.businesswire.com/news/home/20160929005613/en/] 

 
    CONTACT: Technavio Research

Jesse Maida

Media & Marketing Executive

US: +1 630 333 9501

UK: +44 208 123 1770

www.technavio.com[http://www.technavio.com]

NS

SE News | Toronto Star
HD Trudeau running out of moves on oil pipeline projects: Paul Wells
BY  Paul Wells[https://author.thestar.com/content/thestar/authors.wells_paul.html]
WC 809 words
PD 24 September 2016
SN The Toronto Star
SC TOR
LA English
CY Copyright (c) 2016 The Toronto Star

LP 

I don’t know about all y’all, but I’m wondering when the social licence shows up.

“Social licence” is a term, never too carefully defined, for broad social acceptance of some big change. It came into vogue in the late years of Stephen Harper’s government to explain why he couldn’t get oil pipelines built even though he was the country’s biggest fan of oil pipelines.

TD 

The answer came, not (or not only) from implacable Harper opponents or from people who could not tolerate the notion of oilsands development and oil exports, that Harper was going about this business wrong. By making himself big oil’s pal, Harper was alienating indigenous groups, environmentalists, U.S. presidents and, just in general, the neighbours. These groups could then, in various ways, deny pipeline projects the “social licence” they would need to proceed.

This line came, for instance, from Jim Prentice in several speeches and articles after he left Harper’s government and before he became premier of Alberta.

And more important, it was part of the sales pitch for two governments now serving in Canada: Rachel Notley’s provincial NDP government in Alberta, and Justin Trudeau’s federal government in Ottawa.

“Our government will boost exports by seeking out new relationships, strengthening old ones and enhancing Alberta’s environmental record,” Notley told a business group soon after becoming Alberta premier in 2015.

Two years before that, launching his campaign for the federal Liberal leadership, Trudeau spoke to the Calgary Petroleum Club. “If we had stronger environmental policy in this country — stronger oversight, tougher penalties, and yes, some sort of means to price carbon pollution — then I believe the Keystone XL pipeline would have been approved already,” he said.

“Social licence is more important than ever,” he added. “Governments may be able to issue permits, but only communities can grant permission.”

I belabour all this ancient history because on Thursday more than 50 indigenous nations across North America formed a “treaty alliance” against oilsands development. The group is officially opposed to any new pipeline project, including one Trudeau has said he favours: Kinder Morgan’s Trans Mountain project in British Columbia.

The indigenous groups have vowed to back their words with action. “They pledge to “resist the use of our respective territories and coasts in connection with the expansion of the production of the Alberta tarsands, including for the transport of such expanded production, whether by pipeline, rail or tanker . . . .”

National party leaders have had a fun couple of years declaring which projects they support and which they oppose. Trudeau liked Keystone XL, which has seemed dead since U.S. President Barack Obama declined permission for the pipeline shortly after last year’s Canadian federal election. He often says nice things about Trans Mountain. No matter. The indigenous groups are in the business of shutting down all pipeline projects in every direction. They want to ensure “that the tarsands are not able to escape by another pipeline route and thereby cripple efforts to fight the climate crisis.”

These groups, like every environmental lobby worth the name, seem unswayed by the prospect of a national Canadian carbon price at some not-too-distant point in the future. They seem unconvinced, and it’s no wonder, by the very mixed results the Trudeau government has had in attempting to reform the National Energy Board.

Whether you feel good or bad about the near-total collapse of any chance that oil will find its way to market through new pipelines anytime soon will depend on your feelings about oilsands oil and climate change. But it’s not great news for Trudeau and Notley.

Their selling proposition was that, by treating energy and the environment and First Nations and communities less menacingly than Harper did, they could get better results. It was part of their selling proposition in the 2015 elections, and if it is demonstrated to be false it will undermine their appeal when they try to win again.

One wonders how much longer Trudeau, in particular, will keep standing around watching all his efforts on energy exports collapse. “We need national leadership that will make a clear, positive case about what is in our national interest,” he told the Petroleum Club in 2013. If he had the big job, he said then, he’d have “joined and contributed to . . . efforts to build a national energy strategy.”

He has the job now, and the opponents of the projects Trudeau says he favours are not wasting time. His move now — if he has one.


ART 
"Social licence" is a term that was part of the sales pitch for two governments: Rachel Notley's provincial NDP government in Alberta, and Justin Trudeau's federal government in Ottawa, writes Paul Wells.

NS 
gcat : Political/General News | genv : Environmental News | gpol : Domestic Politics | gpir : Politics/International Relations

RE 
cana : Canada | namz : North America

PUB 
Toronto Star Newspapers Limited

AN 
Document TOR0000020160924ec9o000ma


HD Strategy Session
WC 3331 words
PD 9 September 2016
SN Power Play With Don Martin
SC ONHILL
LA English
CY Copyright 2016 CTV Television Inc. All Rights Reserved.

LP 

Host(s): MERCEDES STEPHENSON

MERCEDES STEPHENSON: Time for our week-ending strategy session with political commentator Gerry Nicholls coming to us from downtown Toronto; in Regina, we have sally Housser, a senior consultant with Navigator; and with me in studio, Greg MacEachern with Environics Communications . Well we promoed this before the break, so let's start with it, Sally. The NDP meltdown continues, Alexandre Boulerice saying that he will not seek the leadership. He is certainly not the first and probably won't be the last prominent NDP MP to say he is not interested. It seems that there is a real dearth of strong candidates. What do you attribute that to, Sally?

TD 

SALLY HOUSSER (Navigator Ltd): Well, first of all I argue that there's not enough strong candidates. I think there's some interesting names that have been floated around. I know I have heard of Jagmeet Singh, a tremendously popular MLA in Ontario and deputy premier. I've heard people talk about Mike Layton. Charlie Angus is another name that keeps popping up. Niki Ashton of course who ran last time. But I think people are still waiting right now, they're still in the waiting game. It's a long leadership contest. So, you know, obviously it's easy to rule things out, but takes a little longer to have those conversations with your friends, family, and people that might be organizing for you before you make your clear decision to move on. Obviously the NDP is in a bit of a turmoil right now, still questions swirling around Tom as interim leader. I think obviously members of parliament and Tom himself and the membership really has to ask themselves now what's best for the party. What is going to help us move past this period and keep rebuilding, particularly as we go into the fall? For Tom, obviously his strength is in the House of Commons. But what you really need to see from a leader is not just that work in parliament, but in rebuilding the party, rebuilding the party and fundraising, and in organization and ensuring that we have the tools we need to still be a strong opposition party, but also grow as a political party.

STEPHENSON: Okay. So Gerry, let's ask you, you're also a Conservative party which is having a bit of a leadership contest of itself, and perhaps some of its own internal meltdowns at this point. Is a long space in front of the leadership like this problematic? You have two parties doing it. And it means the Liberals can just go to town with a very strong leader while these other parties fight it out internally and basically fall off the radar screen. GERRY NICHOLLS (Political Commentator): Well I think in this case, for these parties, a long leadership race is probably a good idea, because I have the sense that both New Democrats and Conservatives are kind of like accident victims right now. They're still kind of in a state of shock. They're still kind of traumatized. And also they're also asking themselves some pretty profound questions. What do we want to be when we grow up? I mean how are we going to redefine our ideologies so that they're relevant in the 21st century? So those are some really deep questions, and I think it's going to take a long time to come up with those answers. I think the NDP has an added challenge in that unlike the Conservatives they have an ideological rival on the left, i.e., the Liberal Party of Canada, which under Justin Trudeau has become kind of the progressive party, and in a sense has sucked all the air out of the NDP balloon. So, yeah, both parties have challenges moving forward. Both parties are having a tough time in their leadership races. But we'll see what the world is like in two years. We don't know. That's the thing about politics. Things can change really quickly, and two years from now, things might look better for both the New Democrats and the Conservatives.

STEPHENSON: Greg, one of the big questions that's come up here is the role of Tom Mulcair , and whether him staying on helps the party because it's the steady hand and guided leadership even though he seems to be nowhere. He pops up maybe once every couple of months. Doesn't seem too happy to be there. Others are saying, no, he's got to step down so that someone else can take over as interim leader and we can start to refresh. What do you think the best thing is for the party when it comes to Tom Mulcair ?

GREG MACEAHERN (Environics Communications ): What surprised me about the, how badly he lost the leadership review was that no one expected it. And that is an important detail. That means that he, perhaps he and the people around him, who are usually the best and the brightest in every party, I know my friend Sally is out west now, so that's my, you know, perhaps they should bring Sally back, but I think part of the challenge is how they did not see this coming. That speaks to me as somebody who's not connected to his caucus, to his party, and there's something really wrong there. To me, at that point, that's when you have to step down. The NDP don't have a Bob Rae at this point. Bob Rae kept the Liberals alive in order to get to that next leadership point. Bob Rae was magnificent in the House of Commons during question period. You could hear a pin drop. And I think they need to turn to somebody who is not the former leader, not the future leader, but somebody who can kind of keep the lights on while, as what Sally talked about, increased membership through fundraising goes on.

STEPHENSON: Okay, let's switch gears here a little bit and get into some social media controversy, because that's always fun. There's a new Facebook ad. Check it out. Take a look at this for our viewers at home. It's from Brad Trost. He is a Conservative MP. And you can see there it says Brad Trost is 100 percent Conservative and will fight for you. Like this if you think we should keep men out of women's washrooms, and there's a picture of a little girl. This is, I assume, a reference to some of the debates about transgendered people in Canada being able to choose which bathroom they go into, or non-gendered bathrooms. Gerry, is this a smart approach for the Conservatives, or for this particular MP?

NICHOLLS: Well I think we have to put this in context. What I find interesting about the Conservative leadership race is that, and I kind of thought that would happen, is that the party is kind of breaking down into its ideological component parts, so it's kind of like a gang war of the various ideologies. You have the libertarians under Maxime Bernier, you have the red Tories with Michael Chong at their head, and Kellie Leitch seems to have staked out the populist position. Trost is sort of saying I'm the social Conservative champion. In fact, he's really bold about it. He makes no bones about it. He is the so-con in this race. He is their flag bearer. So I think with this ad, this is, he thinks this is a really hot-button issue ad for him, and something that will appeal to the hardcore of the hardcore so-cons. Is it amateurish? Yes. Is it simplistic? Yes. Is it going to invite a lot of mockery? Yes. But as they say in the military, if something stupid but works, then it isn't stupid, and we'll see if this works for him or not.

STEPHENSON: Sally, do you think that that is part of, we were talking about this sort of culture war internally in the Conservatives where you have Kellie Leitch and maybe Brad Trost on the so-con side of things, you have Rona Ambrose very clearly moving away from that even though she's the interim leader. Is this all part of the Tories trying to figure out where their base is at and where they need to move as a party?

HOUSSER: I think so. And, you know, I have to say that I would actually take kind of a slow burn NDP leadership race over what we're seeing out of the Conservatives right now. Obviously people are trying to stake out their ground, wedge people on certain issues, and I think that's natural in a leadership race. But what I heard, and I was in Calgary yesterday and in Edmonton last week, Conservatives I talked to are extremely frustrated that as this race heats up and is generating a fair bit of the media attention, but it's all the wrong things, it's all the things that I think many people in the Conservative party want to move away from, they're not talking about economic issues. They're not talking about issues that just really affect the day-to-day families. These are, you know, it's not dog whistle politics, it's fog horn I heard somebody say the other day, and I would have to agree with that. But, you know, I mean just the Brad Trost ad, it's just laughable, the idea that this is going to be his winner, you know, fighting against transgendered people being able to take a leak wherever they feel like is just nuts to me.

UNIDENTIFIED MAN: Can we say that on TV? HOUSSER: I say bring it on. Keep it coming, right. STEPHENSON: Let's be fair here, Greg. Every party, especially when they are in opposition, there's a lot more freedom for people to say what they want. There are some Canadians who will see that ad and they'll say, yeah, I like that. You know, is there a place, or is this kind of a rogue MP thing?

MACEACHERN: But there is a freedom in every party for stupidity, you know, but there's a cost for that.

HOUSSER: There is.

MACEACHERN: Cheryl Gallant comes to mind. Brad Trost. Brad said in the summer that, I believe, something like God put Conservatives on the planet to lower taxes. You know, washroom issues, one of the great issues of our times. And, you know, this is something that's going to solve it. I just think this shows that there is no Conservative party. There's a Harper party, it's made up of progressives and reform, they got together, they were able to govern for about ten years, they still don't know who they are.

STEPHENSON: Okay, I've got to break in here because right now we're going to Montreal where the city's mayor Denis Coderre is holding a press conference on the resignation of all three board panelists tasked with reviewing the Energy East pipeline.

DENIS CODERRE (Montreal Mayor Through Translator): Mr. Watson made the decision of integrity. He was diligent and he did everything he could in order to protect the integrity of the National Energy Board . It is with great satisfaction that the metropolitan community of Montreal, and the union of municipalities of Quebec, receives this decision from the chair and the vice-chair of the NEB. And as we can see it, it's not only the panel as such are, or it's the president, Mr. Watson himself. And in order to demonstrate that he wants to be entirely impartial, and to manage the perceptions, and he's removing himself from this file. So we have to recognize that and to congratulate him. And moreover, it's not only the panel or the president, but it is the entire staff that has dealt with this file. This being said, I also want, like the decision demonstrates, that way it can be ensured that the next commissioners will be bilingual and will be competent. We have to make sure that those people can speak in both official languages. But with all due respect, I would like to make some suggestions. Given the fact that there's reality of social acceptance, and as well a reality with the indigenous people, that we have to be sensitive with managing how the territory will be developed, but we have to make sure that all partners can contribute, as it should be, in this discussion, in this debate. It should be also appropriate that the commissioners might be more sensitive, and we need people who acknowledge and recognize that we need also some oil through pipelines, but we have to see and be sensitive in order to have a debate that will cover all the angles. Therefore, we will be waiting for obviously the nomination of those new commissioners and the metropolitan community of Montreal and the Association of Municipalities of Quebec, and as a chair of the Montreal community we will take part with to the hearings, with the belief that a project that is presented to us is not a good project, it is bad, and it came because of the businesses of TransCanada . And TransCanada itself has some homework to do. I will never apologize as the mayor of Montreal, as the chair of the Metropolitan Community of Montreal to protect our environment and also to guarantee healthy economic development, and also make sure that my citizens and my co-citizens are safe and we are responsible. Environment is also for me a jurisdiction that I share. So obviously when through the years the metropolitan community of Montreal gave itself some tools for planning and development, it is appropriate that we talked about a new pipeline that we can take into consideration the consensus that we shape together.

CODERRE: I've been saying since day one that I have, that I trust National Energy Board , and I clearly trust also its president, Mr. Peter Watson . I would like to first of all notice that Mr. Watson showed that he's a man of integrity, that he'd been working in due diligence, that he's been doing his homework, and that the decision that he's been putting up together was for the sake of the integrity of the institution. And I think that we have to salute that. We have to thank him for his sensitivity. And he understands the importance of that issue, but it's also the importance of the process itself. So I want to salute him. I want to say that he just confirmed the trust that I have in its institution and in the president itself. And now it's, the fact that now we're talking about recusal of the commissioners, also of Mr. Watson himself for that file, but all the people who work around that file, just sent a strong message that they've been doing their homework, and it's a good decision. The Montreal metropolitan community, me as a president, the Quebec Municipalities Union will participate in the future audience. But I think that respectfully we should suggest maybe that not only, and we think that...

STEPHENSON: Okay. So that is obviously the Mayor of Montreal, Denis Coderre. He's been a vocal opponent of this pipeline. It's been a difficult issue for the Trudeau government. It's just gotten a lot more difficult with the entire hearing panel walking away and resigning. How does the federal government handle this now? They haven't really wanted to take ownership, but it kind of seems like there might need to be a hand on the rudder.

MACEACHERN: Yeah, and I'm not sure I entirely agree with you. Quickly, I would say from a public policy perspective, it's essential that you have public confidence in the process. So I think the step in that case, it's good. Speaking politically, we just heard from the mayor of Montreal. One of the biggest thorns, political thorns in the side on this issue is now happy. So from a political perspective, that's done. The two gentlemen were appointed by the previous Conservative government, there is an opportunity here for the Liberal government to now appoint a couple of people and have more input on the process. I would see it, yes, as a challenge, but there's also an opportunity there for them.

STEPHENSON: Okay, Sally, the Liberal government replaces this entire hearing board with Liberal appointees instead of Conservative. Is that likely to convince any of the opponents of this pipeline who aren't Denis Coderre and a former Liberal? I'm thinking of First Nations, I'm thinking of environmental opponents, that the process has changed fundamentally at all?

HOUSSER: Yeah, I think just the replacing of the people on the board, it has to be more than that. During the election, the Liberals made promises about reforming and renewing the National Energy Board , and what we see right now is, with these hearings, and the gong show that it was, I think it's going to be difficult for people that, I heard Mr. Coderre say that he had confidence, but I don't know that a lot of Canadians do. I think in order for people to accept whatever the findings are of National Energy Board review, they have to have a certain trust in the system. I don't see that that's there necessarily. I certainly hope that the Liberals really consider that moving forward is that rebuilding that trust is a huge part of it. What I do know is certainly out west here is tremendously frustrating that we seem to be as a country in just gridlock, not just for this but numerous projects. And, you know, I feel like for years there hasn't been anything on a national scope, certainly from the energy sector, approved. So something has got to give. We need to be able to get our products to market. We need to be able to create jobs here in Canada. And this process continues to be tremendously frustrating, particularly for provinces like Alberta.

STEPHENSON: Mmm. And, Gerry, you know, I hear a lot from people in Alberta, that's where I grew up, who are worried. They're saying the pipelines aren't being approved, nothing is happening, it's stuck, this process now just seems to be even more stuck than before. What does the government need to do?

NICHOLLS: Well I think people in Alberta should be worried by what's happening here. This is one of those issues which divides Harper from Justin Trudeau . Harper loved pipelines, right. He would put a pipeline through his grandmother's basement if he had to.

HOUSSER: He never got any built, though.

NICHOLLS: Trudeau hates them. Trudeau hates pipelines, but I don't think he has the political courage to actually nix it. So what I think he's doing is he's sorts of taking the Barack Obama approach, which he did with Keystone, which is to keep dragging it out and dragging it out and dragging it out until it dies. I would be surprised if this pipeline ever gets through.

STEPHENSON: Okay. Well we'll certainly be keeping an eye on it. Thank you very much to our Friday strategists for joining us. We'll see you next week.

NICHOLLS: Thank you.

MACEACHERN: Take care.

HOUSSER: Thank you.

STEPHENSON: When we return, our Friday press gallery is here with their political plays and misplays of the week. Stay with us.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

HD TRP Globe says TransCanada hearings postponed amid protests
CR Stockwatch
WC 222 words
PD 30 August 2016
SN Canada Stockwatch
SC CNSW
LA English
CY (c) 2016 Canjex Publishing Ltd.

LP 

TransCanada Corp (TSX:TRP)

Shares Issued 799,595,972

TD 

Last Close 8/29/2016 $60.21

Tuesday August 30 2016 - In the News

The Globe and Mail reports in its Tuesday edition that TransCanada received an angry reception in Montreal on Monday as protesters chanting anti-pipeline slogans shut down a scheduled regulatory hearing into its proposed $15.7-billion Energy East pipeline. The Globe's Shawn McCarthy writes that TransCanada and its industry backers face major hurdles to win public acceptance in Quebec for the project that would deliver 1.1 million barrels per day of Western crude to refineries and an export terminal in Eastern Canada. After four sessions in New Brunswick earlier this month, the environmental assessment panel was scheduled to commence several days of hearings in Montreal but cancelled the session before it began when a burly protester charged the hearing table and had to be restrained by several security guards. The National Energy Board late Monday said it will postpone proceedings on Tuesday in light of the disruption. Critics in Quebec are complaining about pro-pipeline bias among panel members. While the federal government has jurisdiction over pipelines, Prime Minister Justin Trudeau has stressed the importance of resource projects winning social acceptance from the local citizens and first nations.

SE Report on Business
HD Protests stall Energy East hearings in Montreal
BY By SHAWN McCARTHY
WC 814 words
PD 30 August 2016
SN The Globe and Mail
SC GLOB
ED Ontario
PG B1
LA English
CY ©2016 The Globe and Mail Inc. All Rights Reserved.

LP 

TransCanada Corp. received an angry reception in Montreal on Monday as protesters chanting anti-pipeline slogans shut down a scheduled regulatory hearing into its proposed $15.7-billion Energy East pipeline.

The company and its industry backers face major hurdles to win public acceptance in Quebec for the project that would deliver 1.1 million barrels per day of Western crude – much of it diluted bitumen from the oil sands – to refineries and an export terminal in Eastern Canada.

TD 

After four sessions in New Brunswick earlier this month, the environmental assessment panel was scheduled to commence several days of hearings in Montreal but cancelled the session before it began when a burly protester charged the hearing table and had to be restrained by several security guards.

The National Energy Board late Monday said it will postpone proceedings on Tuesday in light of the disruption. Critics in Quebec are complaining about propipeline bias among panel members and urging the federal Liberal government to suspend the review.

The Energy East project has pitted some eastern politicians, aboriginal leaders and environmentalists against industry and government leaders in the West, who are eager to gain broader market access and international prices for crude exports.

While the federal government has jurisdiction over pipeline approvals, Prime Minister Justin Trudeau has stressed the importance of resource projects winning social acceptance from the local citizens and First Nations.

Montreal Mayor Denis Coderre, along with the mayor of Laval and other municipal representatives, walked out of the hearings Monday not long after the demonstrators charged in.

Mr. Coderre was the first person scheduled to give testimony Monday but chose instead to leave, calling the protests a “masquerade."

He and other local mayors oppose the project. TransCanada has not been able to confirm what approach would be used for the pipeline to cross the Ottawa River, raising concerns about a potential spill upstream from the drinking water intake for Greater Montreal.

“There are too many problems we are witnessing to accept the project," Mr. Coderre told reporters after he decided to leave Monday's hearings. “We're saying the project [TransCanada] presented is wrong, it's bad and we don't have the answers. And frankly, one of the main issues is contingency plans, everything regarding safety."

TransCanada spokesman Tim Duboyce said the company was eager to resume the review process. “We have had and continue to have a positive dialogue with Quebeckers on Energy East," he said in an e-mailed statement.

“Listening, earning trust and dealing with the public's concerns will help us build and operate a safe pipeline."

Mr. Duboyce noted that Quebec business and labour leaders have endorsed the project, which the company says will generate 3,100 direct and indirect jobs in the province during its construction.

Members of Quebec construction unions demonstrated in support of the pipeline outside the building where the hearing was to be held.

Former New Brunswick Premier Frank McKenna said Monday's protest and previous opposition from Mr. Coderre suggest the project's critics are uninterested in evidence about safety measures that would be presented at the hearings. “Before the evidence is even submitted, they say they will not support it under any circumstances," said Mr. McKenna, now a deputy chairman at Toronto-Dominion Bank and a long-time Energy East ally. “This isn't about pipeline safety but about opposition to a carbon-based economy.

… The government shouldn't simply listen to the loudest voices."

Chiefs and elders from three Mohawk communities were also due to appear Monday but said afterward they were unsure whether they will participate in rescheduled hearings. The Mohawks complained the National Energy Board process is inadequate in dealing with their aboriginal rights, and accused the panel of being biased in favour of approving the project.

The federal agency is “trying to convince people that this is the right thing to do," Grand Chief Joe Norton, of the Mohawk Council of Kahnawake, told a news conference. “Our primary goal is to ensure the safety of our land and our people."

Last week, Mr. Coderre asked for the hearings to be suspended after media reports revealed that two of the three NEB commissioners overseeing the review process met with former Quebec premier Jean Charest, who was paid as a consultant for TransCanada at the time.

The commissioners met privately with a number of Quebec stakeholders – including business groups and environmentalists – last year as they prepared for the review. Numerous environmental groups have urged the federal government to suspend the hearings to deal with what they say is the perception of bias.

Mr. Duboyce acknowledged that Mr. Charest was being paid as a consultant to TransCanada at the time of the meeting, but insisted he “was not asked to lobby or advocate on the project's behalf."


CO 
tracan : TransCanada Corporation

IN 
i5020043 : Pipeline Laying | i14001 : Petroleum Refining | i1 : Energy | i14 : Petroleum/Coal Products | i502 : Heavy Construction | iconst : Construction | icre : Real Estate/Construction | iindstrls : Industrial Goods | imidstr : Oil/Natural Gas Midstream Operations

NS 
gcivds : Civil Disruption | c13 : Regulation/Government Policy | ccat : Corporate/Industrial News | gcat : Political/General News | gcns : National/Public Security | grisk : Risk News | ncat : Content Types | nfact : Factiva Filters | nfcpin : C&E Industry News Filter

RE 
cana : Canada | caqc : Quebec | montre : Montréal | ottaw : Ottawa | caon : Ontario | namz : North America

PUB 
The Globe and Mail Inc.

AN
