HD Union-Management Coalition Supports Energy East Pipeline Project
WC 662 words
PD 26 August 2016
SN The Daily Oil Bulletin
SC DOILB
LA English
CY (c)2016 copyright Junewarren-Nickle’s Energy Group. All rights reserved

LP 

On the eve of National Energy Board (NEB) hearings in Montréal on the Energy East Pipeline proposal, a coalition of management and union stakeholders expressed its support for the project.

The Association des constructeurs de routes et grands travaux du Québec (ACRGTQ), the Association industrielle de l’Est de Montréal (AIEM), the Association des firmes de génie-conseil – Québec (AFG), the Association des propriétaires de machinerie lourde du Québec (APMLQ), the Board of Trade of Metropolitan Montreal (BTMM), the Conseil provincial du Québec des métiers de la construction(International), the Québec Employers' Council (QEC), the Fédération des chambres de commerce du Québec (FCCQ) and FTQ-Construction, believe that Energy East is “very important for Québec's economic growth and its energy future.”

TD 

The coalition believes the project deserves a “pragmatic and realistic analysis.” Moreover, the coalition calls on citizens to take the time to find out more about the Energy East project, while taking into consideration all of its features, including its economic benefits.

Stimulating the economy

In a context where stimulating the economy has become a necessity, where working hours have fallen by more than 40 per cent in the industrial building sector and by nearly 30 per cent in the civil engineering sector, the coalition believes that Québec cannot overlook one of the larger construction projects to come along in some 25 years. The coalition noted that very few national projects could generate and maintain, on an annual basis, over some nine years, more than 14,000 direct and indirect jobs.

Nearly one-quarter of those jobs would be in Québec during project development and construction. According to the coalition, Energy East is indeed a job creator and arguments to the contrary don't hold water.

The coalition noted that this private investment project will generate more than $10 billion in tax revenues, above and beyond all other economic benefits and it will contribute more than $50 billion to Canada's GDP.

Leveraging expertise

The economic activity generated by an infrastructure project like Energy East will lead to the creation of new businesses and to the development of subcontractor networks that will remain active well after the pipeline is completed, as they export their know-how, the group said.

The coalition believes that this project represents yet another opportunity to leverage the expertise of workers and businesses in Québec's construction industry. An expertise acquired over decades of work on large infrastructure projects throughout North America.

From the installation of vast wind farms, to the design and commissioning of some of the larger hydroelectric installations on the planet, Québec know-how stands second to none. Younger workers will benefit from training, apprenticeships and mentoring. The importance, the scope and the leading edge requirements of Energy East, will make it a catalyst for the growth of our workforce and for the enhancement of its world class expertise. 

Diversifying energy supply

While it supports the energy transition that the Québec government has committed to, the coalition “reminds citizens that the consumption of petroleum will not come to an end any time soon. Legislators acknowledge that by 2030, hydrocarbons will still account for some 40 per cent of our energy needs. We will therefore continue to rely on petroleum and its derivatives for transportation and other products we use daily, such as plastics.

“Québec imports 100 per cent of the petroleum it uses. The coalition believes that Energy East is an opportunity to build a national market for locally produced oil, thereby increasing our refineries' competitiveness, while ensuring the stability and diversity of our energy supply,” the group added. “Rarely do we see a project that can serve as a foundation for a society's economic development, as well as its energy future. Once it is completed, in accordance with principles of sustainable development and of social acceptance, Energy East will enable Québec to take on a myriad of challenges. The coalition supports Energy East.”


CO 
botomm : Board of Trade of Metropolitan Montreal

IN 
i5010025 : Industrial Building Construction | i501 : Building Construction | iconst : Construction | icre : Real Estate/Construction

NS 
ccat : Corporate/Industrial News

RE 
cana : Canada | namz : North America

PUB 
Junewarren-Nickle’s Energy Group

AN 
Document DOILB00020160826ec8q00007


SE Report on Business
HD Chalk River's nuclear research centre is switching gears
BY By SHAWN McCARTHY
WC 859 words
PD 8 August 2016
SN The Globe and Mail
SC GLOB
ED Ontario
PG B3
LA English
CY ©2016 The Globe and Mail Inc. All Rights Reserved.

LP 

The Chalk River nuclear research centre is set to lose the aged reactor that has been the centrepiece of Canada's nuclear technology effort for decades, but its private sector managers aim to keep the laboratories humming by being part of industry's much-touted “next big thing": the commercialization of small modular reactors.

Their vision: populating the North with microreactors they say could provide greenhouse gas-emission-free energy at a reasonable cost to remote communities, mine sites and oil sands projects. Achieving that ambitious goal would boost Canada's nuclear laboratories and the domestic nuclear industry that has seen a number of once-promising technologies fall by the wayside.

TD 

Unless there is another extension to its licence, Chalk River's 59-year-old National Research Universal (NRU) reactor will shut down in early 2018, ending a celebrated but stormy history as a workhorse that contributed to the development of the Candu heavy-water reactor and supplied cancer-fighting medical isotopes to the world.

The private-sector managers and the government owners insist the NRU shutdown will not spell the end of Canada's role in advancing technology for nuclear technology, or the shuttering of the Chalk River facility.

Given its long history and variety of scientific expertise, the Atomic Energy of Canada Ltd.

facilities are uniquely positioned to work with companies looking to commercialize their design for small modular reactors (SMR) as well as to attract other new business, said Mark Lesinski, chief executive officer of Canadian Nuclear Laboratories (CNL), the consortium that operates the Ontario site on behalf of government-owned AECL.

“The role of the laboratory is pivotal to any [SMR] technology that would be deployed in Canada," Mr. Lesinski said in an interview at his Chalk River office. “I think we can bring to bear a prototype quicker and more cost effectively because of our experience and our capabilities here."

Critics, however, argue that the industry's higher costs and safety concerns will leave it uncompetitive with renewable electricity.

Left to deteriorate under the Conservatives, Chalk River has received a boost under the Liberals, who in April provided $800million over five years to upgrade its infrastructure, while still providing its annual $960-million in operating funding.

“Chalk River is not just an important part of what government does in terms of research but is also something used by industry," Kim Rudd, parliamentary secretary to Natural Resources Minister Jim Carr, said in an interview. Ms. Rudd said nuclear technology remains a key development priority.

Situated on the forested banks of the Ottawa River 180 kilometres northwest of the capital, the Chalk River research centre dates back to the 1950s, when Canada's postwar nuclear program was born with the creation of Atomic Energy of Canada Ltd.

It hosts 70 laboratories and employs some 500 scientists and technicians.

AECL was an albatross for the former Conservative government.

Chalk River's NRU had an unplanned shutdown in 2007 that provoked a critical shortage of medical isotopes and a nasty showdown between then-prime minister Stephen Harper and the top nuclear regulator at the time, Linda Keen. It was forced to shut down again in 2009.

The Conservatives broke up the former AECL, selling its commercial reactor operations to SNCLavalin Group Inc. for $15-million five years ago and contracting out the management of the government-owned labs to a consortium of engineering companies.

CNL is hungry for new business opportunities, and the SMRs represent only part of the solution.

Part of its role is decommissioning the NRU and closing down the Whiteshell laboratory.

It will end the production of the cancer-fighting isotope molybdenum 99 in October, forcing the medical community to import them.

Mr. Lesinski and his team are looking to improve efficiency and expand beyond the traditional role of supporting Candu to provide services for global nuclear reactor vendors and operators.

Some labs still support work with the Candu heavy-water reactor. That includes the $26-billion plan to refurbish aging units at Ontario's Darlington and Bruce plants, and SNC-Lavalin's partnership with Chinese operators for fuel technology that allows Candus to run on waste generated by China's light-water reactors.

Others are focused on related technologies. Physicist Sam Suppiah runs the hydrogen isotope laboratory, which has developed and sells a high-temperature steam electrolysis unit to produce the valuable gas.

Still, the ultimate prize is the SMR market, which has as many as 90 proponents around the world rushing to commercialize their designs. CNL executives are in discussions with several developers. The companies are looking for prelicensing approval from the Canadian regulator, which basically amounts to support for the technology, research backing from CNL, a site for demonstration projects and – for most – subsidies from Ottawa.

Critics such as Greenpeace campaigner Shawn-Patrick Stensil suggest SMR is just the latest version of the nuclear industry's piein-the-sky promises. “The industry will eventually relive past rejection due to lack of social acceptance, unproven designs, bad economics and competition from more proven clean-tech competitors," he said.


IN 
i13 : Crude Oil/Natural Gas Upstream Operations | i1 : Energy

NS 
ccat : Corporate/Industrial News

RE 
cana : Canada | ottaw : Ottawa | caon : Ontario | namz : North America

PUB 
The Globe and Mail Inc.

AN 
Document GLOB000020160808ec880001b


SE News
HD New clinic links patients with medical marijuana
BY Ali Pearson
CR Sault This Week
WC 996 words
PD 4 August 2016
SN Sault Ste Marie This Week
SC SSMTHW
ED Final
PG A1 / Front
LA English
CY Copyright © 2016 Sault Ste Marie This Week

LP 

Sault Ste. Marie has become home to a medical marijuana clinic, but if you didn't know it, you would never suspect.

The clinic, on March Street, looks like any tastefully designed medicaloffice and it has nomarijuana on site.

TD 

"That because their isn't any there," explains Bodystream business designer Brian Warner. "We are not a dispensary.

"Rather we are helping people who are interested in trying medicalmarijuana as an alternative therapy to navigate the system.

"We are a medical clinic." You enter into a tastefully decorated waiting room. You are greeted by a friendly receptionist dressed in scrubs.

The clinic also houses an education room and a testing room, as all patients are drug tested throughout the procedure to ensure they are not using drugs that have not been prescribed to them.

Souzanne Scott was willing to share her experiences. "I was diagnosed with Multiple Sclerosis 32 years ago," she said.

"I am at a capping stage in my disease where there are very few drugs that we haven't used and I am not interested in using opiates."

"I didn't' really want to be using marijuana, but it's my only real option.

"I was on Interferon for 15 years, and that was at the point where it was still being tested."

Marijuana provides her with effective pain relief, she said. "The only side effect is the smile onmy face.

"It's actually also helped me put on a little weight, something that I have been struggling with for a long time," said Scott.

She had tried in past to get a prescription for marijuana because she knew it would work but she could find no provider educated in prescribing.

Warner's clinic made the connections for her.

"This has been great. I don't even have to smoke it," Scott said. "I'm vaping.

"I used to feel really guilty.

I'm not a drinker. Heck, I go to church. Being able to legally obtain nothing that has helped me so much has lifted the guilt."

Clinic director Drew Craig pointed out, "Our clientele isn't criminal. They are just everyday people, just trying to manage pain and not use barbiturates."

Craig invites those with concerns to contact him so that they can get an understanding.

"We aren't here to preach that medical marijuana is better than other therapies or treatments that your doctor might prescribe," said Warner.

"We have seen the increase in knowledge about it as a therapy, and the demand. Patients are asking their doctors and they aren't getting the response that they need," said Warner.

"From a prescribing aspect, you can't overdose on marijuana and it has no addictive qualities," he said. "Patients deserve to have a better choice."

Patients are encouraged to come in with a referral, though due to the physician short a gein Northern

Ontario the clinic also accepts walk-in clients and will assist them in gathering their information.

"We don't want to go against doctors' wishes. We want to help them with the process," Warner said.

"The majority of our clients at the clinic so far have been over 50 years old," said Craig.

"Walk into one of our waiting rooms and you are going to see people from different walks of life, people ranging from those in their mid-20s to grandparents," said Warner.

"The clinic is strictly aligned with licensed providers," and it sets up clients with a dispensary, he said.

"Filled prescriptions are then mailed to the patients," said Craig.

Referring to stereotypes - people smoking marijuana or eating munchies and passing out on the couch- he said marijuana comes in different strains that have different effects on a patient.

While an Indica might be the choice for a nighttime medication, a Stevia might help provide some energy, said Craig.

"Users also don't have to smoke or even vape their medication. It can be processed as edibles or topical creams."

Bodysteam has 11 clinics across the province and hopes to have 22 in operation by the end of the year. Warner said, "One of the greatest challenges that we face is the stigma that surrounds marijuana, though in the last year we have seen social acceptance grow significantly.

"We are trying to put another face on it. We aren't sporting big cannabis leaves.

We are separate from the pot culture," he said.

"Norman J. Kalyniuk M.D. is on staffand we are looking to bring more doctors on board to meet the demand," he said.

Bodystream encourages those who aren't aware to research the topic and find out about medical marijuana and what the clinics can do.

"There is not set list of what marijuana can and can't treat," he continued.

"We are trying to support not only the local community but also the medical community."

He has found that many doctors are willing to prescribe but don't know how to navigate the system. "Now they have the option of referring people to us," he said. "The key thing to remember is that we are a medical clinic and no products are on site."

Scott encourages other sufferers to check out the clinic.

"For me it was a straight path to getting some relief. I am very open about that. It's really been life changing.

"I attribute it to my still being able to walk," she said.

"It's a wonderful breath of fresh air with all of the struggles I have had, to be able to navigate this.

"I'm not the kind of person who can go out and buy it off the street," Scott said. "This has helped me ensure a stable supply of good quality products."


ART 
Ali Pearson, Sault This Week / FINDING ALTERNATIVES: Clinic director Drew Craig at Bodystream speaks with patient Souzanne Scott during an appointment at the March Street Medical Marijuana Clinic.;

NS 
gmarij : Marijuana Usage | npag : Page-One Stories | gabus : Drug/Substance Usage | gcat : Political/General News | gcom : Society/Community | ghea : Health | gmed : Medical Conditions | gsoc : Social Issues | ncat : Content Types

IPD 
News | sault,marie,become,medical,marijuana,clinic

PUB 
Postmedia Network Inc.

AN 
Document SSMTHW0020160804ec8400009


SE Opinion
HD Clean energy profitable with better transmission
BY Dennis Woodford
WC 854 words
PD 14 July 2016
SN Winnipeg Free Press
SC WFP
ED Print
PG A7
LA English
CY All material copyright Winnipeg Free Press, a division of FP Canadian Newspapers Limited Partnership. All rights reserved.

LP 

As reported in the Winnipeg Free Press, Prime Minister Justin Trudeau said a new continental target for clean electricity generation could open the door for greater Canadian hydroelectricity exports to the United States (North American clean energy pledge prompts talk of more Canadian hydro exports, June 30). Is this an economic reality for Manitoba?

At present, Wuskwatim, our new operating hydroelectric generating station, produces electricity at about 10 cents per kilowatt-hour. The average sale price of electricity for export, and mostly to the U.S., is about four cents per kilowatt-hour, and Manitoba Hydro ratepayers are making up the loss with our increasing hydro rates — subsidizing the Americans with our costly clean energy. So if we are to follow Prime Minister Trudeau's target for increased hydro exports to the U.S., are we going to do this through continued subsidization of our clean energy to the Americans?

TD 

We are continuing the boondoggle by building Bipole III with its ridiculous west-side route and Keeyask hydroelectric generating station, both now under construction, and their electricity production price is certainly not going to be less than 10 cents per kilowatt-hour. The need for Keeyask for Manitoba's use disappears through application of Manitoba Hydro's aggressive energy-saving plan, released the day after the recent provincial election. If adopted, Keeyask's far-from-profitably-generated clean energy will all be available for export to the U.S. at a continuing financial loss with ongoing and increased subsidy by Manitobans. This is a problem Manitoba Hydro's new board is charged to resolve.

We cannot wishfully expect the price of U.S. electricity will magically increase to finally bring us a profit for our hydro energy exports. This past week, the $2.77-million Pan Canadian Wind Integration Study was released. It was co-funded by Natural Resources Canada and the Canadian Wind Energy Association. Its advisory committee consisted of representatives from most provinces and from the U.S., including from its Department of Energy. David Jacobson from Manitoba Hydro represented Manitoba.

What is significant for Manitobans in this report is that by 2025, wind energy will be available at a cost of less than 4.4 cents per kilowatt-hour. Recovery of capital investment will be in four years. The existing hydro resources across Canada and additional wide-area electric transmission will “firm up" the uncertainty of the wind resources. Therefore, anticipating electricity prices to increase so Manitoba's new hydroelectricity will become profitable just on exports to the U.S. is a dream. The future price of wind and possibly solar energy will hold it down.

The study is only the beginning of how the clean energy future can be profitably developed. The next step is a thorough study of the benefits of a TransCanada, and transcontinental, electric transmission superhighway system. A TransCanada electric system is particularly strategic with Canada's commitment to reduction in greenhouse gas emissions and in the reduced plundering of our non-renewable energy resources.

By following the Americans' rule to only build electric transmission interconnections whose economic benefits exceed costs by 25 per cent, any public or private investment in the TransCanada electric superhighway will be profitable. This can be done, and Manitoba Hydro did it in 1980 with a transmission line from Winnipeg to Minneapolis, whose benefits exceeded costs by 2 1/2 times. This transmission interconnection helped keep our hydro rates low for 20 years, and it paid for itself in just a few years.

Benefits to be evaluated include an overall reduction in electric generation and fossil-fuelled generators, increased dependable use of wind and solar energy, added security to electric utilities and advantage of time-zone differences to share energy east and west. Manitoba Hydro will have new markets for its hydroelectricity from which it can select the best price available east, west and south instead of being captive to the U.S. market as it is today. If Manitoba Hydro seeks to sell its excess generation capacity from Keeyask through the electric superhighway in place of just energy, less financial loss from its present development plan may be possible.

Natural Resources Canada, having seen the encouraging results of the study, is interested in moving forward. The problem will be the provinces seeing eye to eye for an east-to-west electric superhighway.

The other major problem will be gaining social acceptance for overhead, high-power electric transmission lines. Following the lead shown in Denmark, the U.K. and now the U.S., aesthetic, low-profile transmission pylons are the way forward. In special areas, underground cables can be applied, but are too expensive for long distances.

As we decarbonize to keep valuable fossil fuels in the ground, there is a new and exciting way forward for us to pursue. With a TransCanada and transcontinental electric superhighway system, our hydro rates may even stay manageable and Prime Minister Trudeau's target may be possible after all.

Dennis Woodford, president of Electranix Corp., was a transmission planning engineer at Manitoba Hydro for 15 years.


CO 
manhel : Manitoba Hydro Electric Board | tracan : TransCanada Corporation

IN 
i1610107 : Hydropower Energy | i1 : Energy | i16 : Electricity/Gas Utilities | i16101 : Electric Power Generation | i163 : Renewable Energy Generation | ieutil : Electric Utilities | iutil : Utilities | imidstr : Oil/Natural Gas Midstream Operations

NS 
gpol : Domestic Politics | gcat : Political/General News | gpir : Politics/International Relations

RE 
cana : Canada | camb : Manitoba | namz : North America

PUB 
Winnipeg Free Press

AN 
Document WFP0000020160714ec7e0000n


SE Opinion
HD Are progressives being played for fools?
BY Tom Parkin
CR The Sault Star
WC 549 words
PD 12 July 2016
SN Sault Star
SC SAULTS
ED Final
PG A6
LA English
CY Copyright © 2016 Sault Star

LP 

In previous centuries political theorists - from liberals to revolutionaries - argued progress was as inevitable as the rising and setting sun.

Last century, a growing global economy, improvements in Canadian health care and education and the American civil rights movement were all evidence that social progress was a fact of history. But in this century, as social progress has been frustrated, a different progressivism has emerged. And, true to our diminished expectations of collective action, it's now a force that comes from the individual.

TD 

Today, widely held progressive values in Canada are driving a political push to root out discrimination and create greater social acceptance. The rapid change in Canadians' attitudes about sexual and gender identity is testimony to its potential. So is a reinvigorated anti-racist attitude - evident in everything from advertising to Black Lives Matter.

Women are once again likely to describe themselves as feminists. Canadians' progressive values have generally resisted the xenophobic response to refugees which, at least in part, fuel Donald Trump and Brexit. But as we sit all smug with our Canada global cool contrasting with those burning fires, are progressives being played for fools? Has the language of progressivism become an empty suit any politician can slip on to mollify and misdirect from their undermining of social progress?

U.S. President Barack Obama's recent speech in Ottawa is strong evidence progressivism has become a cheap political suit. Strip the progressive rhetoric offObama's speech. What was underneath was a naked ask for Canada to support the United States' military and adopt the Trans Pacific Partnership.

No one can doubt Obama's - or Trudeau's - words of liberal progressivism. But how do those progressive words square with Obama's continued campaign of drone-driven targeted killings in countries with which the U.S. is not at war?

A campaign many respected legal experts say is contrary to international law.

And how do they square that with the fact Canada is providing military equipment to the very unprogressive, very unfeminist Saudi Kingdom? A place where homosexuality is a crime punished by death?

How do they square with TPP? Doctors Without Borders has warned TPP would hike medicine costs. A former BlackBerry CEO argues it would hurt Canadian innovation. Worker groups express concerns about manufacturing jobs and public services.

What we know for sure is investors have successfully used the World Trade Organization to put limits on green energy initiatives in Canada. And under NAFTA, Canada has been the biggest target of investor actions - many against our environmental protection laws, according to a recent CCPA study.

And with Trudeau musing about more privatization, the risk to social progress is mounting. Like Premier Kathleen Wynne, who is selling Ontario's electricity grid to investors, the federal government is preparing to sell infrastructure - such as airports, transit, ports or high-occupancy vehicle lanes.

From a cost perspective, embedding a layer of rent-seekers makes little sense. Government can always borrow money at better rates than private investors.

But the deeper risk is, behind the rhetoric of progressivism, governments will let investors tie the hands of future governments.

In so doing they'll prevent Canadians from making social progress - on climate, transit, Pharmacare or social programs.


NS 
gdip : International Relations | gcat : Political/General News | gpir : Politics/International Relations

RE 
cana : Canada | usa : United States | namz : North America

IPD 
Column | previous,centuries,political,theorists,liberals,revolutionaries

PUB 
Postmedia Network Inc.

AN 
Document SAULTS0020160712ec7c0000l


SE Editorial
HD The Energy East pipeline is a trap that Quebec should avoid; Locking in oilsands expansion would be bad for Canada and the planet, Éric Pineault says
CR The Gazette
WC 714 words
PD 29 April 2016
SN Montreal Gazette
SC MTLG
ED Early
PG A8
LA English
CY Copyright © 2016 Montreal Gazette

LP 

Environmental and citizens' groups across Quebec are celebrating a bittersweet victory this week. TransCanada has finally agreed to submit a limited environmental impact study of its Energy East pipeline project to Quebec authorities. However, as a result of negotiations with the province, important aspects have been excluded from the assessment process.

Having ditched the bulldozer approach, the public relations staffat TransCanada now seem to be out to gain social acceptance for the project.

TD 

It my profound conviction, as an informed citizen, an environmentalist and an economist, that Energy East should be opposed without compromise. It is a trap.

The pipeline's purpose is to bring diluted bitumen to tidewater, in order to sell oil on international markets. Any local consumption in Eastern Canada is incidental.

A pipeline of any sort implies environmental and health risks, which can be partly mitigated with appropriate investments and technology. Energy East will cross more than 860 bodies of water, including the St. Lawrence River, where the drinking water of more than 5 million people is at risk.

The real goal here is to expand oilsands extraction, not to meet the needs of current production capacity. This will have devastating effects on greenhouse-gas production. Before it is even burned, every gallon of this oil will have sent into the sky up to four times as much CO2 as the conventional oil we still produce in Alberta and Saskatchewan.

Energy East's useful life would be at least 40 years. This suggests Canada would be expanding oilsands production until 2060, when the rest in the world, in theory, will have moved away from dependency on hydrocarbon combustion. Canada will be trapped for the next five decades, addicted to extreme oil extraction with all the deleterious economic and environmental effects that would follow.

Is this a really problem? Could we not expand the sands and use the revenue to finance a green transition? And could not Energy East be part of the transition solution?

These questions bring us to heart of the Energy East trap.

Climate science tells us that 85 per cent of oilsands reserves must stay in the ground until at least 2050 if we want to avoid a collapse of the Earth's climate. Energy East would free for burning an equivalent of 32 million tonnes of CO2 a year. At this rate, the sky would fill up with greenhouse gases before we run out of oil to pump out of the ground.

One can expect energy companies to do all they can to realize the value locked in the ground. But we know that we have to move away from our carbonbased economy, and that we have to do it fast.

The problem with Energy East is that it is instrumental to a rapid expansion of the oilsands complex, and that this will further deepen the grip of extraction industries on the west. It will multiply the economic distortions in Canada as a whole - on our private sector investment where the oil sector is crowding out other industries, on our currency and on our labour markets. Oilsands expansion will also mean committing all our gains in the development of renewable sources of energy to "green" oilsands extraction, instead of directly mobilizing this energy to free our economy from hydrocarbons.

So the real debate is not about which aspects of Energy East should be modified and greened to build social acceptance for the pipeline project. No, that's precisely the trap that is being set. The real debate pits those that act according to the principle of the economic pressure to extract and those who, in the name of the imperative of a just ecological transition, oppose Energy East, knowing that the pipeline is instrumental to the expansion of an industry that must be wound down in a planned and rational manner.

Between these two forces, there can be no compromise or middle ground.

Éric Pineault is an economist and professor at the Institute of environmental science and departmentof Sociology at UQAM, and author of Le Piège Énergie Est (The Energy East Trap) published this week at Écoscociété.


CO 
tracan : TransCanada Corporation

IN 
i1300003 : Crude Petroleum Extraction | i1 : Energy | i13 : Crude Oil/Natural Gas | iextra : Natural Gas/Oil Extraction | i1300006 : Pipeline Transportation

NS 
nedi : Editorials | ncat : Content Types

RE 
cana : Canada | caqc : Quebec | namz : North America

IPD 
Editorial | environmental,groups,quebec,celebrating,bittersweet,victory

PUB 
Montreal Gazette

AN 
Document MTLG000020160429ec4t0000r


SE News
HD Canada’s forest sector: the sunrise industry
BY Flavio Nienow
WC 801 words
PD 18 February 2016
SN Burns Lake Lakes District News
SC BURLAK
ED Final
PG 1
LA English
CY Copyright 2016 Black Press, Inc. All Rights Reserved.

LP 

Burns Lake Lakes District News -- The global commodity slowdown has affected several industries in Canada and has led to the closure of mines in Northern B.C.

The Endako Mine, which is located near Fraser Lake, was placed on temporary suspension in December 2014. Since then, over 300 employees have lost their jobs.

TD 

The Huckleberry Mine, which is located 88 km from Houston, has recently told its employees that it plans on shutting down all operations by Aug. 31, 2016.

What about the forest industry? CouldCanada's forest sector be struggling as well?

According to Susan Murray, a Spokesperson with the Forest Products Association of Canada, the answer is no.

“It [the forest industry] may not be at the peak situation it was at one time, when it was the largest industry in Canada; however, right now, the industry has been growing, exports are increasing and the sector is hiring again," she said.

The Forest Products Association of Canada set the goal of hiring 60,000 people between 2010 and 2020. In the first four years of that period, 16,000 people were hired.

“Some of these [workers] are replacing retiring baby boomers, some are new hires,' explained Murray.“If anything we are having trouble finding workers.'

Dana Collins, Executive Director for the Canadian Institute of Forestry, agrees that the Canadian forest industry is on the uprise again after years of a hard downturn.

Between 2005 and 2009, the forest industry’s contribution to Canada’s gross domestic product (GDP) declined sharply year-over-year as a result of a consumer shift to electronic media and the U.S. housing crisis.

According to The Globe and Mail, in September 2004, 308,664 Canadians earned a living from logging, paper making and wood products manufacturing. A decade later, the industry employed just 190,651 people.

Since its sharp rebound in 2010, the forest industry has consistently accounted for approximately 1.2 per cent of the total Canadian GDP, with wood product manufacturing offsetting declines in pulp and paper manufacturing.

Unlike the energy, mining and many other industries, the forest products industryhas beengrowing in size. According to the federal government, in 2014, the value of Canada’s forest product exports increased by 9.8 per cent over 2013, rising to $30.8 billion from $28.4 billion.

In addition, forest product exports have done well with the low Canadian dollar, with sales to the U.S. returning to historic levels after the collapse of the U.S. housing market in 2008.

Collins says the forest sector is nowconsidered Canada’s “sunrise industry.'

She said theforest industry overcame its challenges by adapting and innovating, and is no longer narrowly defined by pulp and paper.

“It’s now a diverse, dynamic, innovative, green, and sustainable sector that supports science, research and development."

The industry’s traditional products - pulp, paper and lumber - are being used to create new products such as renewable bio-fuels, green bio-plastics, bio-pharmaceuticals, bulletproof vests, car parts and even airplane wings.

Collins explained that the emergence of new products also includes the application ofnanotechnology - the engineering of functional systems at the molecular scale.

“The application of nanotechnology creates a product that's as strong as steel, but lighter,' she said. “We can replace steel in cars, for example, using forest products.'

“We're also seeing bylaws to support this [technology], for example, changes to building codes to allow for wood construction in high or midrise buildings,' she added.

Since the industry has become more innovative, diverse and technically advanced, there is also a growing need for new types of skilled workers. The long list of workers that the industry now requires includes biologists, millwrights, electricians, engineers, sales staff, truck drivers, foresters, chemists, economist and risk analysts and IT specialists.

In the story ‘Millennials, these career sectors are worth considering’ published in The Globe and Mail on Aug. 24, 2015, the forest products industry was selected as one of the most promising industries for young Canadian professionals.

Collins said this innovative path of the industry has alsoattracted a more diverse workforce, encompassing more women and Aboriginal people.

When asked what we should expect of the forest sector in the next five years, Collins said the industry will continue to see an emphasis on innovation.

“We'll see new product development, innovation in long-lived, durable forest products, and hopefully more of a social acceptance and understanding of the environmental benefits of using woodto replace heavy carbon-emitting materials such as concrete or steel.'

Collinsadded thatforest jobs are now popping up all over the country and that this trend is expected to continue for the next five years and beyond.

Copyright 2016 Burns Lake Lakes District News


CO 
fpaocd : Forest Products Association of Canada

NS 
npag : Page-One Stories | ncat : Content Types

RE 
cana : Canada | namz : North America

PUB 
Black Press Inc.

AN 
Document BURLAK0020160219ec2i00002


HD Alberta And Saskatchewan Must Align On Energy Issues As Country Considers Carbon Policy
WC 1266 words
PD 5 February 2016
SN The Daily Oil Bulletin
SC DOILB
LA English
CY (c)2016 copyright Junewarren-Nickle’s Energy Group. All rights reserved

LP 

Whatever ideological differences Saskatchewan’s right-of-centre government and Alberta’s left-of-centre government might have, their leaders need to “bury the hatchet” and present a common argument in regards to their energy sectors in the face of federal climate policies that could hit the oil-rich Prairie provinces’ economies harder than in the rest of Canada.

“Saskatchewan and Alberta share interests,” said Trevor McLeod,director of the Centre for Natural Resources Policy for the Canada West Foundation. He added: “We need to remind Canadians that the world is changing, and that we need to adapt.”

TD 

McLeod told Thursday’s Economics Society of Calgary luncheon there is precedent for the two provinces to align on energy issues, even when their governing parties are on opposite sides of the political spectrum. He said premiers Rachel Notley and Brad Wall could look to when Saskatchewan was the province with an NDP government under then-Premier Allan Blakeney and Alberta’s premier was Progressive Conservative leader Peter Lougheed, and the two worked together.

“Facing similar circumstances, they formed a bit of an alliance, and based on the shared interests of Alberta and Saskatchewan, they were very effective at negotiating together.”

According to McLeod, there needs to be recognition that energy-producing provinces compete on the world stage.

“We know that we need to do more to reduce greenhouse gas emissions, but now is the time to make sure that the Canadian discussion takes account of the global context,” he said. “We need to take that broad view and put competitiveness on the radar, and we need to make sure this pan-Canadian climate strategy does not hobble [the] Canadian economy at the worst possible time.”

Mid-last year, McLeod co-authored a report, making three recommendations about developing a Canadian climate plan. Firstly, the report called for a Canada-wide shared offset market as an important first step towards harmonization. Secondly, the report said, Western Canada should first determine how to integrate its systems when re-evaluating systems and designing new ones, and then consider how to link those to the rest of the country.

Thirdly, in pursuit of more effective climate policy, provinces and the nation as a whole should be mindful that carbon pricing represents only one policy tool among many necessary to achieve substantial emissions reductions. While carbon price policies will play a major role in achieving reductions — especially based on cost-effectiveness and revenue-generating potential — additional “command-and-control” regulations are also vital.

Speaking specifically about Alberta, McLeod said a major concern for the province and its resource-based economy is that despite the government’s recently-announced efforts to curb carbon emissions, the federal government might demand more in terms of reductions from oil and gas producing regions, which could further impact the ability for Alberta’s crude to compete with other countries’ production that does not adhere to such strict environmental policies.

“If [Prime Minister Justin Trudeau] is serious about meeting global commitments made in Paris, [then] we should be a bit worried in Alberta and Saskatchewan,” he said, adding that while Ottawa indicated it would respect provincial jurisdiction on carbon policy, last week the Liberals also announced an additional pipeline approval process that would include consideration of upstream GHG emissions (DOB, Jan. 27, 2016).

“A cynic could be excused for believing the federal government plans to use this new ‘pipeline national interest test,’ which includes the upstream GHG emissions, as a hammer to make sure Alberta, Saskatchewan and some others do more. We’ve seen the impact of [Alberta’s] existing climate plan, and it might not be the end.”

Broad-based carbon price is good: Winter

Jennifer Winter, associate of the energy and environmental policy area at the School of Public Policy at the University of Calgary, told this week’s luncheon that the provincial government was right to implement a broad-based price on carbon, but there are aspects of the plan that she would characterize as less than ideal.

“What you may or may not be aware of is that there is also what is called an ‘output subsidy’ for large emitters,” she said, adding the climate policy review panel indicated the $30-per-tonne rate would result in $3 billion net revenue, rather than the near-$6 billion that carbon rate could earn the province if it was not for the fact that the plan provides output subsidies for large emitters of GHGs that are trade exposed.

“I would argue that it is not the best policy, but it is also not necessarily the worst in the way that the Specified Gas Emitters Regulation was constructed in that it also had an implicit output subsidy involved with it, and with the new carbon tax plan … it is a more even allocation of revenues.”

Just prior to the COP 21 in Paris late last year, Alberta’s NDP government unveiled its climate change management plan, which is based on the climate change policy advisory panel’s final report and includes a legislated emissions limit on the oilsands, a carbon price across all sectors, as well as pledges to reduce methane emissions from oil and gas operations (DOB, Nov. 22, 2015).

The government’s plan includes phasing in carbon pricing in two steps: $20 per tonne economy-wide in January 2017 and $30 per tonne economy-wide in January 2018. The province will set an overall oilsands emission limit of 100 megatonnes, with provisions for new upgrading and cogeneration. The province will also phase out all pollution from burning coal and transition to more renewable energy and natural gas generation by 2030.

Winter also argues against subsidizing renewable energy, because the carbon tax already makes fossil fuel-based electricity more expensive, which should incentivize more renewables to enter the grid.

Around the same time the province was making its climate policy announcement, Winter co-authored a report recommending how government might set up a carbon tax, suggesting it apply to all energy-based emissions in Alberta, along with a revenue-recycling guarantee to minimize any negative impacts on households, firms and the provincial economy as a whole (DOB, Nov. 26, 2015).

Collaborative governance on carbon pricing a key issue for 2016

According to a C.D. Howe Institutereport released last month, integrating federal and provincial carbon-pricing policies will likely be the key collaborative governance issue of 2016. With the recently-elected federal Liberal government commitment to allowing provincial carbon pricing freedom, as well as emerging provincial policies, the author said this raises the risk of a “provincial patchwork” leading to higher costs of doing business.

Therefore, suggests the report about the future of Canadian energy policy, producers and transportation companies should look to their own practices to improve the chances of getting project support. Meanwhile, federal and provincial regulators should examine how securities and competition policy impact potential energy sector mergers.

Since social acceptance and getting crude to world markets is a priority for the energy sector in 2016, governments must have a robust regulatory system that ensures producers can reach those markets in a safe and environmentally-friendly manner, noted the report author, and social acceptance requires governments to lead in areas outside the task areas officially assigned to regulators.

In 2016, said the institute, Canadian policymakers should provide collaborative carbon policies, a robust-but-prompt regulatory review system and an economy that encourages an innovative energy sector, as well as competitive electricity prices and a competitive resource tax and fiscal regime.


NS 
gclimt : Climate Change | ccat : Corporate/Industrial News | gcat : Political/General News | genv : Environmental News | gglobe : Global/World Issues

RE 
cana : Canada | caab : Alberta | cask : Saskatchewan | namz : North America

PUB 
Junewarren-Nickle’s Energy Group

AN 
Document DOILB00020160205ec2500001


HD Getting Pipelines Built
WC 1593 words
PD 31 January 2016
SN Question Period
SC QUES
LA English
CY © Copyright 2016 CTV Television Inc. All Rights Reserved.

LP 

Host(s): ROBERT FIFE

ROBERT FIFE: Joining us from Winnipeg, Conservative natural resources critic Candice Bergen, and with me in the studio, NDP environment critic Nathan Cullen. First question to you, Ms. Bergen, out in Winnipeg, the Harper government completely failed to get any major pipelines built despite nine years in power and at a time when oil prices were sky high, so why not give the prime minister's approach a chance, you know, to have more environmental assessments to get buy-in from the public and First Nations?

TD 

CANDICE BERGEN (Conservative Natural Resources Critic): Well, first of all, let me correct the record on that. Actually, during our tenure between 2006 and 2015, four major pipelines were built.

FIFE: No major pipeline to get Alberta crude oil to tide water.

BERGEN: Well, again, one, two of them go down to the US, but that's the narrative that the Liberals are going on. You know what the Liberals have introduced on Wednesday, what they did is they added another layer that was supposed to instill Canadian confidence, which is also another term that they use is social license, which is kind of an ever moving goalpost. Nobody actually knows what social license is. And the very group that they're hoping to get on board, First Nations, have come out saying they were not consulted at all about the additional consultations that they're going to have so they're not happy. But truthfully, the process that they're talking about is actually ministerial oversight or representation in a new process. There's no description in terms of the GHGs that are going to be measured. There's no numbers or any goalpost there as far as what proponents are supposed to measure up to, and the process truthfully is very, very thorough, it's onerous, it's long. The Liberals have been constantly undermining the NEB, and now they're adding another, this additional roadblock and process that nobody is happy with, and at the end of the day no pipelines are going to be built in the near future. They're over a year or more delayed again, no jobs, no investment.

FIFE: Mr. Cullen, what's your view on this?

NATHAN CULLEN (NDP Environment Critic): The goal is laudable. As Candice and everybody will know, building major industrial projects, particularly pipelines, because they come with some risk in terms of leaks and whatnot, requires public support. It's not 1950, right. The ability to just sort of push things through communities and by important environments is no longer the same than it was, so public support is important, so the goal is right. Is what they are doing the way to do it? I left the briefing with a lot more questions than I had answers. Candice did raise the point about climate change. Good to include it in the decision because Canada just made some big commitments at Paris. You know we had a lot of coverage on that. But when I asked the department, I asked the minister, so how much is climate important now? Like for a company, if you're a company applying, is it one percent of the equation, is it 50 percent of what you got? Is there a maximum you're allowed to emit through your project? All of that is still unknown. And one thing you'll always hear from company reps is certainty matters. I would also suggest certainty for the communities matter. And at one point I would argue against Candice is the process that's in place right now, it does not meet the public test. For an example, there's a Trans Mountain pipeline going to Burnaby, the proposed twinning, during the so-called public hearings, very few people can actually participate of the public. Second, you can't cross-examine the company. So the company puts their evidence forward, this is what we're going to do. And now the cabinet, even with the changes Mr. Trudeau has made, is going to take that evidence as it is without it really having been challenged yet. And to my mind, if you're dealing with bad evidence, you're going to make a bad decision.

FIFE: So, Ms. Bergen, some First Nations, as you said, have come out, said they weren't properly consulted. But we're in a situation here where many of them are opposed to both Energy East or Kinder Morgan, so how do we ever get any First Nation buy-in, and the government seems to be giving them a veto over this, because Mr. Trudeau has promised in the election campaign that he supports the idea of the UN first rights on indigenous people, which is basically a veto?

BERGEN: What we've heard a lot are First Nations who are opposed. Now interestingly, though, I was actually just in BC a couple of weeks ago at the BC's premiers natural resources conference, and I sat down, had a chance to meet with some First Nations there, really progressive, recognizing the economic benefit of pipelines and how it can benefit them. And I think that the companies are doing a better job, and they need to continue doing a better job of making the fiscal case, the business case to First Nations about the positive impact that these pipelines can have. The truth is, environmentally, what we're doing, I mean not so say that the NEB can't improve the process and that there should always be better science and new science, but the fact is Canadian pipelines are built very environmentally sound.

CULLEN: To say the NEB is doing a good job when just this week we had an environment commissioner's report out that said...

BERGEN: Well...

CULLEN: Hold on, let me finish. That of all the conditions that the National Energy Board puts on these pipelines when approving them, saying you can go ahead and build but you must do the following things and the company says yes. Well they don't follow it. We don't know if they do them or not in 50 percent or more of the cases. And to say that's good is not great. To your point, though, around First Nations, it isn't Mr. Trudeau I would argue that's making this decision. It's the Supreme Court just down the street here that has passed a number of significant rulings, over years, saying that duty to consult and accommodate First Nations is not an option anymore.

FIFE: No, but does it mean a veto?

CULLEN: In some cases I think it does. And the companies that I deal with, because I'm in northwestern British Columbia, there's lots of resource projects, 51 different First Nations groups that are just in my riding, so I've seen this in my 11 years that it can go badly and it can go well. From the company's perspective, if they're coming in sincerely with an open heart and open mind it can happen, because Candice is right, many First Nations people are absolutely inclined towards developing resources, but they need to do it responsibly.

FIFE: Do you think that we have, it's in our national interest, because Alberta has contributed so much to our economic fabric of this country, that they deserve to get a pipeline to get their oil to tide water?

CULLEN: I think that some of the things that the Notley government have done to this point greatly improves their chances. We talk about that social acceptance. The admission that climate change is real and that we're going to do something about it, putting a price on carbon which they've done, and moving the needle in terms of the public opposition, not just outside of Alberta, but also within, to make sure that we're doing these things properly and with some sort of consideration of the planet. That's important. Do they deserve it? Well they definitely deserve to make their case, and they're making a much better case than they were ten years ago.

FIFE: Final word to you, Ms. Bergen.

BERGEN: Thank you. Here's what Canadians deserve. We are an energy exporting nation. Our neighbours to the south, who are our competitors, are lifting export bans on oil. They're building pipelines. They're selling their oil. We are now at an unfair and even a greater unfair disadvantage with our competitors because of what the Trudeau government has just announced, and because we're not building pipelines. So we need a pipeline coming out of Alberta. It needs to go right to the east coast, not only for Alberta, but for New Brunswick, and for all of Canada, and so that we're on a competitive playing field.

FIFE: All right, thank you very much. Appreciate you both coming and speaking to us on this subject.

CULLEN: Thank you.

BERGEN: Thank you.

FIFE: The Liberal government says it's lifting some sanctions but not the suspicion.

JUSTIN TRUDEAU (Canadian Prime Minister): To engage with Iran in a responsible way that highlights both the human rights abuses at home and the sponsorship of terrorism abroad.

FIFE: As critics warn about the risk of reviving relations. TONY CLEMENT (Conservative Foreign Affairs Critic): There are plenty of other places to do business that are not in a country that sponsors and funds terrorists.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

Document QUES000020160201ec1v00002


SE Financial Post
HD Canadian energy policies need a rethink, report says; C.D. Howe Institute recommends Alberta adopt Norway-style royalties
BY David Howell
CR Edmonton Journal
WC 559 words
PD 7 January 2016
SN Edmonton Journal
SC EDJR
ED Early
PG C2
LA English
CY Copyright © 2016 Edmonton Journal

LP 

With a difficult 2015 finally in the rear-view mirror, the C.D. Howe Institute says government policy in 2016 will play an increasingly important role in getting Canadian energy products to market.

In a report released Thursday, the independent research institute calls on Alberta's NDP government to adopt what it calls international best practices for collecting energy royalties.

TD 

It warns the new Liberal federal government against making major changes to the approval process for energy pipelines. And it says Ottawa will need to ensure that provinces collaborate when setting carbon-pricing policies. Without proper guidance, a "policy patchwork" could lead to higher costs of doing business, it says.

"Few in the Canadian energy sector, as well as the people across Canada who depend on it, are going to be sad to see 2015 move into the history books," report author Benjamin Dachis said in an interview. "Part of the problem the energy sector is facing in 2016 is cyclical - low energy prices - but another very large part of it is a structural problem," said Dachis, a senior policy analyst at the institute. "There are some very key errors that governments have been making that they need to correct to put the energy sector on a sound footing."

With Alberta's royalty review panel set to report in coming weeks, the report says Alberta and other western provincial governments should replace gross-revenue energy royalties with simpler cash-flow taxes such as those used in Norway and Australia.

Under a gross-revenue system, companies pay the province a share of their gross production revenues. The collection method doesn't take into account the real costs of production, Dachis said.

By contrast, cash-flow royalties apply to companies only after they have recouped all their production costs, allowing them to deduct exploration and development costs and carry deductions forward at an appropriate interest rate.

In Alberta, oilsands producers already pay a type of cash-flow tax while conventional oil and gas producers pay gross-revenue royalties. The entire royalty system could be improved, Dachis said.

"When it comes to good design, there are a number of things the province should be thinking about, in terms of tweaking the oilsands (royalty) regime and then adopting a full reform of the gross-revenue royalties, to adopt a best-in-class cash-flow model that allows companies to fully recoup at least the taxable component of their investments," he said. "That's going to encourage investment."

Premier Rachel Notley has said the results of the royalty review panel's work won't be controversial. The government has already pledged the current rates will stay in place until at least 2017.

The C.D. Howe report says the new federal government, which has vowed to review environmental assessment processes, should make sure that regulators keep a narrow focus when evaluating pipeline projects and other major infrastructure proposals.

"Social acceptance entails more than the regulatory process," Dachis said. "A pipeline regulator can't fix the greenhouse gas emissions coming from the oilsands. A pipeline regulator can't deal with, at least directly, First Nations issues. Governments cannot punt these questions offto the regulators."

dhowell@postmedia.com twitter.com/HowellEJ


RE 
cana : Canada | caab : Alberta | norw : Norway | eurz : Europe | namz : North America | nordz : Nordic Countries | scandz : Scandinavia

IPD 
News | difficult,finally,mirror,institute,government,policy

PUB 
Edmonton Journal

AN 
Document EDJR000020160107ec170000x


HD Four Priorities for Reviving Canada's Energy Sector in 2016 - C.D. Howe Institute
CR C.D. Howe Institute; Canada NewsWire
WC 642 words
PD 7 January 2016
ET 04:00
SN Canada NewsWire
SC CNNW
LA English
CY Copyright © 2016 Canada NewsWire Ltd. All rights reserved.

LP 

TORONTO, Jan. 7, 2016 /CNW/ - Canada's energy sector will need to think about more than just low oil prices in 2016. There are numerous structural issues facing the sector that will need to be overcome, according to a new report from the C.D. Howe Institute. In "The Future of Canadian Energy Policy," the second edition of the Institute's National Priorities 2016 series, author Benjamin Dachis contends that getting elements of energy policy right should be made a national priority.

"Few in the Canadian energy sector – as well as the many Canadians who depend on it – are sad to see 2015 move into the history books. In 2016, the energy sector will be nervously watching government policies," states Dachis.

TD 

The report classifies the policy issues facing Canada's energy sector into four main themes, they are:

*Global competitiveness of Canada's energy industry: Top of mind for most stakeholders in the Canadian energy industry in 2016 will be the global competitiveness of its oil and gas and electricity sectors. With Alberta's resource royalty review about to conclude in early 2016, it should recommend that the province adopt the international best practice of cash-flow tax design. As for competiveness in electricity, Ontario should consider the implementation of a capacity market, where generators would compete to offer supply at a lower price than they do now.

*Social acceptance to enable market access for Canadian energy: Getting Canadian energy to world markets will remain a key priority in 2016. Having a robust regulatory approval system is critical for governments – and the energy sector – to ensure that Canada's energy products get to world markets safely and in environmentally friendly, socially accepted ways. When it comes to the pipeline review process, however, the federal government should focus on minor changes, not major reforms, and should be especially wary of changing the review process for pipelines already underway. But social acceptance entails more than the regulatory process, and requires governments to take the lead in areas outside the remit of regulators.

*Collaborative governance: Carbon pricing will likely be the key collaborative governance issue in 2016, and the new federal government will need to tackle a provincial policy patchwork on climate issues. Energy producers and transportation companies will also need to look at their own practices to improve their chances of getting project support. Both federal and provincial regulators will need to examine how their securities and competition policies will affect potential mergers in the energy sector.

*Innovation: Rather than focus innovation and diversification policies on what is physically produced in Canada and its provinces, governments should focus on how to enable Canadian companies to become global leaders in the specific technologies they are best at applying.

Dachis concludes that "in 2016, governments across Canada should act to provide a competitive resource tax and fiscal regime, competitive electricity prices, a robust but prompt regulatory review system, collaborative carbon policies, and an economy that encourages an innovative energy sector."

For the report go to: https://www.cdhowe.org/public-policy-research/future-canadian-energy-policy[https://www.cdhowe.org/public-policy-research/future-canadian-energy-policy]

The C.D. Howe Institute is an independent not-for-profit research institute whose mission is to raise living standards by fostering economically sound public policies. Widely considered to be Canada's most influential think tank, the Institute is a trusted source of essential policy intelligence, distinguished by research that is nonpartisan, evidence-based and subject to definitive expert review.

SOURCE C.D. Howe Institute

http://rt.prnewswire.com/rt.gif?NewsItemId=C7921&Transmission_Id=201601070600CANADANWCANADAPR_C7921&DateId=20160107[http://rt.prnewswire.com/rt.gif?NewsItemId=C7921&Transmission_Id=201601070600CANADANWCANADAPR_C7921&DateId=20160107]


CT 
Benjamin Dachis, Senior Policy Analyst; and Craig Alexander, Vice President, Economic Analysis, C.D. Howe Institute: 416-865-1904 or email: amcbrien@cdhowe.org

HD Excellere Announces Partnership with Proven Behavioral Health Executive Martin Favis
WC 508 words
PD 14 December 2015
ET 10:02
SN Business Wire
SC BWR
LA English
CY (c) 2015 Business Wire. All Rights Reserved.

LP 

DENVER--(BUSINESS WIRE)--December 14, 2015--

Excellere Partners, a Denver-based private equity firm focused on partnering with entrepreneurs to create industry leaders has teamed up with Martin Favis a recognized behavioral health operator to pursue a buy-and-build strategy in attractive mental health sectors.

TD 

Martin Favis, a 23-year veteran of the behavioral health industry, has a track record of success and achievement in both public and private equity sponsored environments, particularly in leading multi-site and multi-state operations. Notably, Mr. Favis has significant experience in corporate development activities through over 20 M&A transactions and integrations throughout his career. Mr. Favis previously held senior executive roles with Embassy Management, The Duvall Home, Providence Service Corporation and Camelot Care.

According to Mr. Favis, "The continued ills of society suggest strong demand for reputable mental health service providers that are focused on doing things the right way. There is a tremendous unmet need for strong clinical providers truly focused on improving patient care and meeting the expectations of patients and family members who are seeking providers that will treat their loved ones with compassion and a commitment to effective treatment. Excellere and I look forward to identifying businesses to partner with that can benefit from additional resources such as investments in clinical support, staff training and operational excellence in order to expand the overall impact from reputable providers."

Matt Hicks, Partner at Excellere stated, "We developed our investment thesis within behavioral health due to the strong value proposition opportunity amongst patients, family members, clinicians, referral sources, government agencies and payers. That, combined with increasing social acceptance for those seeking treatment, a supportive legislative and payer environment to help improve care and outcomes, and significant market fragmentation, suggest an appealing framework to build an attractive market leader in many of the behavioral segments we pursue."

To learn more about Excellere's interest in the Behavioral Health sector, please contact Matt Hicks (303.765.2410 or mhicks@excellerepartners.com) or Justin Unertl (303.765.2416 or junertl@excellerepartners.com).

About Excellere Partners

Excellere Partners is a Denver-based private equity firm with $1.36 billion of committed capital across three funds, and specializes in partnering with entrepreneurs and management teams through recapitalizations and management buyouts. The Firm employs a proven research-driven, top down investment strategy, and supports its entrepreneurs and management teams with a proprietary value creation process designed to enhance corporate and operational infrastructure for scalability and growth. Excellere's investments are focused on differentiated and growth oriented companies positioned to benefit from industry consolidation and favorable macro-economic and demographic trends. The Firm's targeted industry sectors include healthcare services and products; energy and utility products and services; industrial technology and services; business services; and agri-business. For more information about Excellere, please visit http://www.excellerepartners.com[http://www.excellerepartners.com]

View source version on businesswire.com: http://www.businesswire.com/news/home/20151214006011/en/[http://www.businesswire.com/news/home/20151214006011/en/]

HD Moving from NIMBY to Yes: Stronger "Social Partnerships" Needed to Get Resource Projects off the Ground - C.D. Howe Institute
CR C.D. Howe Institute; Canada NewsWire
WC 545 words
PD 1 December 2015
ET 04:00
SN Canada NewsWire
SC CNNW
LA English
CY Copyright © 2015 Canada NewsWire Ltd. All rights reserved.

LP 

TORONTO, Dec. 1, 2015 /CNW/ - With the new federal government committed to reviewing the approval process for major resource projects, a key focus should be on encouraging stronger social partnerships between stakeholders, according to a new C.D. Howe Institute report. In "From 'Social Licence' to 'Social Partnership': Promoting Shared Interests for Resource and Infrastructure Development," authors Geoffrey Hale and Yale Belanger identify best practices for successful community engagement by companies, industries and governments that have a proven track record of success.

TD 

"Social partnerships have become a key element for energy and related infrastructure development," commented Hale. "Failure to secure social acceptance increases the risk of a project not coming to market," added Belanger. "Communities that don't feel their needs are well understood have greater incentives to form alliances with outside activist groups that pursue much stricter development limits as part of a broader ideological agenda."

The authors provide examples of successful multi-stakeholder "synergy" groups, government-led initiatives and "corridor" coalitions of groups across extended areas. They recommend a virtual handbook of best practices for industry, regulators and community leaders in the following areas:

*Building Multi-Stakeholder Groups and Networks: Local or regional industry working groups including industry representatives provide a valuable means of strengthening connections with local governments and communities, public health authorities and local emergency response professionals. These groups reduce risks, address community concerns, and respond more effectively to occasional emergencies.

*Multi-Jurisdictional Projects: Multi-jurisdictional initiatives require parallel processes that respect legal, institutional and social differences in various jurisdictions. The authors find successful examples of formal multi-jurisdictional advisory processes in British Columbia that could inform future negotiations elsewhere.

*Engaging First Nations and Aboriginal Communities: Consultation prior to detailed project design or approval has become a central factor influencing First Nations' acceptance of resource projects affecting traditional lands.

The energy sector's involvement in hundreds of diverse communities points to a number of lessons. Provincial and federal governments and regulators can do more by promoting multi-stakeholder groups and disclosing more about emergency response plans. Industry bodies should promote cultures of continuous improvement reinforced by benchmarks and internal reporting requirements that demonstrate adherence. Energy firms themselves can look to international certifications of their processes of social partnership, or pool resources to achieve similar objectives.

The C.D. Howe Institute is an independent not-for-profit research institute whose mission is to raise living standards by fostering economically sound public policies. Widely considered to be Canada's most influential think tank, the Institute is a trusted source of essential policy intelligence, distinguished by research that is nonpartisan, evidence-based and subject to definitive expert review.

For the report go to: https://www.cdhowe.org/%E2%80%9Csocial-licence%E2%80%9D-%E2%80%9Csocial-partnership%E2%80%9D-promoting-shared-interests-resource-and-infrastructure[https://www.cdhowe.org/%E2%80%9Csocial-licence%E2%80%9D-%E2%80%9Csocial-partnership%E2%80%9D-promoting-shared-interests-resource-and-infrastructure]

                    

SOURCE C.D. Howe Institute

http://rt.prnewswire.com/rt.gif?NewsItemId=C7026&Transmission_Id=201512010600CANADANWCANADAPR_C7026&DateId=20151201[http://rt.prnewswire.com/rt.gif?NewsItemId=C7026&Transmission_Id=201512010600CANADANWCANADAPR_C7026&DateId=20151201]


CT 
Geoffrey Hale, Professor of Political Science, and Yale Belanger, Associate Professor of Political Science, University of Lethbridge: 416-865-1904 or email: kmurphy@cdhowe.org.

NS

cana : Canada | caon : Ontario | namz : North America

IPC

IPD

HD Finnish mining sector to adopt Mining Association of Canada's Towards Sustainable Mining Initiative
CR Mining Association of Canada (MAC); Canada NewsWire
WC 736 words
PD 3 November 2015
ET 09:00
SN Canada NewsWire
SC CNNW
LA English
CY Copyright © 2015 Canada NewsWire Ltd. All rights reserved.

LP 

KITTILÄ, Finland, Nov. 3, 2015 /CNW/ - FinnMin, the Finnish Mining Association, today announced that it will adopt the Towards Sustainable Mining (TSM) initiative, a corporate social responsibility (CSR) program developed by the Mining Association of Canada (MAC) to improve environmental and social practices in the mining industry. This is the first time TSM has been adopted by a mining association outside of Canada. The agreement was signed at the Fennoscandian Exploration and Mining Conference (FEM).

FinnMin and many of its member companies chose TSM, as it is the most advanced initiative in the mining industry. TSM will contribute to the transparency and accountability of the mining industry and will, therefore, enhance social acceptance among the different stakeholders in Finnish civil society.

TD 

"TSM has proven its effectiveness in Canada, and we at FinnMin believe it will be a useful tool for Finnish mining companies when the companies develop their sustainability reporting in the future," comments Markus Ekberg, Chairman of FinnMin.

FinnMin's adoption of TSM is part of a larger commitment of MAC's to freely share TSM with other countries seeking tools to improve the environmental and social performance of their mining industry, including engagement with civil society and enhanced transparency and accountability.

"We are very pleased that FinnMin has, after a three-year multi-stakeholder process of its own that explored options for improving its mining sector's performance, has chosen TSM," said Pierre Gratton, President and CEO, MAC. "This is a significant milestone for TSM, and could be the start of it becoming a global standard." 

"The adoption of the TSM framework in Finland presents a great opportunity to share the many lessons learned from over a decade of building standards in Canada, and no doubt we will also be able to learn from their implementation experiences," said Alan Young, member of MAC's Community of Interest Advisory Panel.

Finland has already taken a key step in the implementation of TSM with the creation of the Finnish Network for Sustainable Mining.

"The agreement between FinnMin and MAC is very good news for the Finnish Network for Sustainable Mining. It represents the first step in the implementation of a new sustainability standard in the Finnish mining sector. I trust that most mining companies will join the standard within the next few years," says Eero Yrjö-Koskinen, Secretary General of the network.

For further information about TSM in Finland, please visit www.kaivosvastuu.fi[http://www.kaivosvastuu.fi/], in Canada, please visit www.mining.ca[http://www.mining.ca/].

Backgrounder: 

MAC-FinnMin Licensing Agreement for TSM Adoption[http://mining.ca/sites/default/files/documents/Backgrounder-MAC-FinnMin-TSM-Agreement.pdf]

About FinnMin

The Finnish Mining Association, FinnMin, promotes the Finnish mining and exploration industry and technology companies in the field. FinnMin also promotes knowledge of the environment and safety of its members, organizes research and represent its members in international organizations. The association has 45 members, which employ a total of five thousand employees. www.prokaivos.fi[http://www.prokaivos.fi/]

About MAC

The Mining Association of Canada is the national organization for the Canadian mining industry.  Its members account for most of Canada's production of base and precious metals, uranium, diamonds, metallurgical coal, mined oil sands and industrial minerals and are actively engaged in mineral exploration, mining, smelting, refining and semi-fabrication. Please visit www.mining.ca[http://www.mining.ca/]. 

About TSM

The Towards Sustainable Mining (TSM) initiative is the CSR standard developed by the Mining Association of Canada. The Finnish version of TSM contains eight protocols (stakeholder involvement, conservation of biodiversity, tailings management, water management, CO2 reduction and energy efficiency, safety and health, crisis management, and mine closure), which have been divided into different performance levels (similar in structure to the credit rating system). Mining companies are expected to report regularly on the implementation of each protocol. In addition, their activities will be evaluated by an external auditor every three years.

 

SOURCE Mining Association of Canada (MAC)

http://rt.prnewswire.com/rt.gif?NewsItemId=C4259&Transmission_Id=201511031100CANADANWCANADAPR_C4259&DateId=20151103[http://rt.prnewswire.com/rt.gif?NewsItemId=C4259&Transmission_Id=201511031100CANADANWCANADAPR_C4259&DateId=20151103]


CT 
Jessica Draker, The Mining Association of Canada, (613) 233-9392 x225 or jdraker@mining.ca; Pekka Suomela, The Finnish Mining Industry, (358) 50 533 2848 or pekka.suomela@techind.fi (Call 1 AM - 3 PM EST); Eero Yrjö-Koskinen, The Finnish Network for Sustainable Mining (358) 50 347 8778 or eyk@kaivosvastuu.fi, (Call 1 AM - 3 PM EST)
