HD Taking Offshore Up North: Modularization Innovation Helps Tackle Oilsands Labour Concerns
WC 609 words
PD 21 September 2015
SN The Daily Oil Bulletin
SC DOILB
LA English
CY (c)2015 copyright Junewarren-Nickle’s Energy Group. All rights reserved

LP 

Labour is a scarce, expensive resource in the oilsands, and it’s an issue that can be helped by modularization, a recent Oilsands Review speaker series event heard.

“How are we addressing the challenges? I would like to think that we are addressing them with innovation and execution — stealing from other industries and stealing with pride,” said Simon Nottingham, general manager at Fluor Canada Ltd. “We are doing that with our 3rd Gen Modular Execution.”

TD 

The 3rd Gen approach splits projects into process blocks and moves them into designing modules, which in part maximizes the transfer of labour hours from a low-efficiency, high-cost field environment to higher-efficiency, lower-cost module fabrication yards. According to Nottingham, the notion was “stolen with pride” from the offshore sector.

“Moving that design and execution philosophy into northern Alberta, that is how we are providing innovation,” he said. “We can get to a predictable design. I know that our modular yards and fabrication facilities can start executing much more efficiently.”

Repeatable steel structural design deployed in the oilsands would certainly benefit those in the field, added Nottingham. “They would not have to redo all of the jigs and look up the oil specs for each different modular. Imagine what we could do with that in terms of a fabrication concept and getting that into the design.”

Unfortunately, noted Nottingham, convincing clients to implement offshore modularization methods in northern Alberta is a challenge, even if these methods make a lot of sense and putting pumps on steel is proven to work on platforms in the North Sea or off the coast of Africa, or in the shipbuilding industry where there are no foundations or piles for the pumps.

“I really think there are some real opportunities, but we are slow adopters here in the oilsands industry,” he said.

Although there are well-known challenges with oilsands development, Nottingham believes that Alberta has one of the best, largest hydrocarbon reserves in the world. However, maximizing the returns on that potential requires tackling various challenges, including environmental concerns and social acceptance associated with the industry, as well as the human resources issue, he said.

“We are a great, innovative province that is blessed with a huge resource, but with about [only] four million people, and so it is very difficult to build on those great plans.”

Innovation through the downturn

Siemens Canada Limited (sponsor for the Speaker Series event) is looking for technology leaders in the Canadian oil and gas space to be enablers and motivators of innovation, said senior account manager John Lusty. “We want to support those innovators in order to ensure that our oil and gas industry becomes more resilient, and so that it can respond to the next downturn without so much of the severe cost cutting measures that we see today.”

He added: “We want to make sure that as this cycle repeats itself — because it will and we all know that — we are better positioned to be able to use innovation and technology, and link together our physical assets and digital assets to make our processes more efficient, and our organizations more resilient to whatever challenges may come.”

While the energy sector and commodity markets are going through tough times, and press coverage of the sector seems rather grim, Lusty said this is not the first industry recently to experience such a challenge. In 2007-08, the North American auto market went through what Lusty calls “an existential threat.” However, he added, those same companies are now thriving, surviving and more successful than before the global recession.


CO 
flurcp : Fluor Corporation

IN 
i502 : Heavy Construction | iconst : Construction | icre : Real Estate/Construction

NS 
coffs : Production/Services Relocation | ccat : Corporate/Industrial News | gtheft : Burglary/Theft | c02 : Corporate Changes | gcat : Political/General News | gcrim : Crime/Courts

RE 
cana : Canada | namz : North America

PUB 
Junewarren-Nickle’s Energy Group

AN 
Document DOILB00020150921eb9l00006


HD Imaginea Seeks Freshwater Alternative; Company To Get Off Irrigation Channel By Q3 2016
WC 873 words
PD 17 September 2015
SN The Daily Oil Bulletin
SC DOILB
LA English
CY (c)2015 copyright Junewarren-Nickle’s Energy Group. All rights reserved

LP 

Imaginea Energy Corp., by Q3 2016, will not have any water pump or jerrican taking water from irrigation channels — or at least that’s the goal.

“We would like to get off freshwater and we would like to use all our produced water for all our needs,” Krzysztof Palka, chief strategist of sustainability, innovation and operational leadership, told this week’s Canadian Shale Water Recycling and Reuse 2015 Congress. “For some of the operations requiring freshwater, we would add additional processing for a smaller volume from all those oilfield operations.”

TD 

He added: “We don’t have to go all the way to produce water that has the quality of potable water or irrigation water. We can just go to as low as we can to ensure that we can use the water in our downhole [operations], without running into compatibility issues.”

A small producer of about 2,300 bbls per day in the dry region of southern Alberta, Imaginea currently satisfies its water needs from irrigation channels. In 2009, Palka noted, it took 0.14 bbls of water to produce one bbl of oil, and the amount of water required to produce oil is constantly increasing. Once injected into disposal wells, water used in oilfield operations is removed from the hydrologic cycle.

“If every year we draw a little bit more water from the system, then it is really in principle not a good thing, and so we really have to figure out something,” he said, adding the reduction of operational freshwater usage is a certainly simpler, more attainable environmental goal than reducing greenhouse gas emissions. “This may be something that is maybe worth exploring for various reasons, including social acceptance.”

According to Palka, for every bbl of oil produced in Imaginea’s operations, there is far more brackish water produced along with it. “If you think about it, just based on the nature of oil to water that we produce, we are a water producer. We take and sell the oil and gas, but really we are in the business of producing water.”

Considering the amount of water that then gets injected into the formation as pressure maintenance, he said, there is much water producers discard that could actually be used for operations if it could be cleaned up enough. His company realizes that if it could even use a portion of the water it produces for further hydrocarbon production, then it would mean the company would use less to no irrigation channel freshwater.

“Imagine that we produce 10,000 cubic metres of water every day with 50,000 [total dissolved solids], we take a small portion of the water, say 150 cubic metres per day, and we process it and get 100 cubic metres of irrigation-quality water with a very low concentration of all the solids, then we take the concentrated brine and reintroduce it back into the water-injection stream that we are injecting to maintain reservoir pressure.

“It allows us to produce more oil, and suddenly the impact on injection water is fairly minute. There are no issues of compatibility. We effectively do not have any water we have to dispose, and we produce key water that we can use for operations and then maybe share the balance.”

Among those companies offering potential freshwater alternatives for Imaginea is Saltworks Technologies Inc., which has a fleet of mobile pilots and manufactures desalination and treatment plants to deal with some of the most complex wastewaters and brines. “It is basically a low-temperature humidifying and dehumidifying cycle,” Palka said. “It is very good, because it can be used on this brine and will produce salts as part of the process.”

In total, according to Palka, the Saltworks option would cost his company about $11 per cubic metre of freshwater created, which he believes to be not too expensive.

Another company, Altela Inc., uses evaporation and condensation, assisted with steam, to turn produced water into freshwater. Because it uses more energy, the Altela method produces more emissions and costs more money than the Saltworks option. However, while it costs $30 per cubic metre of freshwater created, and it makes less water per day than the other sample, Palka said freshwater from Altela is stream ready.

Thirdly, Atlantis Technologies uses patented radial deionization technology, which passes salty water between two oppositely-charged supercapacitors that attract ions from the water. Leaving within a dielectric layer, the ions pass through a charge-specific membrane coating, and are adsorbed onto the surface. Once filled with ions, capacitor polarity is reversed and the ions are discharged back into the dielectric spacer and removed from the system.

“It is very simple, it uses a relatively low amount of energy,” Palka told the Canadian Business Conferences event. He added: “It’s modularized, it’s standardized, and it can be made portable and mobile.”

If Imaginea could even just partially clean that water and reintroduce it into the reservoir for oil and gas operations, Palka emphasized, then maybe the company could avoid some of the costs from producing brackish water along with oil in the first place, as well as save some money on water disposal.


NS 
ccat : Corporate/Industrial News

RE 
cana : Canada | namz : North America

PUB 
Junewarren-Nickle’s Energy Group

AN 
Document DOILB00020150917eb9h00003


HD CERI Study Sees Potential For Canadian Petrochemical Industry Expansion
WC 1498 words
PD 15 September 2015
SN The Daily Oil Bulletin
SC DOILB
LA English
CY (c)2015 copyright Junewarren-Nickle’s Energy Group. All rights reserved

LP 

With suitable access to natural gas and associated liquids at a cost-competitive price, there is the potential for an expansion of the Canadian petrochemical industry, says a new study by the Canadian Energy Research Institute.

“When you look at the elements that create a competitive advantage, feedstock is very important and in terms of feedstock, Western Canada is well positioned to be competitive,” Allan Fogwill, president and chief executive officer of CERI, said in an interview. “The challenge is access to markets.”

TD 

As products from western Canadian petrochemical products cannot be absorbed within the region, they will require export markets and the means of getting the product to market, he said. That likely will mean rail, depending upon the product, given the increasing difficulty in obtaining pipeline approvals, Fogwill suggested.

The report, Examining the Expansion Potential of the Petrochemical Industry in Canada, also identifies other challenges that need to be addressed, including the development of offshore markets for natural gas to increase the supply of natural gas liquids, especially ethane and the need for added infrastructure for separating sufficient ethane from incremental gas production.

The Canadian petrochemical industry is centred mainly in Alberta (Joffre and Fort Saskatchewan) and Ontario (Sarnia) with 75 per cent of installed capacity used to convert ethane to ethylene (olefin-based). There is a limited aromatics-based industry in Montreal using feedstock from the Suncor Energy Inc. refinery.  

“We are competitive with other areas of the world,” he said. While he acknowledged that competitiveness is less today because of the smaller gap between the price of oil (which most countries use as feedstock) and the price of natural gas used in Canada, “it indicates it should be an area that needs to be considered when petrochemical companies are considering their next investment.

The next step, said Fogwill, would be for CERI to compare the costs of petrochemical plants in specific North American locations, including the Gulf Coast, Western Canada, Ontario and Quebec.

Olefins and aromatics, the two major basic building blocks of the petrochemical industry, are used as feedstock in derivatives or intermediate plants to produce end-use products including various grades of plastics, resins, fibres, and solvents.

In Alberta, where NOVA ChemicalsCanada and DOW Chemical Canada ULC are the major players, the major sources of petrochemical feedstock include NGLs (mainly ethane) from gas processing plants and off-gas plants.

The crackers, though, have a small degree of flexibility to crack some volumes of propane when ethane supply is constrained or when propane offers a cost advantage. “This highlights the fact that the petrochemical industry in Alberta is reliant on supply of NGLs, primarily ethane, which is tied to production and processing of natural gas,” said the report.

In addition to the  olefins (primarily propylene but also some ethylene) produced during the crude oil refining process, other processes such as propane dehydrogenation (PDH) which produces propylene are becoming more prominent, it said.

Because olefins generally are produced in a gaseous state, there usually is downstream integration of derivatives with the cracker generally producing enough ethylene to meet downstream demand. And because ethylene, similar to ethane, is neither easy to transport nor store, ethylene crackers are usually built in conjunction with ethylene derivative plants.

In Ontario, about 60 per cent of the province’s petrochemical capacity is based on olefins and 40 per cent on aromatics (toluene and benzene). Historically, feedstock for olefins facilities has been sourced from Western Canada (NGLs and crude oil/condensate) and local refineries (liquid petroleum gas or LPG). More recently, NGLs (primarily ethane and propane) are being imported from the United States to feed steam crackers.

Aromatics-based facilities sourced their feedstock from local refineries (which in turn source their crude oil from Western Canada and overseas) and local olefin crackers.

CERI said its study demonstrates that the principal consideration in determining whether a region is cost competitive is the feedstock price and second, feedstock availability in sufficient quantity.

North America, which along with the Middle East uses natural gas as  feedstock, has an advantage in that area because the rest of the world uses mainly oil-based feedstocks in petrochemical production.

The Middle East has the greatest cost advantage but this is due to incentives making their feedstocks artificially low, according to the CERI study, which based its analysis on 2012 numbers.  Canada and the United States are the next most competitive regions, followed by Latin America and some parts of the Asia Pacific region.

However, the report noted that recent information regarding investment costs indicates the cost differentials between Canada and the U.S. and globally between ethane and naphtha-based processes are narrowing.

A report from Wood Mackenzie analyzed the cost of ethylene production at various oil and natural gas prices. At $4 per mmBtu for natural gas, the ethylene production cost is approximately 15 cents per pound, increasing to 20-25 cents per pound at $7 per mmBtu for natural gas.

While an August 2015 Brent crude price in the $50 to $60 per bbl range would suggest a naphtha-based price for ethylene in Asia of less than 30 cents per pound, North American ethane based ethylene is cost competitive at between 10 and 20 cents per pound, the consultants determined. However, transportation cost to the growing Asian market would increase this cost.

In the long-term, though, there is a structural price advantage in North America as a result of feedstock costs, according to CERI.

Feedstock availability is another advantage with the total supply of ethane available to Western Canada forecast to increase over time, it said.

The total supply of ethane available to Western Canada is projected to rise to 956,000 bbls per day by 2030 with the greatest projected growth from British Columbia gas as a result of LNG projects. CERI assumes that three LNG terminals will be built, totalling 5.4 bcf per day of capacity and operating at an annual average of 4.8 bcf per day.

Ethane also could be extracted in Western Canada from gas streaming, new straddle plants or LNG ethane extraction, highlighting the importance of both extraction and end-use infrastructure, the study suggested.

For olefins and their derivatives, the most important factor in global prices is the cost structure of the marginal producer which is required to satisfy a given level of demand (usually the highest cost producers), according to the study.

“This means that the feedstock cost advantage generally stays with the low cost producers and translates into higher margins, but not necessarily lower olefin and derivative prices,” it said. “Higher margins however, can fuel re-investment and expansion cycles.”

The study estimated that Canada has up to an additional 350,000 bbls per day of ethane which would provide sufficient supply for two to three additional world scale crackers if all the ethane in the natural gas were to be recovered, rather than the approximately 50 per cent currently recovered.

Plant capacity utilization in Canada is currently high, averaging above 90 per cent, said the report. While there is some excess capacity, it remains to be seen if the utilization rate can be moved up to the 95 to 100 per cent range, it said.  “If not, one observation is that there is no significant excess capacity at this time in Canada,” it said.

Petrochemical companies globally are responding to disruptions in supply and demand by adapting their business models, which include improving scale, operational efficiencies, and value chain integration to drive down costs, the study noted.  A 2012 study by the consulting firm KPMG indicated that chemical manufacturing in Canada costs are about three per cent lower than in the United States and about seven per cent less than in Japan, it said.

However, “this assessment does not include the cost advantage to Canada with respect to feedstocks, nor the added cost in Western Canada to move petrochemicals or their derivatives to tidewater,” the report said.

Market access remains a challenge if expansion is to occur in Canada, CERI said. While the petrochemical sector has been built to serve the domestic and U.S. markets, they show little potential for growth either due to a lack of increase in demand or increased capacity in the U.S. to serve that market, it said.

Overseas market access would be needed to facilitate expansion of the sector in Canada. In the east, this access challenge is due to the far distance between producers and the market.

In the west, the challenge is to move product from Alberta to the B.C. coast, most likely by rail. Although pipeline access would be cheaper, the social acceptance of pipelines is difficult to obtain, the study suggested.  According to the 2015 chemical industry update of the Conference Boardof Canada, one weakness of the chemicals industry is the decline in access to rail transportation and insufficient pipeline capacity, which threatens the industry’s cost structure, it said.


IN 
i2512 : Basic Organic Chemicals | i25121 : Petrochemicals | i25 : Chemicals | ibasicm : Basic Materials/Resources

NS 
mlpg : Liquid Petroleum Gas Markets | ccat : Corporate/Industrial News | m14 : Commodity Markets | m143 : Energy Markets | mcat : Commodity/Financial Market News | mcrntg : Crude Oil/Natural Gas Product Markets | ncat : Content Types | nfact : Factiva Filters | nfce : C&E Exclusion Filter

RE 
cana : Canada | caon : Ontario | usa : United States | namz : North America

PUB 
Junewarren-Nickle’s Energy Group

AN 
Document DOILB00020150915eb9f00001


SE News & Opinion
HD Wind turbines hit new heights; Bigger machines capture energy more efficiently
BY Ian Bickis
CR The Canadian Press
WC 715 words
PD 12 August 2015
SN Edmonton Journal
SC EDJR
ED Early
PG A11
LA English
CY Copyright © 2015 Edmonton Journal

LP 

From megawatts to the size of rotors, everything about wind turbines has been getting bigger.

But even proponents of wind power say they may be reaching a limit as logistics and a lack of social acceptance over their size start to hinder growth.

TD 

San Francisco-based Pattern Energy Group Inc. recently announced it will be installing 61 GE turbines at its Meikle wind project in B.C. capable of generating between 2.75 and 3.2 megawatts of power. At 180 megawatts, Meikle will be the largest wind project in the province.

The 2.75-megawatt turbine rotors will be nearly 60 metres long, while the tower to hold the rotors will be 110 metres. That means the blade tips will reach a height of 170 metres. GE says they're the biggest publicly planned wind turbines in the country.

These latest turbines dwarf those of 30 years ago, when the average turbine had a diameter of 15 metres and pumped out all of 50 kilowatts.

Robert Hornung, president of the Canadian Wind Energy Association, said this evolution in size has been critical for the industry's growth because it allows for more energy to be captured more efficiently.

"Generally, the further off the ground you get, the better the quality of the wind resource. It's more consistent, it's often stronger, which means there's more energy to capture out of the wind."

He said because wind turbines have become more productive, they can also operate in more places.

"We're now able to build productive wind turbines in areas where 10 to 15 years ago you never would have been able to because you never would have been able to capture enough energy to make it worthwhile."

While the sheer size of the newest turbines are the most noticeable advancement, Hornung said every aspect of the technology has been improving, including rotor shape, the use of carbon fibre for lighter blades, and the ability to rotate the blades automatically to capture as much wind as possible.

That kind of progress has helped make wind the most installed form of energy in Canada in the past five years and has driven the cost of constructing wind turbines down by 50 to 60 per cent, said Hornung.

Ward Marshall, director of business development at Pattern Energy, said equipment and computer modelling to optimize the use of that equipment have led to dramatic improvements in performance.

"You have the ability to get all the oink out of the pig," said Marshall.

But while the latest turbines will allow Pattern to capture more energy, Marshall thinks they may be reaching a limit.

"There's always this issue of how big is too big."

The logistics of actually getting massive turbines to sites are getting more complicated, especially in hillier areas of B.C. and Quebec, said Marshall.

Some turbines are being designed to be built more onsite, but that adds to costs, said Marshall.

There's also the problem of social acceptability and public resistance to large towers on the landscape, said Hornung. "In essence, how big can you build in an area where people are living?" But so far those challenges haven't stopped Canada's wind capacity from growing, with more than 10,000 installed megawatts today compared with about 300 megawatts in 2003, said Hornung.

"It's demonstrated that it's truly a mainstream technology at this point."


ART 
Andrew Vaughan, The Canadian Press / A wind turbine is framed by a sun dog, an atmospheric phenomenon, in Dalhousie Mountain, N.S. From the megawatts of energy produced to the size of the rotors, everything about wind turbines has been getting bigger. Such progress has driven down the cost of wind turbine construction by up to 60 per cent.; Andrew Vaughan, The Canadian Press / A wind turbine is framed by a sun dog, an atmospheric phenomenon, in Dalhousie Mountain, N.S. From the megawatts of energy produced to the size of the rotors, everything about wind turbines has been getting bigger. Such progress has driven down the cost of wind turbine construction by up to 60 per cent. [EDJN_20150812_Early_A11_01_I001.jpg];

CO 
cnwea : Canadian Wind Energy Association | paeglp : Pattern Energy Group Inc.

IN 
iwind : Wind Energy | i1 : Energy | i16 : Electricity/Gas Utilities | i16101 : Electric Power Generation | i163 : Renewable Energy Generation | ieutil : Electric Utilities | iutil : Utilities

RE 
cana : Canada | caab : Alberta | namz : North America

IPD 
News | megawatts,rotors,everything,turbines,getting,bigger

PUB 
Edmonton Journal

AN

SE Canada
HD Wind turbines reach new heights
BY Ian Bickis
CR The Canadian Press
WC 260 words
PD 12 August 2015
SN Windsor Star
SC WINSTR
ED Early
PG D1 / Front
LA English
CY Copyright © 2015 Windsor Star

LP 

From megawatts to the size of rotors, everything about wind turbines has been getting bigger.

But even proponents of wind power say they may be reaching a limit as logistics and a lack of social acceptance over their size start to hinder growth.

TD 

San Francisco-based Pattern Energy Group Inc recently announced it will be installing 61 GE turbines at its Meikle wind project in British Columbia capable of generating between 2.75 and 3.2 megawatts of power. At 180 megawatts, Meikle will be the largest wind project in the province.

The 2.75-megawatt turbine rotors will be nearly 60 metres long, while the tower to hold the rotors will stand at 110 metres.

That means the tip of the blades will reach 170 metres high, or a little taller than the tower on Montreal's Olympic Stadium.

GE says they're the biggest publicly planned wind turbines in the country.

These latest turbines dwarf those of 30 years ago, when the average turbine had a diameter of 15 metres and pumped out all of 50 kilowatts.

Robert Hornung, president of the Canadian Wind Energy Association, said this evolution in size has been critical for the industry's growth because it allows for more energy to be captured more efficiently.

"Generally, the further off the ground you get, the better the quality of the wind resource. It's more consistent, it's often stronger, which means there's more energy to capture out of the wind."

HD Six stories in the news today, Aug. 11
CR CP
WC 459 words
PD 11 August 2015
ET 01:20
SN The Canadian Press
SC CPR
LA English
CY (c) 2015 The Canadian Press. All rights reserved.

LP 

Six stories in the news today, Aug. 11 from The Canadian Press:

LIBERAL, NDP ANTI-TERROR STRATEGY JUST 'DROPPING AID ON DEAD PEOPLE': HARPER

TD 

NDP Leader Tom Mulcair and Liberal Leader Justin Trudeau have previously rejected military action against ISIL in Syria and Iraq, calling instead for humanitarian aid. Conservative Leader Stephen Harper responded to those positions Monday by saying both parties would fight insurgents overseas by doing little more than "dropping aid on dead people.''

SAILORS CHARGED IN SEX ASSAULT DUE IN COURT

Three of four British sailors charged with sexually assaulting a woman in Halifax are expected in court today to challenge the conditions of their bail. The men want to return to the United Kingdom pending a preliminary inquiry scheduled for five days next April. The Crown is expected to oppose today's application.

ONT. PREMIER TO PROVIDE PENSION PLAN DETAILS

Ontario Premier Kathleen Wynne and Finance Minister Charls Sousa are expected to provide more details today about the province's new pension plan. The plan hit a snag in July when the federal government refused to co-operate with a request to help administer the plan. Wynne then promised to proceed without federal assistance.

MORTGAGE BROKERS CALLING FOR TIGHTER RULES

Mortgage brokers are advocating for tighter industry rules in the wake of allegations that dozens of brokers working with Home Capital Group Inc. falsified client income information. Home Capital said last month that it had suspended 45 brokers for allegedly committing fraud on mortgage applications, leaving the industry in damage control mode.

TRIAL FOR FIVE ALLEGED HELLS ANGELS STARTS IN MONTREAL

A trial is under way for five alleged Hells Angels charged with murder and conspiracy. The Crown says it might call as many as 300 witnesses in a trial expected to last between a year and 18 months. The Crown alleges the five suspects took part in the biker war between 1994 and 2002 to help the Hells expand its turf and control the illegal drug trade.

WIND TURBINES REACH FOR NEW HEIGHTS

From megawatts to the size of rotors, everything about wind turbines has been getting bigger. But even proponents of wind power say they may be reaching a limit due to logistics and a lack of social acceptance. San Francisco-based Pattern Energy Group Inc. recently announced it will install 61 turbines at its Meikle wind project in B.C. capable of generating between 2.75 and 3.2 megawatts of power. At 180 megawatts, Meikle will be the largest wind project in the province.

ALSO IN THE NEWS ...

_ Canada Mortgage and Housing Corp. will release July housing starts in Canada.

_ Home renovation retailer Rona Inc. will release its second-quarter results.

SE News
HD Pot-testing machine almost ready to go; Local Company: Groups raise concerns for workers
BY Nick Eagland
CR The Province
WC 589 words
PD 23 July 2015
SN Vancouver Province
SC VANPRO
ED Final
PG A15
LA English
CY Copyright © 2015 Vancouver Province

LP 

Workplace tokers may soon find their cover blown by a high-tech machine built to smoke them out.

The Vancouver firm behind a marijuana breathalyzer says its product is now months away from final testing, after which it could end up in the hands of law enforcers and employers.

TD 

But experts say there are some big caveats before widespread workplace weed screening becomes commonplace. Publicly-traded Cannabix Technologies Inc. has in recent months worked with medical marijuana users to test a prototype of its breathalyzer, which determines whether someone has ingested tetrahydrocannabinol (THC), an active component of pot, within the past two hours.

Cannabix's president Kal Mahli said his firm hopes to have it on the market following a battery of beta-testing to ensure it's 100-per-cent accurate.

Mahli said his firm is being hounded by law enforcement agencies for the device, which has also generated interest from transport, shipping, mining and energy industries.

He claims Cannabix is first to develop a pot breathalyzer, though Colorado's Lifeloc Technologies, researchers at Western State University and a pair of University of Akron students have similar devices in the works.

Such breathalyzers are a response to pot's increased social acceptance and the need for a tool to determine if workers can safely perform their jobs, Mahli said.

Indeed, Health Canada expects the number of medical marijuana users to rise to 450,000 by 2024, up from 37,000 in 2013. Mahli predicts use of pot will surpass that of alcohol. Mahli said urine and saliva tests can detect past drug use, but don't necessarily demonstrate a worker's ability to work a given shift, which is where the breathalyzer comes in.

At issue, however, is whether such a device can reliably tell if a worker is fit for duty.

"Presence of THC and even the use of THC in the last couple of hours tells you only that the person has ingested THC in the last couple of hours," said Kirk Tousaw, a lawyer who works primarily with the medical marijuana industry. "It doesn't tell you whether or not that person is impaired ... if their performance is going to be affected."

Tousaw said he's seen hysteria around marijuana use in safety-conscious industries such as trucking and construction, and a lack of science about how marijuana impairs users - particularly medical or experienced users - has Tousaw concerned such a test could harm safe, efficient workers.

Micheal Vonn, policy director for the B.C. Civil Liberties Association, echoed Tousaw's concerns around detecting impairment.

"The trick always with these drug recognition tests is the ability to test for actual impairment, as opposed to use," Vonn said.

"What we don't want to see is the kind of tool that is so broad-based that it would show that someone used marijuana on the weekend, that they are a medical cannabis user and that any other kind of cannabis had been ingested that does not constitute the issue, which is impairment."

neagland@theprovince.com twitter.com/nickeagland


ART 
Ward Perrin, PNG files / Micheal Vonn of the B.C. Civil Liberties Association says testing must ensure marijuana is actually impairing someone's ability to work.; Ward Perrin, PNG files / Micheal Vonn of the B.C. Civil Liberties Association says testing must ensure marijuana is actually impairing someone's ability to work. [VAPR_20150723_Final_A15_01_I001.jpg];

SE Report on Business
HD NDP's energy initiatives carry risk and opportunity
BY By ALAN ROSS
WC 634 words
PD 14 July 2015
SN The Globe and Mail
SC GLOB
ED Ontario
PG B3
LA English
CY ©2015 The Globe and Mail Inc. All Rights Reserved.

LP 

Formerly Alberta's provincial representative to Ottawa, partner with Borden Ladner Gervais LLP. He has acted for and appeared on behalf of several energy companies

The Calgary Stampede is at a close, but a new stampede is just beginning. Alberta's NDP government is ushering in policy changes to the oil-and-gas sector with unprecedented scope and speed. It will profoundly impact how the province – indeed, the country – governs the naturalresource economy and wrestles with its energy superpower status. As Premier Rachel Notley recently explained to a group of international investors, “there is always more than you suspect beneath the surface" in Alberta.

TD 

Hopefully, the province likes what it finds.

The industry is running hard to keep up with the restructuring.

The province's emissions framework, royalties, corporate taxes and energy regulator are under review. One of these changes would be significant. All together may be overwhelming, particularly while flirting with recession.

Uncertain or onerous regulatory reforms create risk at a time of disconcerting market conditions.

Capital is mobile, even skittish, about oil prices and the Greek situation. China's turbulence is another dark cloud on the horizon.

Exploration and production companies with diversified asset bases can redirect dollars outside Alberta. There are abundant tight oil and shale-gas investment opportunities in the United States and elsewhere. Policies resulting in new operational costs have impacts on investment and drilling. Ensuring a competitive royalty, credit and incentive structure – even relative to Saskatchewan and British Columbia – remains critical.

The Premier appears to understand that economics matter. To run Alberta successfully, a government must acknowledge that the province is resource-reliant and that its role is to facilitate job creation. Ms. Notley showed this in a recent speech to the Stampede Investment Forum, calling the oil sands a “tremendous asset" that merit continued investment and expansion.

When a previous Alberta government introduced the Specified Gas Emitters Regulation in 2007, it was the first greenhouse gas (GHG) pricing policy in North America. Alberta's climatechange regime needs updating.

There are a number of models on offer. B.C. imposes a tax per tonne of CO2e (carbon dioxide equivalent) on fossil fuels. Quebec launched a cap-and-trade system. Ontario established a midterm GHG pollution-reduction target, and is moving toward cap-and-trade. All three provinces support a Western Climate Initiative that, along with California, is pursuing a broader regional cap-and-trade program.

No model reflects the full costs of navigating GHG restrictions in an oil-and-gas-dependent province. Nor are they perfect in themselves. Carbon-tax and capand-trade methodologies both add burdens for new facilities and barriers to investment with high net present value.

Perhaps above all, Alberta must demonstrate leadership on national energy issues. Market access, First Nations, GHGs and access to capital are examples where regional interests or interjurisdictional differences have impeded Alberta's success. Ms. Notley's government will also need to work collaboratively.

Engagement with other provinces and the federal government – irrespective of political stripe – prior to the United Nations Climate Change Conference in Paris is one opportunity. Decision making in the interests of Albertans, not the federal NDP or its election timetable, is another.

Stability in the energy sector and provincial revenue allow the Premier to address her priorities in health, education and infrastructure. Her government is undertaking some of the most important policy reviews in the province's history. The implications for Alberta and the entire country are fraught with risk, but contain tremendous opportunity.

The province can assist the social acceptance of energy infrastructure necessary for Canada to remain an international economic leader. Alberta can also provide leadership on what kind of energy superpower Canada wants to be, and at what price.


CO 
bordel : Borden Ladner Gervais LLP

IN 
i835 : Legal Services | ibcs : Business/Consumer Services

NS 
ccat : Corporate/Industrial News

RE 
cana : Canada | caab : Alberta | namz : North America

PUB 
The Globe and Mail Inc.

AN 
Document GLOB000020150714eb7e0001g


SE FP Comment
HD A divided Alberta Energy Regulator
BY Alan L. Ross And Michael Massicotte
CR National Post
WC 784 words
PD 3 July 2015
SN National Post
SC FINP
ED National
PG FP7
LA English
CY (c) 2015 National Post . All Rights Reserved.

LP 

The Alberta Energy Regulator's decisions impact billions of dollars in energy development and investment. Premier Notley is set to review the AER's mandate. Her government is undertaking an ambitious and comprehensive examination of Alberta's energy regulatory framework. A new policy direction is expected to address the Premier's concerns about the AER's role as both "a promoter of energy and the primary vehicle of environmental protection." This includes a potential split of the AER.

Irrespective of whatever potential benefits may result from a split AER, the uncertainty of a restructured regulator - for the second time in less than three years - creates risk for energy companies, investors, and the province as a whole. It is also unclear whether such dramatic reform is necessary to achieve the government's goals.

TD 

Changes to the scope of the AER and its predecessors have a long history in Alberta. Proposals for a "one-window" regulatory approval system span well over a decade. On December 10, 2012, a prior administration passed the Responsible Energy Development Act (REDA) - legislation that created a single regulator. The AER became operational in June 2013. It assumed the regulatory functions, from project application to reclamation, previously administered by the Energy Resources Conservation Board, and Alberta Environment and Sustainable Resource Development. Reorganization was completed in 2015.

The changes under REDA responded to complaints of inconsistent and duplicative procedures for resource development. REDA established a "one-stop" approval process. REDA - as well as federal legislation of the same era, including procedural streamlining amendments under National Energy Board Act - attempted to reduce the time and expense required to obtain regulatory approvals, and to make the Canadian energy industry more competitive and attractive for investment dollars globally.

Under REDA, oil and gas policy development rests with the provincial government. Alberta Energy now drives the AER's priorities. The achievement of government policy outcomes is undertaken by the AER. All of this represents significant change from what was previously an independent provincial energy regulator. If the government now seeks to effect further change to the mandate of the AER, the regulator does not necessarily need to be split. Rather, a new policy direction may be provided pursuant to section 67 of REDA - with a shortcoming. A criticism of REDA generally, and of section 67 in particular, is that it reduced the AER's independence from government.

The AER's stated mandate since the 2013 reorganization and the passage of REDA has been "to provide for the efficient, safe, orderly and environmentally responsible development of energy resources in Alberta through the Regulator's regulatory activities." This includes "the protection of the environment" and "the conservation and management of water, including the wise allocation and use of water." Premier Notley's chief concern is that the AER's environmental oversight and energy regulatory approval processes are inconsistent, based on her interpretation that the regulator's "overarching mandate is to promote energy development."

Given the relatively short timeframe REDA has been in force, it remains to be seen how effectively the objectives of environmental responsibility and resource development are co-managed. It is too early to assess the legitimacy of criticisms that a single regulator removes environmental checks and balances and shifts the AER's role to one of simply permitting.

Changes to the AER's structure are among the most significant reforms proposed by the new government. The AER's mandate impacts the energy industry's ability to obtain project approvals, secure financing and assess jurisdictional and regulatory risk. From an industry perspective, potential implications of a split regulator include lack of clarity, duplication, and project delays. However, it may also facilitate increased social acceptance for Canadian energy project development and result in greater focus on, and management of, each aspect of energy regulation.

A refreshed policy approach can be implemented through section 67 of REDA - albeit with effects on regulatory independence - and staffing changes. Some of the AER's recent innovative approaches, including cumulative impacts management and play-based regulation, may also provide an existing platform for the government to address environmental oversight concerns.

Energy Minister McCuaig-Boyd stated there will be "an announcement in the next few weeks" about a review of the AER and a wider look at Alberta's energy regulations. In a short period of time the new government is poised to address several critical pillars of Alberta's economy, including royalties, taxes and greenhouse gas. The AER is now among them - with implications for the entire country.

Alan L. Ross, formerly Alberta's Provincial Representative to Ottawa, and Michael Massicotte are partners with Borden Ladner

Gervais Llp.


NS 
c13 : Regulation/Government Policy | c131 : Regulatory Bodies | gpol : Domestic Politics | nedc : Commentaries/Opinions | ccat : Corporate/Industrial News | gcat : Political/General News | gpir : Politics/International Relations | ncat : Content Types | nfact : Factiva Filters | nfcpex : C&E Executive News Filter | nfcpin : C&E Industry News Filter

RE 
cana : Canada | namz : North America

IPD 
News | alberta,energy,decisions,impact,billions,dollars

PUB 
National Post

AN 
Document FINP000020150703eb7300046


SE OnLine
HD U.S. gay marriage ruling warms Sask hearts
BY Sean Trembath
WC 577 words
PD 27 June 2015
SN Postmedia Breaking News
SC CWNS
LA English
CY Copyright © 2015 Canwest News Service

LP 

Erin Beckwell knows the joy that comes with finally being legally allowed to marry the person you love.

In November 2004, Beckwell and her wife Lisa became the first same-sex couple to be legally married in Saskatchewan. On Friday she was taken back to that time, as the United States Supreme Court declared same-sex couples have a right to marry anywhere in the U.S.

TD 

"I got goosebumps just thinking about what it was like for us, waiting for those court decisions and the emotions afterward," Beckwell said shortly after hearing about the decision.

Since same-sex marriage became legal in Saskatchewan, 436 same-sex couples - 163 male and 273 female - have tied the knot in the province, according to eHealth Saskatchewan.

Even when the change came in Canada, Beckwell said she remembers thinking the U.S. queer community had a much longer road ahead. She wasn't sure she would see marriage legalized south of the border in her lifetime, she said.

"It's kind of surreal to imagine that, 10 years later, here we are."

Friday's 5-4 ruling means the 14 states with bans on gay marriage will have to stop enforcing them. Those states will also have to recognize gay marriages performed elsewhere.

Beckwell said the change here more than a decade ago helped shift people's understanding of LGBT people and culture.

"Even being able to go from referring to Lisa as my partner to being able to, and have other people, refer to her as my wife - it's a very subtle shift, but it matters," she said. She talked about marching in Saskatoon's pride parade more than a decade ago and hearing people say it was inappropriate for children to see gay people. This year, the parade included plenty of children whose parents wanted to teach them about diversity and acceptance, she said.

"Marriage is one of the factors that has allowed that conversation to happen."

While Saskatchewan people aren't directly affected by Friday's ruling, some same-sex couples have hesitated to travel to states where their marriage isn't recognized, according to Garnet Woloschuk, program manager at OUTSaskatoon.

"I know for some people, they don't really feel safe going to certain states," he said.

He called the ruling a positive step, but noted legal recognition is not the same thing as true social acceptance.

"Women have been equal under the law for decades, but if you talk to many women, would they say they feel equal?" Beckwell echoed that sentiment and mentioned other marginalized groups, such as transgender people, who still struggle for recognition. With marriage legally protected, she said energy should now be devoted to other causes.

With that in mind, Friday's news was still worth celebrating, and served as a landmark example of the progress that has been made, she said.

"When I came out nearly 20 years ago, (same-sex) marriage wasn't legal anywhere. That's kind of a profound thing to think about." strembath@thestarphoenix.com( mailto:strembath@thestarphoenix.com ) twitter.com/strembath

strembath@thestarphoenix.com( mailto:strembath@thestarphoenix.com )

twitter.com/strembath

By the numbers

Same-sex marriages in Saskatchewan

2004 - 11

2005 - 50

2006 - 33

2007 - 26

2008 - 35

2009 - 28

2010 - 29

2011 - 44

2012 - 54

2013 - 52

2014 - 57

2015 - 17

Total - 436

© Copyright (c) The StarPhoenix


NS 
gsoc : Social Issues | ggaym : Same-Sex Marriage/Civil Union | glgbt : LGBT Rights | gcat : Political/General News | gcom : Society/Community | ghum : Human Rights/Civil Liberties

RE 
cask : Saskatchewan | usa : United States | cana : Canada | namz : North America

IPD 
beckwell,knows,comes,finally,being,legally

PUB 
Canwest News Service

AN 
Document CWNS000020150627eb6r0063m


SE FP Comment
HD Alberta makes big move on carbon
BY Neil McCrank and Alan L. Ross
CR Financial Post
WC 943 words
PD 26 June 2015
SN National Post
SC FINP
ED National
PG FP7
LA English
CY (c) 2015 National Post . All Rights Reserved.

LP 

It is summertime in Alberta, and change is here. Climate change policy, messy and multi-jurisdictional, tops Premier Rachel Notley's proposed reforms. Experimentation risks turning an Edmonton summer into a winter of discontent in the province's battered oil and gas community. However, if implemented prudently, Alberta's leadership on greenhouse gas (GHG) emissions can unlock new energy infrastructure development to the benefit of all Canadians.

When the Alberta government introduced the Specified Gas Emitters Regulation in 2007, it was the first GHG pricing policy in North America. It set limits for large emitters. The regulation created an intensity-based approach to improve production efficiency without a cap on total annual emissions. It required facilities that emit more than 100,000 tonnes of GHG a year in carbon dioxide equivalent (CO2e) to reduce emissions intensity by 12 per cent.

TD 

There were four ways a company could comply with Alberta's GHG framework: (i) improvements to their operations; (ii) Alberta-based carbon offset credits; (iii) emission performance credits; and (iv) contributions to the Climate Change and Emissions Management Fund into which an emitter paid $15 per tonne of CO2e emissions over target.

In Alberta, companies could buy offset credits as a replacement for improving the environmental performance in their own operations - for example, a tonne of upgrader pollution is cancelled out by a tonne of wind-farm reductions. Given the relative lack of exchange opportunities in Alberta, the province's offset market historically faced challenges. The fund became the preferred vehicle for emissions reduction, largely because it guaranteed a ceiling price.

As previous administrations acknowledged, Alberta's climate-change regime needed refreshment. The Specified Gas Emitters Regulation was created as a flexible scheme, to be "reviewed for ongoing relevancy and necessity." It was meant to be responsive to technological changes and policy harmonization. The chief criticism of the Specified Gas Emitters Regulation was its intensity-based approach, which did not generate reductions in absolute emissions.

This week, significant change arrived. The province's new environment and parks minister, Shannon Phillips, announced Specified Gas Emitters Regulation would be extended until at least the end of 2017. The results are significant and - in Alberta - unprecedented. Any facility that emits 100,000 tonnes or more of GHGs per year will now be required to reduce their CO2 emissions intensity by 15 per cent in 2016 and 20 per cent by 2017. They will also have to ultimately pay $30 for every tonne of CO2 released over that level. Compliance mechanisms continue with the previous suite of options. The impacts to industry of what amounts to a new operating cost remain to be fully determined.

More change is coming.

Over the next three months, the University of Alberta's Andrew Leach will lead an advisory panel to review the province's climate strategy. Unlike in 2007, an assessment of GHG policy requires co-ordination with other jurisdictions. The Alberta government must be selective in its long-term climate-change initiatives. No current provincial model reflects the realities of navigating GHG restrictions in an oiland-gas dependant province. Nor are they perfect models in themselves. Both carbon tax and cap-and-trade methodologies add burdens for new oil and gas facilities and barriers to investment with high net present value costs.

The Specified Gas Emitters Regulation started to show its age. Alberta is still the single largest GHG emitting province in Canada. It permits higher annual emission levels than more recently implemented GHG regimes. Moreover, the value of Alberta's Specified Gas Emitters Regulation as a currency to advance the province's commercial interests abroad - in Washington on Keystone XL or Brussels on the EU Fuel Quality Directive - was long spent. The regulation was never fully understood in foreign capitals, let alone Ottawa.

The role of the federal government remains critical, albeit to date, limited. A 2013 "40/40 plan" - reducing emissions by 40 per cent per barrel of oil and charging companies exceeding emission limits a $40/tonne penalty - receded quickly. On May 15, 2015, Environment Minister Leona Aglukkaq announced a reduction in Canada's GHG emissions to 70 per cent of the 2005 Canada-wide levels by the year 2030 - without placing regulations on the oilsands. Canada's federal opposition parties are vague on what their approaches to climate change would be, and the results of an upcoming election uncertain.

Irrespective of which party is in power nationally, provinces' co-ordination on climate change must acknowledge Ottawa's role. Notley stated as much in last Monday's Speech from the Throne. A weakness of the Canadian Energy Strategy, a cornerstone of previous interprovincial engagement on GHG policy, was that it largely ignored the federal government. However, the premiers must also resist playing climate change politics with Ottawa.

From royalties to refineries, the Notley government is poised to substantially impact energy and environmental policy in Alberta and beyond its borders. A refreshed national engagement on climate change need not be a threat to the Alberta economy. A stable framework for GHG emissions - which many in the oil and gas industry themselves have asked for - may provide necessary clarity for investment and growth. It may also facilitate something more elusive, the social acceptance to develop pipeline infrastructure necessary for Canada to remain an international economic leader, rather than simply an energy superpower-in-waiting.

Neil McCrank Q.C., formerly chair of the Alberta Energy and Utilities Board, is counsel to Borden Ladner Gervais LLP. Alan L. Ross, formerly Alberta's provincial representative to Ottawa, is a partner with Borden Ladner Gervais LLP


NS

RE 
cana : Canada | caab : Alberta | ottaw : Ottawa | caon : Ontario | namz : North America

IPD 
News | summertime,alberta,change,climate,policy,messy

PUB 
National Post

AN 
Document FINP000020150626eb6q00048


SE Energy
HD IEA says peak in energy emissions by 2020 possible as oil demand plateaus
BY Yadullah Hussain
WC 754 words
PD 15 June 2015
SN Postmedia Breaking News
SC CWNS
LA English
CY Copyright © 2015 Canwest News Service

LP 

It could spell the end of an era. The International Energy Agency, which was hastily founded by developed oil-consuming countries back in the 1970s to keep an eye on global markets and ensure they never ran out of crude supplies, is now calling for new proposals that could see oil demand plateauing after 2020.

In the run up to the United Nations Climate Change Conference (COP 21), being held in December in Paris, the IEA is proposing four strategies to help transition to a de-carbonized world: ensuring carbon emissions peak by 2020, setting long-term emission targets, five-year reviews and establishing a process for tracking achievements in the energy sector.

TD 

With energy production accounting for two-thirds of the world's greenhouse-gas emissions, policymakers are training their sights on coal and crude oil production, leading to policies that could curtail investments in many fossil fuel developments including the oilsands.

"Any climate agreement reached at COP21 must have the energy sector at its core or risk being judged a failure," said IEA chief economist Fatih Birol in a statement. "Climate pledges submitted for COP21 are an important first step to meeting our climate goal, and our report shows that they will have a material impact on future energy trends."

The Paris-based agency believes that a peak in global energy-related emissions could be achieved as early as 2020 if governments implement five key policy measures - so-called "bridge scenarios" - that includes banning coal-fired power plants, raising investments in renewables to US$400 billion by 2030, from US$270 billion currently, phasing out energy subsidies for consumers, energy efficiency in transportation and buildings, and reducing methane emissions in oil and gas production.

"These measures have profound implications for the global energy mix, putting a brake on growth in oil and coal use within the next five years and further boosting renewables," said the IEA in an executive summary received by the Financial Post ahead of the report's full release Monday. "In the bridge scenario, coal use peaks before 2020 and then declines while oil demand rises to 2020 and then plateaus."

Related

Why would Big Oil champion a carbon tax? Experts say it's so companies don't get 'blindsided'( http://business.financialpost.com/news/energy/why-is-big-oil-championing-a-carbon-tax-experts-say-its-so-companies-dont-get-blindsided[http://business.financialpost.com/news/energy/why-is-big-oil-championing-a-carbon-tax-experts-say-its-so-companies-dont-get-blindsided] )

End of the oilsands by 2050? G7 puts Canada on the spot with target for low emissions( http://business.financialpost.com/news/energy/end-of-the-oilsands-by-2050-g7-puts-canada-on-the-spot-with-target-for-low-emissions?__lsa=5e19-2a63[http://business.financialpost.com/news/energy/end-of-the-oilsands-by-2050-g7-puts-canada-on-the-spot-with-target-for-low-emissions?__lsa=5e19-2a63] )

The major climate milestone is possible utilizing only proven technologies and policies, and without changing the economic and development prospects of any region, the energy watchdog states.

"As IEA analysis has repeatedly shown that the cost and difficulty of mitigating greenhouse-gas emissions increases every year, time is of the essence," said IEA executive director Maria van der Hoeven. "It is clear that the energy sector must play a critical role if efforts to reduce emissions are to succeed. While we see growing consensus among countries that it is time to act, we must ensure that the steps taken are adequate and that the commitments made are kept."

A number of countries including Canada have announced their intended nationally determined contributions (INDC) to rein in carbon emissions, but the goals fall short of the major course correction required to ensure global temperatures do not rise more than two degrees centigrade - a key environmental goal.

The biggest breakthrough would be to break the link between economic growth and GHG emissions. The IEA believes that the countries' current combined pledges would weaken but not break the link over the next two decades.

"If stronger action is not forthcoming after 2030, the path in the INDC Scenario would be consistent with an average temperature increase of around 2.6° C by 2100 and 3.5° C after 2200."

Last week, more than 100 North American scientists called for a moratorium on new oilsands development to limit climate warming, although the industry believes technological breakthroughs can help rein in emissions.

Many oil companies, including Royal Dutch Shell Plc., BP Plc. and Suncor Energy Inc. have recently called for a carbon tax in the hope of bringing cost certainty to their projects and social acceptance to an industry that is increasingly being demonized.


CO 
inenag : International Energy Agency

NS

IPD

SE City
HD Energy East pipeline to undergo BAPE study
CR The Gazette
WC 154 words
PD 9 June 2015
SN Montreal Gazette
SC MTLG
ED Early
PG A4
LA English
CY Copyright © 2015 Montreal Gazette

LP 

Quebec Environment Minister David Heurtel has finally mandated an environmental study of the Energy East pipeline project. The report by the Bureau d'audiences publiques sur l'environnement is due 60 days before the beginning of submissions to the National Energy Board regarding the pipeline.

A panel of experts will be formed by the end of June, followed by public hearings on the pipeline.

TD 

The investigation includes: Evaluating the impact of the pipeline on greenhouse gas emissions; consulting with local communities to gauge social acceptance of the project; ensuring TransCanada maintains high standards to protect the environment and Quebecers; and ensuring the company has the best possible emergency response system.

TransCanada is building new pipeline infrastructure and repurposing old lines to bring bitumen from oilsands in Alberta to refineries on the East Coast of Canada.

The report is expected by the end of 2015.


RE 
cana : Canada | caqc : Quebec | namz : North America

IPD 
News | quebec,environment,minister,david,heurtel,finally

PUB 
Montreal Gazette

AN 
Document MTLG000020150609eb6900017


SE Financial Post
HD Royalties as rent; Why hiking carbon levy, not royalty rates, could help solve Alberta's financial woes
BY Yadullah Hussain
CR Financial Post
WC 1348 words
PD 16 May 2015
SN National Post
SC FINP
ED National
PG FP6
LA English
CY (c) 2015 National Post . All Rights Reserved.

LP 

Rachel Notley's New Democratic Party brought the Progressive Conservatives' near-44-year rule in Alberta to an abrupt end with a platform that pledged to raise corporate taxes, review oil and gas royalties and cut greenhouse gas emissions.

But rather than tinkering with royalty rates and corporate taxes, some analysts say the new government should train its sights on bolstering the province's carbon pricing structure, a move that may offset some of the need for tax increases and repair the province's reputation as a carbonpolluter.

TD 

Under the Specified Gas Emitters Regulation, the province charges major emitters of greenhouse gases $15 per tonne, but the program has been criticized for not reining in carbon emissions or bringing in significant revenues for the province.

"How many times can you skin the cat?" said Jack Mintz, Palmer Chair, School of Public Policy at the University of Calgary. "Corporate tax increases, royalty increase and carbon tax are major hits, but the crucial one is the carbon one." "We have been supportive of moving towards a more effective carbon pricing," said Matt Horne, Pembina Institute's associate regional director. "That could be the cap and trade that Quebec has adopted and Ontario is moving towards, or the B.C. carbon tax model, which is the strongest example to look to."

Adopting a carbon-tax model may be easier to implement than adjusting the complex royalty regime and, in theory, could help the province gain social acceptance for pipelines with the added benefit of meeting the low-carbon fuel standards being implemented by many oil-importing regions.

The carrot of government backing pipelines may entice industry to endure the stick of higher carbon taxes. Although most oil and gas producers publicly balk at any notion of raising business costs amid a sustained price downturn, many companies have privately been working on the assumption that carbon levies could reach $40 per tonne - a figure the previous government had proposed in 2013, which is estimated to raise oilsands costs by $2 per barrel. The NDP platform states that as the government it would "lead on climate change" and phase out coal-fired electricity generation to reduce smog and greenhouse gas emissions.

"We need to look at all the options before us and then have a good, thorough conversation with other jurisdictions to talk about how this is all going to work together," Notley said this week on the idea of a carbon-tax, noting that a capand-trade scheme may not work for Alberta.

Changes in the royalty regimes, however, may be inherently more difficult and has the industry more fearful.

"When there is uncertainty in a regulatory regime, there is greater risk that capital will either stall or even start to flow out of that regime rather than into it," said Janice Buckingham, Calgary-based partner at Osler, Hoskin Harcourt LLP.

While Premier-elect Notley believes Alberta has the lowest royalty rates in the world, a comparison with other jurisdictions suggests otherwise. Similar to its Western Canada counterparts, Alberta's existing royalty regime is complex and operates on a sliding scale, sensitive to market prices, productivity, age and depth of wells drilled.

If Notley wants to implement a competitive royalty regime that escalates royalties as prices rise, "it's fair to say, the province has that," Buckingham noted.

The maximum royalty on Alberta's conventional oil is 40 per cent of net revenue, compared to British Columbia's 35 per cent; the natural gas upper limits net 35 per cent for Alberta and 27 per cent for B.C. For oilsands production, the current structure allows for recovery of extensive investment before a royalty of 25 per cent to 40 per cent is payable, compared to 37.1 per cent for Saskatchewan's mostly heavy oil. Including all taxes and royalties, Alberta nets 54 per cent from the oilsands, B.C. 43 per cent and Saskatchewan 50.2 per cent, according to School of Public Policy data. In Texas the total tax and royalty rate stands at 48.5 per cent.

Royalty rates hardly paint a complete picture of a jurisdiction's competitiveness.

"The important point from (the Alberta) industry's perspective is to look at the entirety of the economic rent that's charged by government to producers," Buckingham said. But Alberta has a unique selling point: Unlike B.C. and Saskatchewan, the oilsands offer the world's largest marketable oil reserve in the world, third in volume only to state-owned resources in Venezuela and Saudi Arabia. Once built, albeit at a higher cost than most jurisdictions, oilsands developments promise durable production for decades, unlike the easilyexhausted shale plays.

"To offer a fast-food analogy, Alberta might say: 'Yes, you are going to make less per unit and we are going to take more, but there is many more units to be made here," said Kenneth Green, senior director, natural resource studies at The Fraser Institute.

The Fraser Institute's annual Global Petroleum Survey ranks Alberta as the 16th most business-friendly jurisdiction in the world and Green expects the province's ranking to slide in the new survey out by the end of the year due to rising uncertainty on the government's policy. Notley has said the royalty review will go ahead in this term of her government, though the exact timing is uncertain.

"Other factors need to be considered in order to formulate a final conclusion on whether one jurisdiction is more viable than the other," said Torran Jolly, a Calgarybased tax partner at KPMG. "It is a hard analysis to do in isolation on one variable such as price, not taking away the fact the oilsands is the thirdlargest reserve in the world. However, we are challenged in Alberta's (lack of ) access to market."

Indeed, if the government is looking to charge a premium for companies to operate in the oilsands, the payback to the industry must be vociferous, rather than just a lukewarm, backing of pipelines. Instead, the NDP has questioned the importance of U.S.-focused Keystone XL pipeline and the Northern Gateway conduit to Asia, although has backed the west-to-east Energy East project. But the appointment of Brian Topp as chief of staff by Notley, may not inspire the industry with confidence given his critical view on pipelines.

The new government's efforts to raise revenues through higher corporate taxes could also backfire, if companies shift their profits to other lower-tax jurisdictions. If the NDP follows through with its pledge to raise corporate taxes to 12 per cent from 10 per cent, it would make Alberta a higher-tax jurisdiction than B.C., Ontario and Quebec.

"You don't have to move capital, machines and labour to shift profits to other provinces," said Mintz, as the companies will start orchestrating financial engineering to lower government take. "Some companies are planning to shift profits out of Alberta if the rate goes up to 12 per cent."

With Ottawa announcing Friday a promise to cut carbon emissions by 30 per cent by 2030, Notley may be in the sweet spot to drive her ambition to cut carbon emissions. "You can't keep piling them on," Pembina's Horne said of new taxes. "A carbon tax would result in less corporate tax being collected - and ensure Alberta remains competitive."

Financial Post yhussain@nationalpost.com Twitter.com/Yad_FPEnergy


ART 
Ben Nelms, Bloomberg News / Alberta's unique selling point is that its oilsands offer the world's largest marketable oil reserve, promising durable production for decades.; Andrew Barr, National Post / SOURCE: UNIVERSITY OF CALGARY SCHOOL OF PUBLIC POLICY; Ben Nelms, Bloomberg News / Alberta's unique selling point is that its oilsands offer the world's largest marketable oil reserve, promising durable production for decades. [NTNP_20150516_National_FP6_01_I001.jpg]; Andrew Barr, National Post / SOURCE: UNIVERSITY OF CALGARY SCHOOL OF PUBLIC POLICY [NTNP_20150516_National_FP6_01_I002.jpg];

calguv : University of Calgary

PUB
