HD *MKTOIL Energy Summary for Jan. 28, 2014
CR Stockwatch
WC 1369 words
PD 28 January 2014
SN Canada Stockwatch
SC CNSW
LA English
CY (c) 2014 Canjex Publishing Ltd.

LP 

Oil Summary (:*MKTOIL)

Tuesday January 28 2014 - Market Summary

TD 

by Stockwatch Business Reporter

West Texas Intermediate crude for March delivery added $1.55 to $97.27 on the New York Merc, while Brent for March added 68 cents to $107.37 (all figures in this para U.S.). Western Canadian Select traded at a discount of $18 to WTI ($79.27), unchanged. Natural gas for February added 15.8 cents to $5.00. The TSX energy index added 2.99 points to close at 270.50.

TransGlobe Energy Corp. (TGL) lost 54 cents to $8.28 on 737,700 shares. Investors were disappointed with the Egypt-focused company's year-end update, which showed lower year-over-year reserves, production decreases at the core West Gharib and West Bakr projects, and another abandoned well at South Alamein. TransGlobe blamed the reserve and production declines on poor exploration results and mechanical problems. The abandoned well, West Manar, was not much of a surprise. It was the second well of a two-well program and the first well, Taef No. 1, turned up dry. The wells cost TransGlobe a total of $4-million. The company remains interested in this area because Taef and West Manar are right next to the Boraq discovery, which could begin production in 2015, assuming the military moves its operations in the area and grants approval for development. TransGlobe expects Boraq will eventually add 8,000 to 10,000 barrels a day to the company's total output. Year-to-date production is 19,000 barrels a day.

During a conference call this morning, TransGlobe's management said 2013 proved too difficult for reserve additions, but the company is "now moving at full speed" and expects to make up for it in 2015. It has tweaked its production guidance to account for potential delays in bringing projects on stream. For example, both Boraq and Northwest Gharib were forecast to start production in 2014, but those have been pushed back by a year. Still, the overall goal of doubling production to 40,000 barrels a day in 2018 is unchanged, and management had another carrot to dangle: It has started a financial review "to confirm that the company is in a position to initiate a sustainable dividend." It will make a final decision after it reviews its financial statements on March 4. If it does start a dividend, said management, it would probably be a quarterly dividend effective March 31.

Canacol Energy Ltd. (CNE) added 46 cents to $6.96 on 1.06 million shares. Its Mono Arana 2 appraisal well in Colombia's Middle Magdalena Valley has found 244 feet of net oil pay in the Lisama formation. It has not tested the well yet, but by comparison, the Mono Arana 1 well found 85 feet of net oil pay and tested at 1,242 barrels of oil a day. Canacol's goal is to finish five more Mono Arana wells by June, with expected production of 6,000 barrels of oil a day (2,400 net). These wells are targeting shallow conventional resources. The Middle Magdalena Valley is also prospective for deeper shale -- in fact, Canacol refers to it as Colombia's "shale oil sweet spot" -- but those are harder to bring on production. The Mono Arana 1 well, for example, found 230 feet of pay in the deeper La Luna formation, so Canacol and joint venturer ExxonMobil decided to re-enter the well specifically to test La Luna. Results were expected in mid- to late 2013, then December, and now the first quarter. The Oso Pardo 1 well, another attempt at targeting deeper shale, failed to penetrate La Luna because of mechanical problems.

Bankers Petroleum Ltd. (BNK) added eight cents to $4.37 to 4.94 million shares. Much of the volume came from TD Securities, which crossed 2.85 million shares at $4.31 this morning. The company seems to have created a feel-good documentary about its activities in Albania. Yesterday, a YouTube user called Albania Oilfield uploaded an hour-long video (which happens to be this user's only video) called "Bankers Petroleum -- Patos Marinza," in Albanian but with English subtitles. The documentary is filled with workers, executives and locals alike praising the Patos-Marinza heavy oil field and Bankers' ever-valiant efforts to hire plenty of locals, clean and protect the environment, and provide social services from schools to bridges. The film is light on details of future plans. President and chief executive officer David French does say he plans to increase production by 15 per cent every year, and he can easily imagine Patos-Marinza's output doubling to 40,000 barrels of oil a day. Chief operating officer Suneel Gupta said that in the next few years, as production increases, Bankers will focus on expanding the export market. All of the oil currently goes to the Mediterranean, but Mr. Gupta wants to start looking at Asia and even the United States. The film's narrator concludes: "Bankers Petroleum Albania today is the leader in the oil industry in the country. The giant of the Albanian underground is awake." In the last few seconds of the credits, the text "Bankers Petroleum Albania Ltd. Copyright 2013" appears. The film was produced by an Albania-based ad agency called SourceOne. Both Bankers and SourceOne are members of the Canada-Albania Business Council, along with other Canadian companies such as Stream Oil & Gas Ltd. (SKO: $0.60), Petromanas Energy Inc. (PMI: $0.14) and miner Tirex Resources Ltd. (TXX).

The friendly film is well timed. Last week, local news outlets reported that state-owned Albpetrol and the ministry of energy are accusing Bankers of illegally selling low-quality diluent in the domestic market without paying taxes. They are basing this on the increased amount of diluent the company has been importing. Bankers denies this and says all of the diluent is used for licensed operations, namely underground injection to dilute the heavy oil and make it easier to pump out. The increased amount of imported diluent has to do with the increased level of production, which was 19,300 barrels of oil a day in the fourth quarter. It is unlikely that the accusations will go anywhere.

Pipeline hysteria: This afternoon, about 100 protesters paraded a 91-metre inflatable pipeline around the Capitol ahead of Barack Obama's State of the Union speech tonight. The pipeline was emblazoned with: "Pipeline President or Climate Champion? NO KXL," in reference to TransCanada Corp.'s (TRP: $48.38) Keystone XL. They chanted, "Get up, get down, keep fossil fuels in the ground," and accused the pipeline of "terrorizing our planet and our people." The protesters "aren't holding their breadth [sic] waiting for a mention of Keystone XL," according to 350.org's press release -- the President did not say anything about it in last year's address, although he said "energy" 18 times -- so today's antics seemed more about grabbing attention than anything else. Gimmicks are always a good strategy, as the Skwomesh Action group can attest. It held an event in Delta two days ago to help the Unist'ot'en camp oppose basically every development proposal in the B.C. Interior and most of Alberta. To drive traffic, it offered gluten-free pancakes and mimosas made with organic juice.

Enbridge Inc. (ENB: $46.59) had some tentatively good news. A joint B.C.-Alberta working group has prepared a report on moving Western Canadian oil and gas to Asian markets. The document is marked "strictly confidential," but was released to B.C. and Alberta reporters yesterday. It talks of developing "broad social acceptance" of projects and also sets out some preliminary recommendations and milestones for the next 18 months. The recommendations stem from the five conditions B.C. has put on its acceptance of Northern Gateway. Alberta Energy Minister Diane McQueen told the Canadian Press that some of the suggestions in the report will help meet those conditions. The report estimates that Canada is losing out on $50-million a day in potential revenue by not having pipelines to carry product to Asia.


CO 
dumac : Transglobe Energy Corp

SE Business
HD B.C.-Alberta report on oil exports sees progress ahead on key issues; ‘Ultimately, the work being done today will help us to fulfill our shared commitment to create jobs, stimulate long-term growth and to position Canada as a true energy superpower,’ report says
BY KELLY CRYDERMAN
WC 572 words
PD 27 January 2014
SN The Globe and Mail (Breaking News)
SC GMBN
LA English
CY ©2014 The Globe and Mail Inc. All Rights Reserved.

LP 

CALGARY --

A joint British Columbia-Alberta government working group focused on getting Western Canadian oil and natural gas to Asian markets says progress on issues such as spill prevention, First Nations engagement and sharing the economic benefits will come this year or early next, according to a report prepared for Premiers Christy Clark and Alison Redford.

TD 

The document – marked as “strictly confidential” but released to reporters in B.C. and Alberta on Monday – speaks mostly in broad generalities about the work to date and provides little in the way of specific plans. But it does lay out some timelines for progress, guiding principles, plans for creating a “world-class” marine and terrestrial spill regime, and notes the two provinces need to enter into negotiations with Ottawa regarding the “financing” for the infrastructure improvements to highways, ports and airports needed to gain access to Asia-Pacific markets.

The report talks about developing “broad social acceptance” of projects by being more responsive to those with environmental concerns, using tools such as social media and addressing “misinformation” about natural resource sector growth. It reiterates that Alberta’s oil and gas royalties are not on the table for negotiation when it comes to getting economic benefits to British Columbians, but the B.C. government has the right to negotiate with industry.

“Ultimately, the work being done today will help us to fulfill our shared commitment to create jobs, stimulate long-term growth and to position Canada as a true energy superpower,” said the December report.

Public concern in B.C. over the safety and environmental risks of oil-sands pipelines – particularly spills on land or off the West Coast – prompted Ms. Clark in 2012 to lay out five conditions related to the environment, First Nations consultation and financial benefits in order to support oil-pipeline development in the province.

In November, 2013, Ms. Clark and Alberta’s Ms. Redford said their two provinces had reached a framework for an agreement to satisfy B.C.’s demands, and had established a joint working group to work out the details. In the December report from public servants in both provinces, the document said the benefits of the oil and gas industry extends to all Canadians but B.C. faces “risks” that Alberta does not.

Of particular concern to B.C. residents is the proposed 1,177-kilometre Northern Gateway pipeline. If built, the Enbridge Inc. pipeline would bring oil-sands bitumen to Kitimat, B.C., from Bruderheim, Alta. In December, an independent body mandated by the federal Environment Minister and the National Energy Board – the joint review panel – gave a conditional green light to the project. That recommendation will inform a federal cabinet decision to come in the first half of this year as to whether to give final approval to the project.

However, it was only last May that the B.C. government formally rejected the proposed 525,000-barrel-a-day pipeline, telling the federal panel conducting hearings on the project that the company has failed to adequately explain how to deal with a major heavy oil spill on land or in coastal waters.

Globe and Mail Update

CLM RESOURCES
SE Report on Business: Canadian
HD Quebec uranium fight intensifies; Strateco petitions Quebec court to force approval of mine opposed by Cree community
BY JORDAN FLETCHER
WC 508 words
PD 10 December 2013
SN The Globe and Mail
SC GLOB
PG B6
LA English
CY ©2013 The Globe and Mail Inc. All Rights Reserved.

LP 

The battle over uranium mining in northern Quebec is heating up again.

Strateco Resources Inc. petitioned a Quebec court on Dec. 5, seeking to force the province's environmental minister to allow underground uranium exploration at the company's Matoush project, located in the Otish mountains 200 kilometres northeast of Mistissini.

TD 

Quebec's Minister of Sustainable Development, the Environment, Wildlife and Parks had denied Strateco's permit on Nov. 7 after the local Mistissini Cree community refused to consent to uranium development near its hunting grounds and trap lines.

“Many Cree work in the mining industry; we are not anti-development,” said Cree Grand Chief Matthew Coon Come.

“But uranium is a special case. The tailings will remain toxic for hundreds of thousands of years. It is a burden for future generations that we are not prepared to assume.”

Strateco's CEO, Guy Herbert, said the Matoush project is crucial to the development of the company's assets in northern Quebec. He estimated that the project could produce 30 million pounds of some of the highest-grade uranium in the world – worth roughly $1.7-billion at current market prices – and channel $800-million to Quebec over 10 years.

He said the company has invested almost $125-million in the project since 2006 and obtained 22 different permits from the environmental ministry. He said the authorization at issue now would be the final hurdle in its protracted fight to move the project forward.

“We have the law on our side,” Mr. Herbert said. “This is public land. …We have the right in Quebec to mine uranium.”

But the Cree view Strateco's legal wrangling as a last-ditch attempt to undermine their rights under the James Bay and Northern Quebec Agreement of 1975.

While the Matoush project is located on provincial territory, its disposition still requires Cree consultation under the treaty, said lawyer for the Cree, Jessica Orkin of Sack Goldblatt Mitchell in Toronto.

The treaty also created an elaborate environmental review process, the first of its kind in Canada, and the minister must consider a number of factors, including both Cree input and the rights of resource developers, in approving any mining projects under its jurisdiction.

The minister's Nov. 7 decision stated that the lack of social acceptance by the local Cree communities was “obvious and determinative” in denying Strateco's permit.

Strateco has maintained that its interests and prior investments were ignored. It will be back in court on Jan. 24, 2014 to argue its motion.

Whatever happens there, Mr. Herbert said the company doesn't intend to walk away from Matoush. “If the court decides against us, we will seek damages and lost profits for our investors.”

Uranium is used as a fuel in the production of nuclear energy. Mr. Herbert expects the demand for nuclear energy will only grow. “This is the time to develop uranium mines,” he said.


CO 
srscsi : Strateco Resources Inc | altvst : Advantage Link Inc

IN

RE

PUB 
The Globe and Mail Inc.

AN 
Document GLOB000020131210e9ca00014


CLM Vaughn Palmer
SE Editorial
HD Provinces' pipeline push faces many obstacles; Working together: B.C. and Alberta's joint effort to pump Northern Gateway may be too little, too late
BY Vaughn Palmer
CR Vancouver Sun
WC 946 words
PD 6 December 2013
SN Vancouver Sun
SC VNCS
ED Final
PG A16
LA English
CY Copyright © 2013 Vancouver Sun

LP 

Before year-end, B.C. Premier Christy Clark and Alberta Premier Alison Redford are scheduled to receive the report of a joint working group on the movement of heavy oil through this province to the coast.

The working group, staffed with senior public servants from both provinces, was established last summer in a bid to harmonize policy-making between the two governments and put paid to the breach that preceded the recent B.C. election.

TD 

Prime goals: "Opening new markets and expanding export opportunities for oil, gas and other resources. Creating jobs and strengthening the economy of each province and Canada through the development of the oil and gas sector."

Deliverables: "Increased liaison with Alberta on pipeline projects moving heavy oil and/or oil byproducts through B.C. Working with other government agencies, cies, provincially and federally, to ensure the B.C. and Alberta goals are met. Common co-ordinated communication."

Terms of reference, released in October, established five working teams under assistant deputy ministers Al Sanderson from Alberta and B.C.'s Fazil Mihlar (until recently The Vancouver Sun's associate editor).

One team is charged with smoothing over the main source of the earlier breach, namely dark suspicions that B.C. was seeking a cut of the royalties Alberta collects on the provincial oil resource.

Big misunderstanding, ing, according to the terms of reference: "It is not about royalty sharing but rather about receiving a fair share of the economic and fiscal benefits of a proposed fis-heavy oil project that reflects the levels, degree and nature of the risk borne by B.C., the environment and taxpayers."

With that in mind, the fiscal and economic team has been instructed to: "Establish the range of views on the fiscal and economic benefits relative to the costs and risks borne by each province; identify potential means and mechanisms that would create an equitable sharing of fiscal and economic benefits that reflect the costs and risks resulting from the projects; and define next steps in developing a strategy for enacting the appropriate mechanisms."

Not much doubt that it is mainly up to B.C. to figure out how to secure a piece of the action, probably by tapping the companies with a levy on pipelines or oil exports.

Joint progress is more likely from the team working on the most cost-effective and least risky method for transporting Alberta oil through B.C. "If pipelines are not developed, rail will step into the void to deliver bitumen to the West Coast," declared the terms of reference in an unmistakable warning to the no-pipelines branch of the no-growth crowd.

The transportation working team has been directed to compile an inventory of port, rail, road, and other infrastructure improvements needed to expedite the delivery of heavy oil and other energy resources to tidewater.

A third working team is dedicated to the well-worked-over territory of oil spills, on land and at sea. To minimize duplication, the team is expected to co-ordinate with existing federal and provincial efforts to minimize risks and beef up resources for cleaning up spills when they happen.

The terms of reference suggest that marine spills could be better handled by "a unified command and incidence response structure" based on the one already in place in the U.S. Land spills would benefit from a "harmonization" between Alberta and B.C., including establishment of industryfunded resources that would be available for quick response and cleanup in either jurisdiction.

A fourth team is tackling "social licence" - namely, what it will take to engage the public and

build support. Suggested areas to explore: "Define engagement in the context of the projects; identify key areas that need to be addressed and continually maintained in order to develop broad social acceptance of the projects; and define next steps for developing a strategy that could address key areas that have been identified."

Given the head start seized by opponents of the proposed Enbridge Northern Gateway pipeline, I wouldn't bet the engagement team will meet with much success.

Plus there's the no-less formidable obstacle to success poised by the mandate for the fifth working team, "developing a strategy for engaging First Nations." To which I would add: "at this late date."

Though Alberta and B.C. pledge to work together on an approach to First Nations, the terms of reference acknowledge that in one important respect they are far apart: "Alberta is covered by a series of numbered treaties that reduce some of the complexity faced by B.C." Alberta has flexibility in its dealings with First Nations; B.C. has no choice but to engage each affected First Nation in depth.

Not likely will the working group and its five subsidiary teams be able to do much to improve the odds of success for Northern Gateway. But there is also the proposal to twin the existing Kinder Morgan pipeline, which is expected to move to the formal application stage later this month.

As for the working group, it is expected to deliver up a report to the respective premiers by Dec. 31, including recommendations and an action plan "that may be considered for implementation." Note the word "may." While the mere existence of the working group shows relations are on the mend between B.C. and Alberta, it is too soon to say whether they will ever be on the same page on pipelines and petroleum.

vpalmer@vancouversun.com


NS

cana : Canada | namz : North America

IPD 
Column

PUB 
Vancouver Sun

AN

HD Gaining Public Trust For Large-Scale Projects Not An Easy Feat
BY By Paul Wells
WC 2759 words
PD 20 November 2013
SN The Daily Oil Bulletin
SC DOILB
LA English
CY (c)2013 copyright Junewarren-Nickle’s Energy Group. All rights reserved

LP 

The oil and gas industry's ability to gain public and social acceptance on the grassroots level for large-scale infrastructure projects that are required to gain access to new markets remains compromised, as opposition groups continue to win the public relations battle and often use delay as their tactic of choice.

And while proponents of the various proposed LNG and pipeline projects that would allow producers to ship product from Canada's West Coast work hard at leveling the playing field through education and science, the task is daunting as emotive sound bites from opponents often capture the ear of the public over companies' technical approach.

TD 

Ian Anderson, president of Kinder Morgan Canada, which is proposing a $5.4-billion expansion to the Trans Mountain crude oil pipeline to the West Coast, says the project is a prime example of the new reality that companies face in their efforts to gain a social licence to operate and put pipe in the ground.

"The project we're embarking upon is really the completion of a phased expansion of the system. In 2008 we completed the first phase, which was expanding through Jasper National Park and Mount Robson Provincial Park, which are two World UNESCO Heritage Sites," he says.

"We completed that late in 2008, which is not even five years ago, and there was nowhere near the debate, controversy, opposition and the media coverage we're seeing today. That's what we're seeing today, so in a five-year time-frame things have changed dramatically."

Michal Moore, an energy economics professor with the University of Calgary's School of Public Policy, says the tactics being used by environmental groups and other opponents continue to evolve as their efforts to stymie the advancements of infrastructure projects ramp-up.

"The evolution of the tools that opposition groups are using are all based around delay, distortion of information and the repetition of that distortion," he says.

"Ask yourself how rapidly a false or misleading statement ... makes it around when it's disseminated through social media? You can have a false statement that gets repeated so often that it becomes a truth -- and assumed truth [in the public realm] -- in literally minutes," Moore adds.

"The changes seem to me to have occurred in large measure because of the impact of repeating lies and distortions or misinformation, including misunderstood information or data. The approach to this is to vulcanize decision-making and do it in such a way that projects can't get critical mass and, as a consequence, they die."

Peter Tertzakian, chief energy economist at ARC Financial Corp., agrees that the landscape for social acceptance and support of energy projects continues to change with more pressure being placed on companies to justify the benefit-versus-risk component.

"It's much different than five years ago. Five years ago the issue of social licence was taken care of by the National Energy Board [NEB] and there was a lot more trust in our institutions," Tertzakian says.

"Today, the NEB, which was supposed to be the custodian of social licence on behalf of Canadians, seems to be marginalized and the onus regarding the social licence issue is now on the industry to justify what they are trying to do."

The changing times

When the Canadian Society for Unconventional Resources (CSUR) started out about a decade ago its main focus was facilitating and enabling technology transfer and dialogue between its members, as well as public education efforts, though not to the degree seen today.

But with political and public concern about coalbed methane development in the early- to mid-2000s, and then the early days of horizontal drilling and multi-stage fracturing later in the decade, the group's role started to change.

"The issues didn't just come up from the regulatory bodies, we heard the same questions at our stakeholder engagement sessions. It started out where you would have 10 landowners that were concerned about what was happening, to 20 or 30 or more in a session -- the scope was getting bigger," says CSUR executive vice-president Dan Allan.

He says the context of those discussions started changing dramatically, especially when industry started exploiting shale gas and tight oil plays, whether it be concern about large-scale horizontal drilling and multi-stage fracturing programs or the infrastructure required to move product to tidewater facilities.

"It morphed from just the stakeholder being interested -- the guy directly affected -- to the public at large being interested because they were now concerned about the size and scope, they were concerned about the industry's credibility, because maybe they heard about a pipeline break in the U.S. and therefore the whole industry had to be called into question," Allan says.

"This was a level of scrutiny we've never seen before. There's almost been a new industry created in North America of environmental groups, watchdog groups, social media groups -- anyone who's looking at anything that may or may not fit in their estimation -- and they've got the money and the passion for their efforts," he adds.

"You can't fault anyone for asking questions, but I think it's more than that now. The levels of miscommunication are just staggering.... This intense scrutiny, probably driven by social media, has made industry's job very, very difficult."

Gary Leach, president of the Explorers and Producers Association of Canada (EPAC), says that some sophisticated opponents, many of whom are not directly affected by a particular project, want to use the public review process to delay or derail oil and gas development projects.

"We think that projects can still undergo a world-class review without sacrificing timeliness and certainty and we have delivered this message to the Alberta government too," he notes

Leach adds that it is difficult to explain complex issues -- particularly the trade-offs that have to be made -- to find a reasonable balance among the social, economic and environmental issues raised by oil and gas development and infrastructure projects.

"Too often, the general news media fails this basic role and repeatedly demonstrates how easily it is willing to be distracted by well-choreographed protesters, such as those who recently blocked the doors to the NEB hearings in Montreal on the Enbridge Inc. crude oil line reversal," he says.

"Individual corporations and associations have responded with sizeable public advertising campaigns. Even the federal government is getting into this advocacy marketplace with a recently announced multimillion-dollar advertising campaign to promote the oilsands."

Tertzakian says industry has come out of the denial phase and has recognized the need to increase efforts to gain public trust.

"That's not to diminish the efforts that have already been made, but there is a greater recognition that you can't just do the application for social licence at the corporate level, the government level -- going to Ottawa for what I'll call 'suit-to-suit' combat," he says.

"That's not where the exclusive focus has to be now. It's on the ground, engaging with the communities and telling them what they're doing and working hard at making the public understand the process," Tertzakian adds.

"This is where there still is a great deficiency, but I do think there are many companies that are starting to get it and act successfully on it. But boy, there's a lot of work to do."

Leach says that one idea that the upstream and midstream industries are looking at to bolster public support for energy development is continuous improvement in industry performance in areas that directly impact public perception, for example safety and environment.

"We all know in this day and age that a single incident anywhere in North America by an oil and gas producer, a pipeline operator or a rail car company can negatively impact the reputation of the entire industry," Leach says.

"The Canadian pipeline industry has recently introduced its own program backed up by an advertising campaign to inform the public in key markets. Organizations like the Canadian Standards Association are interested in expanding their involvement with the oil and gas industry in this area and EPAC and others in the upstream sector are looking at the concept of 'standardization' to see what aspects may be applicable to our highly diverse and complex upstream industry."

Corporate leaders need to step up

Tertzakian believes one component that is currently lacking is the resolve of high-level corporate leaders to take a more hands-on approach to the grassroots dialogue that occurs as projects go through the process of gaining a social licence to operate.

"There aren't enough -- I can only really think of one [Kinder Morgan's Anderson] -- CEOs and industry leaders that are willing to stand up and show their face, make statements publically and go and interact in communities like Kitimat on a routine basis," he says.

"They have a tendency to send foot soldiers out. When I first started out [in the early 1980s], the champions of the industry were not shy to speak up and stand up and be advocates. It's hard to think of many industry leaders that are leading the charge of being an advocate."

Anderson views public engagement as a vital part of his job, a situation he says has changed over the years and one that will continue to evolve.

"Whether it was the upstream producers or the pipelines, we have kind of come out of a decade or two of focusing on attracting capital, deploying resources and maximizing production capabilities and all of that goes with technological improvement and access to labour and so forth," Anderson says.

"Facing the public is not something the producers were doing a decade ago in a large way and certainly not what the pipelines were doing. That has fundamentally changed," he adds.

"I think I recognized some years ago that I was not going to rely upon consultants and staff to go into the hard corners. We need to, as an industry, go into the tough corners -- you don't always win in the offensive zone, you need a good defensive game, too."

Anderson notes that the "tough corners" include interaction at the municipal level with local elected officials, First Nations communities and even opponents of a project.

"I think we need to go to all of those places to get a full appreciation of what the issues are. I always say all issues are local, politics are local and in many respects all benefits can be defined locally," he says.

"That's when you appreciate what's important to the people whose lives you're impacting. And if you're not investing the time there, I don't think you're fully understanding and appreciating what you can do to make a difference."

Chris Theal, head of Calgary-based Kootenay Capital Management Corp., says progress is being made as industry continues its efforts to improve stakeholder and public engagement.

"On the LNG front, I think you're starting to see the right things. You need the federal and provincial government, the First Nations and the companies all under one roof talking about the fiscal equation and the environmental equation. If everyone under that tent can get aboard, then it works," Theal says.

"I think with Northern Gateway and Keystone XL, it's been a reactionary process. I think that's the key -- you have to get everyone in a room and find an economic, environmental and social solution that works for everyone."

Delay of game

In a report released in October 2012, the Fraser Institute pointed out the many non-economic factors that are front and centre in the debate, and contribute to the snail's pace of moving projects forward to the decision-making phase.

"British Columbia could benefit greatly by exporting LNG to the Asia-Pacific Region. However, opposition by special-interest groups, out-dated, cumbersome, and overlapping regulations, along with other non-market factors, are inhibiting the development of the pipelines and terminal facilities required to ship LNG from Canada's West Coast to Japan, Korea, China, India, and other Asian countries," said the authors of the report, Gerry Angevine and Vanadis Oviedo.

However the report, called Laying the Groundwork for B.C. LNG Exports to Asia, noted that existing outdated regulatory processes and procedures, unnecessary duplication of federal and provincial government project reviews, and an unwieldy environmental review process could impede the timely development of a Canadian LNG export industry.

"If the federal and B.C. governments believe it is important to secure a niche for British Columbia's gas resources in the Asia-Pacific market, they should consider introducing reforms to streamline the regulatory approval process and thereby expedite development," the authors say.

CSUR's Allan agrees, adding that prolonged delays in the regulatory process can compromise the "window of opportunity" for projects to succeed.

"So if you are a group opposed to development of fossil fuels, all you have to do is delay. That's a huge advantage -- they don't have to stop it, they just have to delay it," he says.

"I just think that democracy has seemed to have lost its way. It used to be we had a simplistic society where if you had 100 people in a small village and you get 60 to agree, that was it. Today we can get 60 per cent and it doesn't mean anything."

The U of C's Moore says that anti-petroleum special interest groups are often masters at clogging up the regulatory process and, as a result, forcing delays.

"There's a history of the interest groups forcing a public agency or a public review body to look and say, 'You know what, maybe we should take another look.' It emboldens splinter groups to come in and carve off a point of view that's not necessarily in the broad public interest -- they are basically destroying the idea of the majority prevailing," Moore says, pointing to the failed Mackenzie Valley pipeline, and the current status of the Keystone XL pipeline to the U.S. Gulf Coast, as examples.

"It's a vulcanization that is not designed around finding the best and most coherent public policy or public investment in infrastructure, it's a negative approach that wins by stalling or throwing up impossible barriers or by diverting attention."

The regulatory dilemma

The industry in Canada, no doubt, doesn't want to miss the boat of opportunity in relation to improving export opportunities, especially to the Asia-Pacific region and the growing economies, and respective increased energy demand, of some countries in that region.

But to move projects forward and seize that opportunity in a timely fashion, Moore contends it's going to take a concerted effort by both industry and government to gain the trust and confidence of a wary Canadian populace.

"How do we get there? We improve energy literacy and we insist on egalitarian decisions and opinions by regulators and policymakers and get government to act responsibly and consistently," he says.

"The last part of the puzzle, one I know my friends in the environmental community don't like, is that we need rules and procedures that are religiously adhered to. That means you cannot use the regulatory arena for policy decisions," Moore adds.

"It's not fair, it slows things down and it makes the job of trying to render a decision about an infrastructure project almost impossible. Somehow we need to empower our regulators to actually do their job and not to allow the regulatory arena to be used as a forum for policy decisions."

EPAC's Leach agrees that a tightening of the regulatory process is a must.

"It's well known that after the abuses by some non-government organizations of the Northern Gateway hearings the federal government changed the rules on who is appropriately allowed to participate in NEB hearings. This has not made activists happy and one well-funded U.S.-based group has challenged these restrictions, first applied in the Enbridge Line 9 reversal application, in court as violating the Charter of Rights," he says.

"Alberta is grappling with similar issues as it introduces new rules for public participation in the regulatory review process and aboriginal consultation process. We are deeply concerned that the resulting rules do not overlook industry's need for fair, thorough but timely and efficient review of project applications."

Junewarren-Nickle’s Energy Group

SE OnLine
HD 'We have to talk about it': Some doctors angered by CMA refusal to wade into euthanasia debate
BY Sharon Kirkey
WC 1202 words
PD 21 August 2013
SN Postmedia Breaking News
SC CWNS
LA English
CY Copyright © 2013 Canwest News Service

LP 

This country's leading doctors' group has voted against wading into the debate about doctor-assisted death - drawing accusations from some of its members that they are burying their heads in the sand on an issue of profound importance to Canadians.

Delegates to the annual general meeting of the Canadian Medical Association (CMA) on Wednesday voted against a motion urging all levels of government to hold public hearings into "medical aid in dying."

TD 

Some doctors argued that it would be premature to call for nationwide public hearings when doctors themselves haven't decided whether they would be willing to participate in helping their patients end their lives, while others said it wasn't clear exactly what "medical aid in dying" means.

Others were visibly exasperated.

"I have a bit of a problem understanding the attitude of my colleagues from other provinces regarding what's going on with this issue," said Dr. Ruth Vander-Stelt, from Gatineau, Que. "Canadian physicians outside Quebec do not want to talk about this issue of medical aid in dying. We can't talk about it. You have to shut your ears, shut your eyes and shut up," she said.

Vander-Stelt said she has her own "conscientious objection" towards a proposed Quebec law that would permit aid in dying for patients experiencing incurable and irreversible illness and suffering.

"Society is waking up - it's coming. We have to talk about it," she said.

The debate was so contentious, delegates couldn't reach agreement on the wording or language, referring a motion to replace "physician-assisted suicide" with "physician-assisted death" on all future communications from the doctors' group to the board of directors.

One doctor argued the word "suicide" can provoke the same negative emotions as "abortion" and "rape."

However, Dr. Robin Saunders, outgoing chair of the CMA's ethics committee, said it is time doctors "call a spade a spade."

"Medical aid in dying is, in fact, euthanasia," he said. "That is the term we should be using."

Canada's Criminal Code makes it an offence to counsel, aid or abet another person to commit suicide, punishable by up to 14 years in prison.

Federal Health Minister Rona Ambrose said this week that the government has no intention of reopening the debate. Nine private members bills seeking to decriminalize doctor-assisted suicide have all been defeated.

But recent court cases, the proposed Quebec law and a rapidly aging population confronting its own mortality are pushing the issue into the public conscience.

"The baby boomer generation is starting to reach this inevitable crossroads in their lives," Saunders said. "This cohort - perhaps more than any other - is used to having control.

"Should physicians remain steadfastly committed to one of the most fundamental tenets of ethical practice - namely, to respect the value of human life, and not actively participate in (physician-assisted death) and euthanasia - or does the physician have the moral responsibility to relieve suffering even if by doing so death is hastened?"

Dr. Pierre Harvey, of Riviere-du-Loup, Que., said the CMA's mandate is to be leaders in health care.

"Give me one good reason why, as leaders, we should not confront this inevitable question that has to be discussed everywhere in Canada? On what basis can we refuse to undertake a consultation on something so basic as this?"

Although the issues are highly emotionally charged and sensitive, "it's undeniable that social acceptance of this is increasing," said Dr. Laurent Marcoux, president of the Quebec Medical Association. A 2013 survey found 86 per cent of Quebecers are in favour of medical aid in dying, he said.

Incoming CMA president Dr. Louis Hugo Francescutti said doctors are not ducking the issue.

"As someone who just lost their mom, this is an issue that's near and dear to my heart," the Edmonton emergency physician said.

"I don't think we ducked. What physicians do when they're not sure is pause and reflect and ask for consultation."

In another motion, delegates supported a doctor's right to exercise "conscientious objection" when faced with a request for doctor-assisted death, should the practice be legalized in Canada.

Ottawa physician Dr. Lee Donohue said many patients ask for her "aid, assistance, support and expertise in helping them to die, and their families ask me to do the same.

"For times in which they're asking me to do what I don't feel is in their best interest, or what I can't do, we talk about it."

The federal government is appealing a B.C. court ruling that struck down Canada's ban on doctor-assisted suicide, ruling it unconstitutional. The case is likely to reach the Supreme Court of Canada.

A 2011 survey of 16,000 CMA members found that 38 per cent of doctors believe that assisted suicide should remain outlawed, while 34 per cent think it should be legalized. "We are a split profession," Saunders said.

Dr. Doris Barwich, of the Canadian Society of Palliative Care Physicians, said two-thirds of the presentations to the Quebec national assembly were against medical aid in dying.

"There's a substantive body of literature and a lot of opinion around undoing 2,000 years of medical history and our oath," she said.

"It's like cutting down an old growth forest - once you've gone a certain direction you can never can come back."

The CMA represents 76,000 doctors in Canada.

In other resolutions Wednesday, doctors condemned owners about the violence in the National Hockey League. In 2011, Montreal Canadiens forward Max Pacioretty suffered a fractured vertebra and concussion following a violent check by Boston Bruins captain Zdeno Chara. Pittsburgh Penguins' Sidney Crosby was sidelined for a year from concussions.

"It's not just professional sport," said outgoing CMA president Dr. Anna Reid. "We want to signal to young players that it's not OK to deliberately take your stick and hit someone over the head."

"We speak on behalf of Canadians, we speak on behalf of our patients. When we speak out to prevent serious injuries that are intentional, I think people stand up and listen," Reid said.

Francescutti said he regularly sees emergency patients with concussions and other hockey-related injuries. "Violence (in hockey) needs to be addressed. Don Cherry might disagree with me. But it's not an inherent part of the game," he said. "Anytime the goal is to send someone out on the ice to purposely hurt someone else, how could we support something like that?

"In spite of the public trying to get the NHL to take this issue seriously, they've haven't. Maybe if the CMA lends its voice to it then the NHL will take this a little more seriously."

Delegates also supported a ban on the sale of energy drinks to youth below the legal drinking age as well as restricting the sale of sugary, high-calorie foods in sports and recreational facilities.

skirkey@postmedia.com( mailto:skirkey@postmedia.com )

twitter.com/sharon_kirkey( http://twitter.com/sharon_kirkey[http://twitter.com/sharon_kirkey] )

SE Business
HD U.S. shale oil boom could re-write the Canadian economy’s oil story; New supplies are a long-term wild card for global prices and the battle for market share – and that may change energy’s role in Canada’s economic future
BY CLÉMENT GIGNAC
WC 959 words
PD 7 June 2013
SN The Globe and Mail (Breaking News)
SC GMBN
LA English
CY ©2013 The Globe and Mail Inc. All Rights Reserved.

LP 

As a net commodities exporter, Canada has benefited from strong energy prices over the past decade. Indeed, the surging terms of trade (export prices relative to import prices) have stimulated corporate investment and job creation across the country, particularly in the Western provinces. Reflecting the importance of natural resources in the Canadian stock market benchmark, the S&P/TSX has outperformed its U.S. counterpart seven times in the past 10 years.

But with the U.S. shale oil boom underway, are we headed toward a game changer for Canadian terms of trade and economic prosperity?

TD 

Shale oil: A “shock wave” on global oil trade, according to the IEA

Remember peak oil theory? The members of this club argued that global crude oil supplies have peaked and entered an irreversible long-term decline, setting the table for permanently elevated oil prices. The concept didn’t account for, or at least underestimated, the impact of technological innovation fostered by rising energy prices. That’s what recently happened to natural gas prices in North America, which have plummeted from above $10 (U.S.) per million British thermal units to under $4, as hydraulic fracturing (”fracking”) and horizontal drilling have unlocked huge reserves of natural gas believed unreachable as recently as five years ago.

Similarly, according to a recent report from the International Energy Agency (http://www.iea.org/newsroomandevents/pressreleases/2013/may/name,38080,en.html[http://www.iea.org/newsroomandevents/pressreleases/2013/may/name,38080,en.html]), booming U.S. shale oil production will send “shock waves” through the global oil trade over the next five years, in a development that could be as dramatic as the rise of Chinese demand over the past 15 years. The IEA predicted in its latest report that the U.S. will overtake Saudi Arabia as the world’s top oil producer by 2017, thanks to horizontal drilling and fracking. At 7 million barrels a day, the U.S. is currently producing more oil than it has in 20 years.

Putting aside some issues related to water management and social acceptance in populated areas, booming shale oil activity is more than welcome to stimulate the economy in many states such as North Dakota, Louisiana, Wyoming, Montana and West Virginia (to name a few), which are involved in this energy revolution. In addition, prospects on external trade are improving, with U.S. oil imports having already dropped to their lowest level in 16 years.

As far as Canada is concerned, the improved U.S. economic outlook represents good news in the short term and won’t immediately threaten our oil exports south of the border, as Canada has outpaced OPEC as the U.S.’s number-one oil supplier. Over the medium and long term, however, we are much more concerned, since this new unconventional oil supply could have significant ramifications on global oil trade and the price outlook.

Heading towards a higher WCS oil price or a much lower WTI price?

So far, the negative impact of the combined surging oil production from U.S. shale oil and the Canadian oil sands has been limited to an unusual price gap between Western Canadian Select (WCS) and West Texas Intermediate (WTI) crude, stemming mostly from transportation bottlenecks and high level of maintenance from some U.S. refineries. The prevailing wisdom among Canadian experts is that this phenomenon is temporary, since the situation will correct itself when regulatory approval is received from Washington on the Keystone XL pipeline project or from the National Energy Board on several Canadian pipeline projects. We are not convinced.

If the traditional optimism from the IEA regarding oil demand increase (an additional 6 million barrels a day from 2012 to 2017) fails to materialize due to prolonged stagnation in Europe or a deceleration in the Chinese economy, we must be ready for much weaker oil prices – unless OPEC members agree to cut production. With its already shrinking global market share (now about 33 per cent), this potential call for OPEC to reduce production and maintain current elevated oil prices in order to accommodate surging North American production will become an intriguing open debate.

Bottom line: Canadian investors and policy makers should remain vigilant

Since Canada’s crude oil exports are a critical driver of high-paying jobs, royalties, taxes and, ultimately, federal equalization transfers, all Canadians should closely monitor the impact of this energy revolution south of the border. In the short term, like many pundits, we believe that the current U.S. shale oil boom will help the U.S.’s still frail economic recovery, and not greatly threaten Canadian oil exports and oil sands projects. However, Canadian political leaders should remain vigilant about the willingness of Capitol Hill to authorize the Keystone project, given the strong opposition from environmental groups regarding the oil sands carbon footprint and the U.S.’s possible energy independence in sight by 2030.

Down the road, investors should also monitor OPEC’s reaction (particularly that of Saudi Arabia, with its huge proven reserves), since artificially elevated oil prices will not necessarily be in their long-term strategic interests. Any intention from OPEC to protect market share, or a decision from Washington to reject the Keystone project ,will send a disconcerting message regarding oil sands expansion and be a potential game changer for Canada.

Clément Gignac is senior vice-president and chief economist at Industrial Alliance Inc., vice-chairman of the World Economic Forum Council on Competitiveness and a former cabinet minister in the Quebec government.

Globe and Mail Update

HD ENB Globe says Enbridge in a tough spot in Quebec
CR Stockwatch
WC 233 words
PD 27 May 2013
SN Canada Stockwatch
SC CNSW
LA English
CY (c) 2013 Canjex Publishing Ltd.

LP 

Enbridge Inc (TSX:ENB)

Shares Issued 823,022,699

TD 

Last Close 5/24/2013 $48.44

Monday May 27 2013 - In the News

The Globe and Mail reports in its Saturday edition that Quebeckers spend a lot of time arguing with each other through summits and public hearings, in the hopes of reaching an elusive consensus. The Globe's Sophie Cousineau writes the consultations that Environment Minister Yves-Francois Blanchet wants to hold on Enbridge's plans to reverse the flow of a pipeline to bring Western oil to Montreal are just the latest hearings in an ever expanding list. Quebec is suffering from a severe case of hearingitis, says The Globe. The government wants to ensure there is social acceptance before it green-lights the project, even if it is unclear Quebec has any legal say in the matter. The National Energy Board is already carrying its own public examination. But no one will say a word on this, certainly not Enbridge. Social acceptance is the new religion, to oppose this would be like declaring war on apple pie, suggests The Globe. The paper says many hearings and summits are an entirely predictable showdown between well-organized industry and green interests whose positions are irreconcilable. On such divisive issues as pipelines, reaching social acceptance is close to impossible, says Ms. Cousineau.


CO 
ipipf : Enbridge Inc

IN 
i1 : Energy | i13 : Crude Oil/Natural Gas | i1300006 : Pipeline Transportation

NS 
npress : Press Releases | ccat : Corporate/Industrial News | ncat : Content Types

RE 
cana : Canada | namz : North America

IPD 
In the News

PUB 
Canjex Publishing Ltd.

AN 
Document CNSW000020130527e95r000b6


CLM ENERGY
SE Report on Business Column
HD Dialogue of the hard of hearing
BY SOPHIE COUSINEAU
WC 872 words
PD 25 May 2013
SN The Globe and Mail
SC GLOB
PG B2
LA English
CY ©2013 The Globe and Mail Inc. All Rights Reserved.

LP 

MONTREAL -- scousineau@globeandmail.com

Common wisdom has it that Quebec's favourite sport is hockey. But scratch the surface and you might find that Quebeckers spend more time arguing with each other through summits and public hearings, in the hopes of reaching an elusive consensus, than actual time on an ice rink.

TD 

The consultations that Environment Minister Yves-François Blanchet wants to hold on Enbridge's plans to reverse the flow of a pipeline to bring western oil to Montreal are just the latest hearings in an ever-expanding list. Quebec is suffering from a severe case of hearingitis.

The government wants to ensure there is social acceptance before it green-lights the project, even if it is unclear Quebec has any legal say in the matter. The National Energy Board is already carrying its own public examination. But no one will say a word on this – certainly not Enbridge or Quebec's oil refiners, Suncor Energy Inc. and Valero Energy Corp., which would profit from access to cheaper Alberta oil.

Social acceptance is the new religion, and to oppose this would be like declaring war on apple pie. But the fact is many hearings and summits such as the one on mining royalties are a waste of time. More often than not, they are an entirely predictable showdown between well-organized industry and green interests whose positions are irreconcilable.

Most people are left confused after listening to this dialogue of the deaf. On such divisive issue as pipelines, reaching social acceptance is close to impossible.

This is a case where the Parti Québécois government should do what all governments have been elected to do: Put their pants on, make an informed decision and live with it.

Enbridge wants to reverse the flow of the pipeline, Line 9, that runs between Sarnia, Ont., and Montreal so that it goes eastward, and increase its capacity to 300,000 barrels per day from 240,000. Ironically, this was the line's original flow until the end of the 1990s, when imported oil became cheaper than western oil.

Environmentalists have been criticizing Enbridge's project as a way of condemning Alberta's “dirty” oil sands, even if the light crude that would be flowing East could also come from the United States or Saskatchewan. However, the problem really lies with Quebec's demand for oil.

The PQ government hopes to position the province as a green tech hub and plans to electrify some of its public transportation with its electricity surpluses. But until the province's crude consumption truly decreases – and this can't be done overnight – it will continue to buy oil.

Quebec currently imports its oil from Europe and North Africa. Is the oil extracted in Algeria and shipped by tanker so much cleaner than western oil? And what about the Alberta oil that is now making its way by train, with the risks associated with derailments, such as the one that happened in Jansen, Sask.?

The bigger issue is one of safety. Using pipelines is a secure way to ship oil, but when accidents happen they can be catastrophic, as in the Kalamazoo spill of 2010, when an estimated 20,000 barrels of oil were discharged near the Michigan River. This is where Quebec needs to get tough – especially since the federal Environment Commissioner recently concluded that Canada is ill equipped to handle a spill should a pipeline burst or a tanker run aground. There can be no complacency.

But once the necessary precautions are taken by the government and the industry, approving the reversal of Enbridge's pipeline should be a slam-dunk decision, so obvious are the benefits to Quebec.

Getting access to the cheaper Alberta oil will preserve, for the foreseeable future, Quebec's two last refineries: Suncor's in Montreal-East and Valero's in Saint-Romuald, on the south shore of Quebec City. Together, they employ around 1,000 workers. Montreal-East has already been hit hard with five refinery closures, and the dismantling of the Royal Dutch Shell refinery, where 800 people worked, is still a vivid memory.

Valero has also long committed to $140-million in additional investments in Quebec, should it access cheaper western oil, and the company's CEO, Brian Klesse, confirmed it this week again. The company plans to upgrade its Montreal-East equipment and maritime terminal at a cost of $110-million, and would invest another $30-million to expand its Saint-Romuald wharf. Another $60-million would help finance the acquisition of small tankers, but unless Chantier Davie Canada Inc. landed the contract, the money would be spent out of province.

That is only from Quebec's perspective; the money spent on western oil would also help Alberta and possibly narrow the price discount on Western Canada Select versus North Sea Brent crude. Quebec imported $13-billion worth of oil in 2012, which represented 60 per cent of the province's trade deficit, according to the Institut de la Statistique du Québec.

Jobs, investments and hey, even making friends in Alberta: Anyway you look at Enbridge's pipeline reversal project, this is a no-brainer.
